PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade how he justifies his own and the Prime Minister's statements, that as a result of the London Foreign Minister's meeting, there are no barriers to the resumption of sporting links with unified South African sports and that these could be resumed `straight away' when the facts show that the communique from the meeting agreed only that unified sports should be `recognised' in an unspecified way, subject to guidance by African National Congress (ANC) dominated unified sporting organisations, with the ANC still, by the way, being strongly opposed to the removal of sporting boycotts. Now that the Government appears to be admitting that the requirements of the Gleneagles agreement are being met, do the Prime Minister's statements mean that the Hawke Government is planning to resume sporting links, despite continuing ANC opposition and without further referral to a Commonwealth meeting on this subject which has been deferred until November?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said yesterday, in response to an interjection from Senator Michael Baume, there is absolutely no need for him to get his knickers in a twist about this. The sporting issue is being considered and resolved in a way that is entirely sensible and rational and meets the concerns, certainly, of the ANC and, certainly, of those of us who believe that it is appropriate that there be some measured response to the pace of change that is now occurring in South Africa.

ANSWER.PARA: The decision reached at the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers meeting over the weekend was as I described it yesterday. There was agreement in principle that those sports achieving unity should be recognised by the international community. There is further agreement that that pro- cess of recognition should take place in consultation with the relevant black African sporting bodies which, for the sake of completeness, I indicate from the discussions so far amount to the following: first of all, there is the Steering Committee on South African Sports, the so-called C10, which consists of representatives from the National Olympic and Sports Congress, including Mr Mluleki George, who was in Australia last week, the South African Non-Racial Olympic Committee, including Mr Ramsamy, the South African Council of Sport and a number of other familiar organisations.

Secondly, there is the Monitoring Committee of African Sport Representatives, which has been formed under the auspices of ANOCA, the African National Olympic Committees Association. Thirdly, in the wider international community, there is the Apartheid and Olympism Commission established by the International Olympic Committee (IOC). It is understood, intended and expected that there will be consultation with all those different bodies before there is any actual implementation of international sports contact. But the basic principle that has been agreed is that that process of international recognition and the modification that is implied accordingly of the Gleneagles agreement should occur in relation to and only in relation to those sports which achieve a unified administration.

So that is the set of principles that has been agreed. The working out of those principles will take some time. The pre-condition is, of course, that unity be achieved in the particular sport. As I have indicated in relation to those sports in which Australia is interested, we expect that to be achieved in relation to cricket around the middle of the year; we expect it to be achieved in relation to the Olympic sports by the end of the year; and we do not know when it is going to be achieved so far as rugby is concerned.

In any event, the process of moving from recognition of a sport as ripe and timely for international contacts to the point of actually having those contacts is something else again. There will be lead times involved, planning, preparation, tour dates to be fixed and so on. It is premature to speculate about just how early that could occur. I simply say again that the momentum is there. The principles have been agreed in a separate and distinct category of consideration from the principles governing sanctions at large, and they appear in different sections of the communique to reflect that particular reality.

Since Senator Baume makes the point, what has happened has been done not in any way against the opposition of the ANC. On the contrary, the particular process that I have outlined and described is entirely consistent with what the ANC has indicated to us that it would like to see happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister very much for that answer and for his clear distinction between the word `recognition' and the agreement to play sport. I ask the Minister: what indications does he have from the ANC that it will agree before the Harare meeting in November to play sport, not just to recognise a sporting body? What indications does he have from the ANC which would justify the Prime Minister's statement that as soon as sporting bodies are unified one could begin playing sport `straightaway'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to go into detail about the nature of the communications with the ANC that have led me to express the conclusion I have, except to say that on the basis of all the contacts I have had-including at a very high level last weekend with the ANC, as well as before that-I am completely confident that the pattern of response that I have described is not only acceptable to but is positively being encouraged by the ANC as an appropriate response.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the Prime Minister's remarks, they are entirely consistent with what I have said. There is a sequence; there is a pattern of events being laid out. The pre-condition is unity and once that unity is achieved, we fully expect the rest of the steps to fall immediately into place.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications and concerns the situation on radio 2XX in Canberra in which a radio commentator, Mr David McMullen, was sacked from the station for `deliberately breaking the spirit of 2XX's policy of opposition to the war'. I ask: firstly, is that policy in breach of public broadcasting guidelines? Secondly, what action is being taken on that matter? Thirdly, should the name of the station be changed from 2XX to 2WANK?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have read that newspaper report and, as I understand it, so has the Minister. I will have to qualify what I say by making the statement that I have not had time to find out whether the details of the report are accurate-and I read it this morning. I am doing that now and the Minister's office is, indeed, doing it. It is an ongoing dispute. I understand that the allegedly sacked announcer and the manager of the radio station have both given interviews today on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, which I have not heard either.

ANSWER.PARA: If the substance of the story is accurate, there is no question that this action is in breach of the very purpose for which public radio was established by this Government. It is something that I know the Minister is disturbed about, and so am I. It seems an extraordinary action. I remind honourable senators-not that they need to be reminded-that the very purpose of setting up public radio was to provide a wide range of diverse opinion on a wide range of subjects. My own experience in public radio, in which I have an interest in my own neck of the woods, is that by and large public radio has fulfilled that expectation very well indeed. This is the first time to my knowledge that such an extraordinary action has apparently been taken.

The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is responsible for oversighting the conditions of public radio licenses. It would appear that, if the substance of the story is correct, the action is absolutely in breach of those requirements. I can assure Senator Aulich that, if he or any other member of the public aggrieved by this action-I stress again that we are currently examining this-complains directly to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, the Tribunal will investigate it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to an address by the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Fraser, this morning to the International Union of Housing Finance Institutions, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Activity should pick up during the second half of 1991, aided by . . . the counter-cyclical workings of fiscal policy.
This would appear to be at odds with a statement by the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, on the AM program on Friday, when he said:
There has been no attempt by the Government to say, well, there's a recession, we should therefore loosen off on fiscal policy. That's not part of our thinking at all.

In light of these apparently conflicting statements, can the Minister advise what the Government sees as the prime role for fiscal policy in a recession, or is Alan Wood right in his suggestion in today's Australian when he says:
Unfortunately, it-
the Government-
doesn't seem to have any idea what the objective of fiscal policy is any more.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, fiscal policy under this Government has been very tight-tighter of course than any fiscal policy administered by any previous government.
—That is ancient history.

—I am not talking in terms of ancient history. It is talking in terms of political will. In answer to the question let me say that I have not read Mr Fraser's speech, but inevitably in a time of recession fiscal policy operates in a counter-cyclical way because the surplus is reduced by cyclical factors associated with a recession: unemployment benefits rise, corporate taxes go down. And inevitably that happens in a time of recession. So a surplus is reduced or a deficit-which is more familiar to Opposition senators than to us-rises. There is nothing surprising about that. What Mr Willis was saying in his comments the other day was that fiscal policy, as it affects government expenditure, has to be maintained tightly by the Government in the circumstances. That is what Mr Willis was talking about. I do not see any inconsistencies between the two, but I will look at Mr Fraser's speech to see whether there is any wisdom hidden in the depths of the speech which has not been revealed by the honourable senator's question.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. Would the Minister inform the Senate of the current activities of ships of the Royal Australian Navy and other Australian personnel in the Gulf? Would the Minister also outline the perceived threat to Australian Defence Force personnel in this region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —All three Royal Australian Navy ships deployed in the Gulf region are operating in the Arabian Gulf supporting multinational force operations against Iraqi forces. The primary threat to shipping in the Gulf is from free-floating mines. In the northern Arabian Gulf the threat is further increased by minefields laid by Iraq to counter allied operations in the Kuwait area. The possibility of air launched missile attacks, mostly Exocet, cannot yet be discounted. The Iraqi surface naval threat has been neutralised. The HMAS Brisbane is located in the central Arabian Gulf conducting anti-aircraft warning support to the multinational force warships in the area, and HMAS Sydney is operating further to the north on search and rescue activities but outside the area of highest probability of Iraqi minefields.

ANSWER.PARA: The HMAS Westralia is conducting replenishment operations with the multinational force warships operating in the southern and central Arabian Gulf. A clearance diving team is training in the Bahrain area with United States Navy personnel. They are on stand-by for explosive ordnance disposal tasks and mine clearance tasks in the Arabian Gulf.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to the reported statement of the Prime Minister in Tasmania over the weekend. The Prime Minister is reported as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: Federal resource security is not necessary for new projects, such as pulp mills, to go ahead. In order to get a development you don't necessarily have to have federal legislation.

Has the Government made a firm decision not to pass so-called resource security legislation either in respect of Tasmania or the mainland, now or throughout its present term of office? Does Mr Griffiths' reply to a question in the House of Representatives yesterday mean that the Federal Government, while not passing resource security legislation itself, does intend to rubber stamp such legislation if passed by the States? If the Government does not intend any resource security legislation, does this commitment relate only to forests as a resource or does this undertaking extend to all resources? Finally, if the answers to parts 1 and 3 of this question are yes, can one draw from these decisions that the Government is beginning to understand that sustainable development not only means maintaining supplies of a sought after resource such as timber but also maintaining in perpetuity the rich biodiversity of forests of which exploitable tree species are but a small part?

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is in four parts. I might deal with them one by one. Firstly, the Government has made no decision on whether to proceed with resource security legislation. Secondly, the Government has repeatedly said that if a proposal is brought forward by a State government it will be given prompt consideration. In that sense, having given those two answers to the first two questions, questions 3 and 4 are not applicable. Let me say, however, that in respect of the last part of question 4, where Senator Coulter raises the question of the biodiversity issue, yes, the Government understands that.

—I also address a question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I remind the Minister of the Prime Minister's statement, reported in the Adelaide Advertiser of 21 January, that the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein would `love nothing better than to destroy the joint United States-Australian defence bases at Pine Gap and Nurrungar' and, further, his statement on the record that the bases were `not irrelevant' to the conduct of aspects of the Gulf war. Does this statement not give the lie to the oftrepeated claim that the facilities are only for verification of arms control agreements? Does it not in fact confirm the claims made by me and others in this place, and by respected scholars elsewhere, that the facilities are literally about war fighting through the interception of Iraqi communications? Does it not highlight the need for a more comprehensive and candid statement about the roles of these facilities than the Government's masters in Washington have yet allowed it to make?

—There are three questions there. The answer to the first question is no; the answer to the second question is no; and the answer to the third question is that the assumptions that are inherent are invalid.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. It seems that the Government is very reluctant to answers questions on this very sensitive subject. I ask the Minister: is that fear to answer the question in any way connected to the possible role of one or more of these facilities in the horrendous United States bombing of a Baghdad air-raid shelter causing hundreds of civilian casualties? Does the Government like having innocent blood on its hands?

—Senator Vallentine says that Ministers are reluctant to answer questions because of fear. I answered three questions Senator Vallentine asked me. The difference between my answers and Senator Vallentine's questions is that her questions were highly verbose and my answers were precise. If that is induced by fear, I am sorry.

—I address my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask about Australia's decision to normalise relations with China, to which I have urged the Australian Government to move immediately. I refer to radio reports today and to a front page article in today's Sydney Morning Herald. I ask: what is the timing for the Minister announcing Australia's decision? Besides normalisation of ministerial, parliamentary and official visits between the two countries, what other elements are included in the decision? Will the significant exception to the removal of sanctions be the current restrictions on defence sales and visits by some security officials?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has made no decision on this question and accordingly matters of timing do not come into it so far as when a decision already made will be announced. No decision has been made. I have said publicly-indeed I did it in answer to Senator Teague's adjournment speech the other night-that the Government is giving close consideration to these questions.

ANSWER.PARA: The background is as follows: following events in China in June 1989, as honourable senators will recall, we announced a few days later, on 13 July, a series of quite substantial restrictions in respect of Australia's official relations with China, which very substantially downgraded the relationship. Those measures were based on a series of principles which we articulated at the time: our global human rights concerns and interests; our concern to avoid action which would harm the ordinary Chinese people, and our encouragement of moderation and liberalisation within China by all appropriate means, keeping open channels of communication but at the same time preserving Australia's long term strategic and commercial interests. All those principles were relevant to the decision.

In January 1990 the Government essentially reaffirmed the decisions taken in July the previous year, but the policy was modified in two areas: to lift the blanket ban which had hitherto applied on ministerial visits and to consider them henceforth on a case-by-case basis, and to authorise me, in consultation with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), to make adjustments to other elements of the policy framework as appropriate.

Although there have been a number of improvements evident in the human rights situation over the course of the past year, which will be very much in our minds as we evaluate the competing considerations now, I want to say clearly on the public record that we remain very concerned about the condition of human rights in China and the inhibitions on dissent in any form, and we will certainly continue to make strong representations to the People's Republic of China (PRC) authorities, both bilaterally and in multilateral forums such as the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, of which China is a member.

The other night in the adjournment debate I indicated that the Government is giving close consideration to a number of remaining restrictions, in particular the suspended procedures for consideration of new proposals for technical cooperation and agricultural research projects, the suspended consideration of concessional finance for development projects and the question of parliamentary and formal party visits. I made it clear then, and do so again now, that there are two other restrictions still extant apart from those, to which we are not giving any consideration or modification at this stage-defence sales and visits by security officials, because of their obvious continuing sensitivity.

In considering these issues, we are taking into account the nature of our relationship with China, the various matters of principle to which I earlier referred and also current developments in the attitudes and policy responses of likeminded countries. That process is a continuing one and, when the Government has decided to make any policy change, it will make an appropriate announcement.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware that the Australian Council for Overseas Aid claims that the Gulf crisis has already cost developing countries over half the total development assistance they receive from all sources? Can the Minister give an assurance that the Australian Government will give special attention to this critical funding need when overseas aid is considered in the 1991-92 Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of claims by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid that more attention needs to be given to the impact of the Gulf crisis on developing countries. As a government, we certainly recognise the problems that have hit many developing countries as a direct result of the Gulf crisis. The media have tended to concentrate only on some aspects of those problems, for example, the refugee issues and the displacement of guest workers from Iraq and Kuwait, without I think giving sufficient attention to some of the longer term considerations.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the case that many developing countries have suffered very real and very substantial economic hardship, and that will continue long after the conflict ends. The major economic losses arise from the loss of remittances of guest workers, which is a very substantial contribution to a number of developing country budgets; the loss of export revenue as a result of trade sanctions-we are feeling that here, and it is being felt even more harshly in a number of other countries; and in particular oil price pressures on the balance of payments difficulties. That is not so acute at the moment because oil prices have come down, but for the long months of uncertainty before the actual conflict broke out the substantial increase in oil prices was having a devastating effect on a very large number of country budgets.

Quantifying the economic impact of the Gulf crisis in this respect is, however, extremely difficult. The World Bank is doing some valuable work in this area. We are receiving its assessments and continuing to monitor the situation but there is nothing that I can report at the moment in terms of a precise and credible quantification. We appreciate the difficulties that are being faced, as I have indicated, by developing countries. As to the last part of the honourable senator's question, we will certainly bear that in mind in considering our options for the 1991-92 aid budget. However, it is premature to speculate at this stage on the outcome of that deliberation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES: JOINT VENTURE

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to the joint venture between the Department of Administrative Services (DAS), IBM Australia Ltd and Wizard, which joint venture has also tendered to the Department of Administrative Services for a Department of Veterans' Affairs contract for computer equipment and for an Australian Customs Service contract for a $200m replacement for its central computer system. I ask the Minister: what is IBM's relationship with Wizard? How does he reconcile the quite obvious conflict of interest in that the determination of tenders will be recommended by one of the participants? Does he have any recognition at all that his actions will only serve to limit competitive tendering to the Government for computer equipment? Is he heading down the same track as Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia and creating his own version of Labor Inc. in the Commonwealth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should probably thank Senator Parer for the compliment at the end of his question. I am sure, however, that that degree of power does not emanate from the portfolio of Administrative Services and that, if power did rest in that area, I would not exercise it in that way. The rest of Senator Parer's question raises a genuine issue which needs to be responded to seriously, unlike the last part of the question. There has been a restructuring of the Department of Administrative Services to bring together under one division all the various information technology responsibilities within the Department.

ANSWER.PARA: The question that Senator Parer raises appeared in a column in the Canberra Times on 11 February, so this time the honourable senator is only nine or 10 days late. It was suggested in that article that, by placing the DAS role in oversighting the information technology tendering process in the same division as the branch of DAS which supplies information technology services, a conflict of interest could emerge. Some steps have been taken to keep the two branches of the organisation separate, but I have had discussions with the head of the Department in recent days to look at how we can ensure that there is no conflict that negates competitive and fair tendering. Some of the aspects of our discussion relate to the structuring of the organisation and whether it needs once again to be reviewed; and secondly, whether we need some code of ethics to guide the operation of this branch.

In the interim I have been given an assurance that the two areas of the Department that are involved in information technology have not been merged in a structural physical sense at this stage, and there has been no contact between the information technology services branch and the oversight branch in this instance. However, this is an area that to me poses a potential conflict and one that I will be addressing.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Does the Government intend to adopt the Leader of the Opposition's proposal, reported in the Sunday Age, that education payments to the States be replaced by a system of vouchers paid directly to individuals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Foreman raises an issue which highlights not only the Government's attitude to policy in education but also major differences and distinctions between us and the Opposition. This particular issue starkly shows the areas of difference-the lack of application which has been shown by the Leader of the Opposition in what is merely a top of the head policy projection, with no intellectual or financial rigour applied to it. As well, it indicates the commitment to ideology over a commitment towards practical solutions. The Leader of the Opposition contends that we do not have a workable practical solution. To evidence that we should look at how funding operates at the moment and compare that to the proposal that has been floated over the weekend.

ANSWER.PARA: Current arrangements for government funding of education services provide for three important goals, and they are goals that have been attained under this Government and are valuable ones. Firstly, there is an agreed and assured division of financial responsibility between the Commonwealth, States and individuals. Secondly, we have a pursuit of agreed goals in education. Those are goals which I am sure members of this Senate have been involved in for some time through Senate committees to achieve and define. Thirdly, there is the provision of special support via targeted programs and other equity measures to individuals and institutions disadvantaged in their access to educational resources. They are the three benchmarks of our policy directions and they provide equity and access in education.

Let us compare those to the policy of the Leader of the Opposition. The first result of Professor Hewson's policy would be to increase the potential for transfer to financial responsibility from governments to individuals. Of course, that would quite directly necessitate the introduction of fees where none currently exist and would involve the extension of increase in fees and charges where they already exist. The second disastrous effect would be to fragment and divide the system of education. It would be much more difficult to pursue common goals and policy strategies in the national interest if one divides the system in the way Professor Hewson suggests. Thirdly, it would leave the decision of allocation of resources largely to market forces without regard to assessment of relative need of individuals and institutions. Therefore, one would increase the present inequities in access to education. The end result would be to create confusion, uncertainty and administrative complexity on the one hand, and on the other hand it would exacerbate inequity and would waste resources. The short answer to Senator Foreman's question is no.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Has Radio Australia moved to fill the position of executive producer of Radio Australia's Vietnam program by seeking applicants from the Hanoi Ministry of Culture, Information, Tourism and Sports? Is the Minister aware of the communique of the Australian Ambassador to Vietnam, Mr Alliband, to the director of Radio Australia which said that `details of the position have been passed to contacts in the Vietnamese journalists association and the Ministry of Culture and Information who will advise Radio Australia of any suitable candidates that emerge for that position'.

—I have not the slightest idea. I have had a look and the responsible Minister has not provided me with a brief on the matter. I will provide Senator Crichton-Browne with an undertaking that I will obtain an answer and will try to get it today.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. With overseas travel scaling down because of the Middle East war, what measures, if any, are being implemented to channel would-be overseas travellers towards domestic tourism destinations? Have any programs been organised to promote the advantages of holidaying in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I do not think we can point to any official data yet, because the Gulf war has not been going that long, I think there is a fair degree of anecdotal evidence that Australians may well be changing their travel plans to favour domestic destinations. Both industry and press reports suggest that many Australians have recently postponed spending on overseas travel, and outbound corporate business is well below normal expectations. I think Qantas Airways Ltd can certainly confirm both of those points. Therefore, there may be opportunities for the tourism industry to focus greater attention on domestic holiday destinations to attract those Australians who have recently deferred overseas travel plans.

ANSWER.PARA: Responsibility for the promotion of those domestic tourism destinations, however, does rest with State and Territory tourism authorities. This was reaffirmed at a meeting of Commonwealth, State and Territory tourism Ministers last October at which Ministers agreed that it was not the appropriate role of the Commonwealth to be involved in domestic advertising or promotion campaigns. Any Commonwealth involvement would, therefore, need to be supported by State and Territory governments and done in close cooperation with them, as occurred after the pilots dispute. In response to the downturn in outbound travel, several of the State authorities have indicated that they are going to strengthen their domestic promotion if it is in order to secure some of the potential increase in domestic travel.

State and Territory tourism Ministers, or their representatives, met last week with Mr Simmons, the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, to discuss the effects of the Gulf war on the tourism industry. The meeting agreed that, from a national perspective, the Australian Tourist Commission should continue to actively promote Australia overseas to ensure that our share of international travel is maintained. That will include the Greg Norman advertisements which will be shown in both the United States of America and Japan in April and May of this year. The campaign will be funded, of course, from the additional $23m in funding for the Tourist Commission which was announced by the Government in only December of last year.

However, the Government and the Australian Tourist Commission are not just about short term responses. It is important that the Tourist Commission's programs overseas continue at this time to ensure not only that we pick up business which is being diverted from other destinations now by fears about the war but also that they are well placed to spring back once the war ends.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Can the Minister explain to the Senate why it has been necessary to form a ministerial working group of senior Ministers to oversee waterfront and shipping reform and, apparently, his handling of the matter? What is it that this group is going to achieve that the Minister has not been able to achieve? In view of this obvious lack of confidence shown in him by senior Ministers, has the Minister offered his resignation to the Prime Minister in advance of his 6 May automatic resignation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is about as sensible as the non-stop comments that Senator Macdonald has been making about the situation in the port of Cairns. I must say that since that situation was moved to be resolved a fortnight ago, we have not heard from him on the issue. But if I could just take the rare opportunities that are offered to me by the Opposition to talk in the Senate about the waterfront and explain--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, let us have a debate on it. The setting up of the ministerial working group arose directly out of a meeting that I had late last year with the Prime Minister. The meeting with the Prime Minister was requested by me late last year to urge on all of the parties that are involved in this process-that is, the only significant overhaul of the waterfront situation in this country for half a century-the urgency that the Government places on it and the need to expedite it.

ANSWER.PARA: The reality is that the report of the Inter-State Commission on what should be done to reform the waterfront was welcomed by the Opposition. In fact, even John Sharp applauded it and supported its recommendations. The process that we have in place is absolutely based on those recommendations at that time applauded by the Opposition.

Might I say, quite unblushingly, that that process rests, for its successful conclusion, on agreement. It is a process of consensus, not coercion, which this Government is giving all of the parties involved in this very important issue an opportunity to take up. It is the first best option that this Government-indeed, any government-should adopt, because it is not just getting the agreements, as I have said to the Senate before, that is important; getting them effectively implemented, that is, willingly implemented, is just as important.

Before we go to the second best option, which is the one the Opposition wants us to adopt now, without specifying it-this is the `take the gloves off and get tough with the unions' approach-the maximum amount of pressure has to be brought to bear on the parties. I put that view to the Prime Minister last year and suggested to him that we needed to upgrade that pressure publicly, even if it was at the slight expense of any ego I might have. The Prime Minister agreed and, I must say, I was very pleased to be able to announce the formation of this group in Sydney a fortnight ago. It has held its first meeting and that meeting was productive. As a result of that meeting there will be further meetings held this week between the Prime Minister, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, unions and myself to stress again to the parties the need to go with the first best option-that is, the agreement and consensus option-before the Government is in a position to declare that option invalid and move to the other options available to the Government.

I conclude by saying this: the facts are that all of the `get tough' options that are available are certainly available and I am familiar with all of them. But the situation is that these cannot be applied in parallel with getting an agreement with the waterfront unions which will provide, firstly, the best level of reform available and, secondly, the most sustainable level of reform available. The Government is committed to that process and it will be successfully resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Does the Minister's answer indicate that he is simply incapable, by himself, of handling the matter of waterfront reform?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that Senator Macdonald, when and if the Opposition ever gets into government, is not part of any prospective ministry. I do not think there is any great risk of that. I point out to Senator Macdonald that the Government is in fact that-the Government-and it is the Government's policy that is going to be implemented on the waterfront. I both solicited and appreciated the involvement of all the other affected Ministers in this process. The situation was quite simple.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been having, as the Ministers themselves are well aware, a series of one-to-one consultations with other Ministers with a direct involvement. I am not-I assure Senator Macdonald-isolated in the sense that I am the only one with an interest in this matter. The Minister for Industry, the Minister for Trade and the Treasurer have a direct involvement in it, as does the Prime Minister. I suggested last year that, rather than continue to have these ad hoc discussions with a whole range of Ministers, it would be useful at this time to formalise that process in a meeting of those Ministers. In fact, that has been a successful process. I welcome it. It will help put some more pressure on the parties and I am absolutely confident that the first best option-that is, reform by agreement-will be achieved and it will meet the targets set by the Government.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EARLY RELEASE PROGRAMS: UNEMPLOYMENT BENEFIT FOR PARTICIPANTS

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. I refer to reports that millions of dollars are to be spent on upgrading the Adelaide-Melbourne rail line near the Victorian-South Australian border and I ask: can the Minister please advise as to the timetable of the spending and exactly what is being done to upgrade the line? Can he also advise of any discussions on the actual routing of the line between Adelaide and Melbourne?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an important matter and the Minister for Land Transport has provided me with the following advice. On 27 August 1990, the Minister announced that the Federal Government would contribute $21m to Australian National to upgrade 100 kilometres of the Melbourne to Adelaide main line. There is, however, no plan at this stage to re-route the line. The money will be provided under the land transport development program.

ANSWER.PARA: The work is expected to start late this year and will take three years to complete. It will involve the replacement of old wooden sleepers with gauge convertible concrete sleepers. This will reduce the travelling time between Melbourne and Adelaide by about 30 minutes, substantially reduce maintenance costs and the problem with derailments. It will also facilitate cost effective conversion of this section of the track, should a decision be taken later to standardise the gauge on this particular line.

Australian National expects benefits of about $1m a year to flow from this project. The improved transit times and better reliability should prove attractive to shippers and induce an increased share of freight traffic between these cities onto rail. It is the type of project that would assist the operations of the proposed national rail freight corporation. Use of concrete sleepers will mean also that, over the 50-year life span of these sleepers, 5,600 river red gums will not need to be felled.

—I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations whether he can confirm to the Senate that the Industrial Relations Commission has recently ratified the merger agreement between the Building Workers Industrial Union and the Builders Labourers Federation. If he can confirm this, would he advise honourable senators what the implications are for the building industry in the areas of industrial peace and productivity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday at 2.15 in the Federal Industrial Relations Commission in Sydney, Deputy President Moore issued a consent order proposing steps to amalgamate the Building Workers Industrial Union and the four State registered builders labourers federations in Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania and Western Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposal that Moore sanctioned is a proposal for an eight-year, slow-track amalgamation, able to be accelerated by any of the constituent unions in particular circumstances that apply in each of the States. The signs already are that there is considerable interest in stitching together that amalgamation much more quickly in some of those States so that the building industry will have before it the prospect of one building industry union.

Senator McKiernan asks me what this portends for industrial relations in the building industry. I think it portends a number of quite significant and important developments. It certainly opens the way for award restructuring to be realised more practically and across the wide scope of all the classifications-trade, semi-skilled and part-skilled certificated men who operate in the building industry-in order to get a more multi-skilled, universal trades type in the building industry and achieve some of the efficiencies that that type of restructuring has achieved in other industries in Australia.

As well, it means that the Government's micro-economic reform program for the building industry, a large part of which relates to industrial relations, can now be achieved at a much quicker pace than would otherwise be the case. That being the case, there stands to be the prospect of the building industry being able to continue to produce in Australia a high quality product at a cheaper price and on time.

All of the parties-some of whom have put aside long-running political grievances-are to be congratulated in coming this far. I hope that the legal framework they have consented to, and now endorsed by the Commission, is realised in the personal relationships that emerge and the stability that will bring on the union side of industrial relations. I know that many employer spokespersons have hailed this as a significant change and look forward to working with the new organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is it a fact that the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission is refusing to issue guidelines about the content of company prospectuses? Further, is the Minister aware that capital raising through prospectuses are being avoided by business? Finally, given the lack of legislative detail or direction, does not such irresponsible action on the part of the Chairman lead to further concentration of the capital markets into the hands of large institutions to the detriment of small investors?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the specific statement that has been attributed to Mr Hartnell, the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission. But I am confident that in general his intention in administering the law passed by this Parliament as recently as late December of last year would be to encourage the capacity of Australian businesses and those involved in trade and commerce throughout Australia to attract the necessary capital which would enable them to undertake either the launching or the expansion of their business activities.

ANSWER.PARA: After all, this Parliament had, as one of its prime objects in accepting political responsibility for the shaping and moulding of corporate securities law, the need to inject confidence in investors in the corporate sector. This confidence had been shattered by the fragmentation of companies and securities regulation due to the inability of the federal structure of our Commonwealth to comprehensively provide for the national market that was emerging and recognised, for example, by the stock exchanges in the need for the raising of capital.

I am confident that Mr Hartnell would be at pains to ensure that all companies which have a need for access to capital are able to obtain it. He certainly would not be devising rules or modes of operation of the Australian Securities Commission which only favoured the larger organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support aware of media comments in rural New South Wales expressing concern about proposed changes in airspace management practices which, it is alleged, `will jeopardise the safety of aircraft'? PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans, for Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:

(1) That, in accordance with section 242 of the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989, matters relating to the powers and proceedings of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities shall be as follows:

(a) That the committee consist of 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 2 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority groups or independent Senators.
(b) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(c) That the committee elect a member nominated by the Government Whips or the Leader of the Government in the Senate as its chairman.

(d) That the committee elect a deputy chairman who shall act as chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee, and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another member to act as chairman at that meeting.
(e) That, in the event of the votes on a question before the committee being equally divided, the chairman, or the deputy chairman when acting as chairman, have a casting vote.
(f) That 5 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(g) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any subcommittee any matter which the committee is empowered to examine.

(h) That the committee appoint the chairman of each subcommittee who shall have a casting vote only, and at any time when the chairman of a subcommittee is not present at a meeting of a subcommittee the members of the subcommittee present shall elect another member of that subcommittee to act as chairman at that meeting.
(i) That the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the members of that subcommittee.

(j) That members of the committee who are not members of a subcommittee may participate in the proceedings of that subcommittee but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum.
(k) That the committee and a subcommittee have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(l) That the committee and a subcommittee have power to move from place to place.
(m) That a subcommittee have power to adjourn from time to time and to sit during any adjournment of the Senate and the House of Representatives.
(n) That a subcommittee have power to authorise publication of any evidence given before it and any document presented to it.
(o) That the committee have leave to report from time to time.
(p) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.
(q) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution be communicated by message to the House of Representatives with a request for the concurrence of that House in the resolution.

This Bill seeks appropriations of the Consolidated Revenue Fund in 1990-91 totalling $234.1 million.
The Bill provides for certain proposed expenditure for the ordinary annual services of Government, in addition to the amounts which were appropriated by Parliament at Budget time.

Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1990-91 contains provision under Division 310 for an Advance to the Minister for Finance of $170 million to enable the Minister to make money available, inter alia, for expenditure which is urgently required and was unforeseen at the time of preparation of the Bill for that Act. The amounts in this Bill are being sought in advance of the Additional Estimates to meet urgent requirements which have arisen as a consequence of the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq on 2 August last year.

The Bill now before this Chamber provides for $181.4 million for payment by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce to meet insurance claims associated with defaults by Iraq on credit sales by the Australian Wheat Board, which were insured under the National Interest provisions of the Australian Trade Commission Act. This amount, to meet the Government's immediate obligation under National Interest insurance provisions, is payable prior to funds becoming available under the Additional Estimates and is to meet payments falling due on the first of each month. A further $27.5 million will be provided in subsequent years: $23.6 million in 1991-92 and $3.9 million in 1992-93.
