TALK.START.PARA: —I take up this afternoon the theme that I was pursuing last evening in explaining why the Opposition is opposing the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill 1990. I had made the point, during the course of my speech last night, that although Iraq is a party to the four Geneva conventions it has not constrained its behaviour or its actions. I cited many of the things that Iraq has perpetrated during the course of this war. I referred to the use of missiles on the populations in the suburbs of Jerusalem. Indeed, if we go back further we can recall the use of chemical warfare against ethnic members of its own community, namely the Kurds.

SPEECH.PARA: The agreement to the Convention by Iraq was not by signature but by act of accession, yet still that country is not constrained in its behaviour. Last night I pointed out to the Senate, and I do so again, that simply to ratify the protocol that is the subject of this Bill would, in fact, in no way ameliorate our enemy's behaviour and would, indeed, act, or could act, as a fetter on the proper conduct of the war in a way that I will outline during the course of the rest of my speech.

I would remind the Senate just precisely what the four conventions are which Australia is seeking to ratify and, indeed, to which Iraq has acceded. Firstly, there is a convention for the amelioration of the condition of the wounded and sick in armed forces in the field; secondly, a convention for the amelioration of the condition of wounded, sick and shipwrecked members of armed forces at sea; thirdly, a convention relevant to the treatment of prisoners of war; and, fourthly, a convention relevant to the protection of civilian persons in time of war.

These conventions became part of our domestic law in 1957 under the Geneva Conventions Act. Under that Act it became an indictable offence for a person in Australia or elsewhere to commit, aid, abet or procure the commission by another person of a grave breach of any of the conventions. I have already given the Senate examples of where Iraq has breached those Conventions. I mentioned the allied pilots captured by Iraqi forces who were humiliated, beaten and forced to make false statements.

The 1977 protocols, which are the subject, as I have said, of the Bill, were an attempt to codify the existing treaty and customary international law relating to the rules of warfare and add new law to govern the conduct of hostilities. The result is complex and uncertain. For the Government to simply say that the Australian defence forces have no quarrel with their implementation, and indeed there is no way in which our own forces could be wrongly caught by the provisions of the Bill, is simply unable to be said with certainty. As I have said, the resulting codification of existing law and the protocols is complex and uncertain. This is evidenced by a commentary on these additional protocols which was published in Geneva in 1987, a formidable document of some 1,625 pages-surely not necessary if the law was to be clear-cut.

The Opposition is thus opposing the legislation. Reasons that we include for opposing the Bill are these: our allies, the United States, take the view that the protocol is fundamentally and irreconcilably flawed and that a number of the provisions of the protocol are militarily unacceptable. Left wing members of the Government have argued in this chamber that somehow that is an indictment of us because we are agreeing with our allies and they engaged in their usual form of United States bashing. On the other hand, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his letter to former President Reagan, acknowledged that the protocol contains a number of ambiguities and operational complexities.

If in our region, for instance, our allies and potential adversaries had not ratified the protocol, the benefits of the protocol would appear to be more illusory than real. The impact of the obligations on the Australian Defence Force (ADF) are real and immediate in terms of training obligations and operational restrictions. In practice, our adversaries-whether they be nation states or liberation movements-may only pay lip service to their obligations under the protocol.

The protocol is vague. It is excessively legalistic. This is perhaps illustrated by the fact that article 82 requires that a legal adviser be available to advise military commanders on the application of the protocol and its effect upon military manoeuvres. Clearly, that is almost something which one would expect to be written into a farce. The preceding comment is further illustrated by the open-ended nature of article 5 which prohibits the use of unspecified methods of warfare which may-and the word is `may'-cause superfluous injury or unnecessary suffering. One immediately asks the question: in whose judgment, and is the judgment to be made before or after the event?

As I said yesterday, certain Government speakers made statements which inferred that the Australian defence forces were in fact content to go along with the protocols passing into our domestic law; whereas the more accurate view would be this: that in attempting to protect civilians, protocol No. 1 places unrealistic limitations on fighting forces. The Gulf war has provided ample example of the way the protocol would complicate matters. The destruction of civilian infrastructure, including roads, airfields, oil refineries and water supplies, may be essential to reducing an opponent's capacity to fight, but the protocol outlaws those attacks.

The protocol also limits the use of covert operations. It places unrealistic requirements on identification of enemy combatants, which is particularly problematic in guerilla war, and by restricting attacks which would have led to environmental damage by limiting scope for retaliatory strikes. One even asks whether that well-known tactic which became quite famous during World War II, which was made famous in a movie called The Man Who Never Was, would now be considered an acceptable tactic. It was a method of misleading the enemy as to what the intention for the invasion was to be.
The view of the Australian Defence Force is perhaps better expressed this way: the ADF's legal section has decided that the Defence Force could `live with' the protocol.

This is hardly what we would call an enthusiastic endorsement and one not shared by many front-end force commanders. The problem, of course, which the ADF has is that this piece of legislation is a matter of government policy and, therefore, in a very real way, it is constrained in taking an active stance. However, in the quasi-official Defence Force Journal the view was put:

The ADF has not promoted ratification of the Protocols, that being a Governmental responsibility, but has acted responsibly in providing advice on their military acceptability. There is more than a semantic difference between the two positions but there is some danger of the two being merged in coming months before resumption of the debate in Parliament.

That article was dated January-February 1991. As I said last night, the timing of this legislation being brought on to debate was extraordinary to say the least. In the middle of hostilities, when we have our troops exposed, it has become quite clear that the left wing of the Australian Labor Party has managed to roll the more sound voices in the Government to bring it on and the Government is simply pacifying the Left by allowing the debate to come on.

In the other place my colleague Mr Peacock went into considerable detail to outline precisely which provisions of the protocol would impair the conduct of the proper affairs of the allied commanders in the Gulf. He outlined some of the following: the articles contain a blanket prohibition against the right of reprisal; the protocol forbids the use of weaponry likely to cause, as I mentioned before, superfluous injury or unnecessary suffering; it prohibits attacks on dams, dykes and nuclear power stations; it prescribes the distinction between military and civilian objectives; it prohibits attacks that may cause incidental loss of civilian life-and we have already seen examples of that-it obliges nations to ensure that legal advisers are available at all times to advise military commanders on their obligations under the protocol-as I said, something that perhaps would have been worthy of Gilbert and Sullivan.

The prohibition against reprisals is also particularly problematic. Let us take the current position of Israel. Under the protocol, if one party to a conflict-in this case Iraq-causes a fundamental breach of the protocol, the other party-Israel-is still bound to conduct its affairs in conformity with the provisions of the protocol. Are we then to assume that Israel's right to self-defence, as recognised in article 51 of the United Nations Charter is to be withheld? Israel's restraint is laudable and has been widely recognised but its right to self-defence is also recognised and ought to be preserved. Are we to believe that any measured and proportional response in which Israel must be forced to engage is to be prohibited by the protocol and that that act of self- defence would make the Israelis war criminals?

One should be aware that the mere fact of reprisal has considerable effectiveness in deterring aggression and preventing or bringing to an end breaches of international law. The Cold War victory of the West over the Warsaw Pact was founded on the strength of deterrence, as was borne out by the fear of reprisals. The appeasers in the Australian Democrats and their associates on the Left should consider the importance of the preservation of the right of reprisals and understand that it has led to multilateral nuclear disarmament.

It was not pacifism, weakness or unilateral measures that brought to an end the Cold War; it was deterrence, resolve and the preservation of international rights, such as the right of reprisal, which would be outlawed. To this point in the Gulf war, we have seen the United States preserve its right to respond in kind should Iraq resort to biological or chemical warfare. This has surely influenced Hussein's decision against such warfare up to this time. That is why last night I raised the question of controversy over the question of the bombardment of the shelter in Baghdad, the death of civilians, the contention that it was a military installation, the contention by others that it could have been either jointly a military installation used by civilians or, indeed, that it could have been a ploy by Saddam Hussein to give him some justification to begin to use chemical warfare.

The problem with the sort of high-tech war that we are now engaged in, where we are amazed continually about the capacity to have accurate targeting and the stated intention of the allies to use targeted bombardment for military purposes only, is that it has led us to expect that the technology will always make it accurate. The Opposition has chosen to oppose the ratification of protocol I for the simple reason that it believes that there is adequate provision within international law as it is to act as both a punishment and a deterrent to people acting in a way which civilised people believe is not acceptable. We oppose it because we believe that the protocol places an unfair and burdensome restriction upon the ability of our own armed forces to conduct war to their best endeavours, bearing in mind that our point of view and the bipartisan point of view is that Australia is presently engaged in this war because we want a just peace.

The Archbishop of Canterbury elect, at the service which opened this Parliament last week, said he had to draw issue with those who wanted peace at any price. He said that we could only have peace with justice. Therefore, when we are looking at the way in which we act and prosecute that war, we want just peace and not peace at any price. The protesters who simply quote slogans and say, `Stop it, and it will all go away.' do not realise that if one person's aggression is such that reasonableness, argument, logic and discussion will not bring about a just peace, then we must pursue the resolutions of the United Nations and pursue that just peace.

It is with a good deal of care, concern, discernment, logic and compassion that the Opposition is opposing the implementation and the passing of this Bill, because we believe that it is not in the interests of the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to note that these protocols have been under debate for some years and that the Government has, so far, twice failed to ratify the signing of the protocols, despite having promised to do so five years ago. I am glad that we are at last discussing them, although very sadly we are doing so under the cloud of war. It is ironic that Australia originally signed the protocols at the time of the Fraser Government, so I am curious to know why the Liberal Party has chosen to change its position and what pressure it has come under to do so. Has the pressure come from the military in Australia? That is doubtful, despite the campaign of retired Brigadier P. J. Greville against the protocols.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans announced that Australia would ratify the protocols some five years ago, as I have indicated, and it is obvious that the Government's failure to do this is due to a lack of public interest in the issue and opposition from the Liberal Party. This opposition has been well aired by a number of speakers in the debate on the subject in the other place and it makes pathetic reading in Hansard. The honourable member for Kooyong, Mr Peacock, partly justified his decision to vote against ratification by referring to opposition to the protocols by what he called our major ally, the United States. We have just heard that reiterated by Senator Bishop.

Brigadier Greville provided the text in an article in the Pacific Defence Reporter in October 1988 when he quoted the then US President, Ronald Reagan, as believing that protocol I was fundamentally and irreconcilably flawed while his joint Chiefs of Staff concluded:
A number of the provisions of the protocol are militarily unacceptable.

That is exactly what has been trotted out from the Opposition both in the House of Representatives and in the Senate last night and this afternoon-it is unacceptable militarily to the United States command. Obviously, under a coalition government, our foreign policy would be determined exclusively in Washington instead of only mostly, as is the case with the Hawke Government, and exclusively with military criteria applied as designated by the Pentagon.

This is a cause for some concern, but it is distressing to see that the coalition now chooses to oppose these protocols by looking over its shoulder at what the Americans think. I wonder who briefed Mr Peacock on all those clauses to the protocols that he objected to when he spoke on the subject on 12 February. Having just heard Senator Bishop's contribution referring to our allies' views on the military unacceptability of the protocols, the source of that pressure is pretty obvious.

Nor do I have any doubt that the United States takes no notice what Australia thinks before making its decision. It takes no notice whatsoever of Australia's views and this has been demonstrated time and time again. I find it humiliating that the coalition behaves in this way as though Australian concerns are taken into account by the United States military. They dictate and the Australians obviously follow suit with very little critical analysis.

It is worth noting that while the United States has not signed the protocols, 11 North Atlantic Treaty Organisation nations have signed them, including the United Kingdom and France, while others, including Canada and the Federal Republic of Germany, have ratified the protocols. I do not propose to go into the details of the protocols as much has already been said on the subject in here and in the other place for those interested enough to read about what is on the agenda but just from listening to Senator Bishop a moment ago, I cannot help say that all the prohibitions that she listed would be commendable rather than something to be afraid of.

Principally, I want to point out that the signing of these protocols is a matter of setting standards. It is no good pointing the finger at the other countries and saying that they have signed the protocols but then ignore them. Unfortunately, that is the case. As earlier speakers in the House of Representatives pointed out, war is not a nice matter, although they went on to add that it was sometimes a regrettable necessity. One of the problems of embarking on a war is that standards go out the window, they just go by the board-and that is across the board as well. Atrocities are committed on all sides in a conflict. A look at any military conflict will prove that point.

We embark on a war with noble aims, but in this century alone we can recall how the Boer War ended up with concentration camps; the First World War saw the use of gas; the Second World War ended up with gas chambers, obliteration bombing and nuclear weapons. In each major war this century, civilians have become increasingly the primary casualties. In the Gulf we are seeing the same phenomenon with the deaths of civilians now referred to as collateral damage, in sanitised Pentagon jargon-highly offensive. These deaths are always accidental, of course, caused by the evil tactics of the other side in hiding military facilities under a civilian bunker to score a propaganda victory, for example. Fortunately, the Sunday Times has now revealed that the Pentagon has conceded that the bombing of the Baghdad shelter was a mistake, but it would be good to get a public admission which our own Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) could then concede after his initial comment, taking the official day-after-Pentagon line. It is highly embarrassing that our Government just takes the Pentagon line and then sometimes gets caught out as in this case.

Another justification for opposing ratification of these protocols concerns the fact that they involve wars of liberation. Most of the 30 or so wars going on in the world today are civil wars or wars of liberation. I suspect that many future wars will be along the same lines as the world tries to sort out its longstanding differences, many of them a hangover from the colonial era. This convention and its protocols are important, precisely because of this. I realise that they will be particularly hard to enforce because so many of these conflicts are wars of liberation, but that is where I come back to the setting of standards and that is really what most United Nations conventions are all about.

We worry a lot about victims in crime, but in war we seem to be more concerned about the boys and girls in the front line. I fail to understand why we call them that so often. Senator Bishop referred to them in that way when she was speaking yesterday. Perhaps it is because we are so conditioned to ageing politicians sending our young men and women off to fight their wars-the fruit of our youth being sent away to kill or be killed. In the Gulf war we seem almost totally fixated by the high-tech weapons as the media has been carefully sanitised to avoid the mistakes of the Vietnam war by not showing too many bodies. What bodies there are have mostly been on the Iraqi side, both military and civilian.

As I observed earlier, civilians are increasingly the victims in modern war. In the Second World War, there were 50 per cent of casualties in the civilian area; in Korea, 80 per cent; and in Vietnam, 90 per cent. The report of the International Red Cross Society on casualties in conflict, which was released in Melbourne last month, reiterated this latest figure of 90 per cent of casualties being civilians and pointed out that five million people were killed in armed conflicts in 1988-89 and at least 32 million wounded. Of course, this is often a cost of the war that people who take the country to war do not want to acknowledge. It is not only the bodies but the leftovers-the new generation of veterans-that we are creating when we have not dealt with the last ones yet.

The coalition speakers tell us that war is nasty and it is unfortunate that civilians get hurt. But we have to be sensible and practical and we must not do anything to hinder the armed services. I noted with interest Senator Faulkner's comments yesterday on the bombing of the civilians in the Baghdad bunker, and agree with him that surely the United States would not have deliberately bombed civilians. For example, if the United States were to ratify these protocols and keep to them absolutely, this war crime would not have been committed. I do not blame only the United States carelessness for this gross error, Australia is also responsible and we have to look at the role of Pine Gap. It is quite possible that the targeting information, which was obviously erroneous for that bombing raid to occur, was transmitted through Pine Gap. Pine Gap is one of the chief sources of satellite pictures and military interception of messages. The fact is that war and atrocities go together.

Iraq, of course, is also guilty of war crimes many times over in using chemical weapons against its own people, in its aggression against Kuwait, and in deliberately targeting Israeli civilians. If countries such as the United States and Australia were to ratify these protocols, we could bring a great deal more weight to bear on countries ignoring them-such as Iraq-rather than pussyfooting around and saying that if Libya and Syria signed them, then they are meaningless and we should not take any notice of them either. That is just not a logical position.

There is no justification for ignoring the attempts to set some ground rules for war. I abhor all war and feel very saddened that so many countries are now engaged in senseless slaughter in the Gulf, which will do nothing to solve the political problems and bids for power in the Middle East. The slaughter and its aftermath of increased enmity towards the West will add to those problems enormously.

War always brings certain casualties: truth, of course, is one of the first; human lives lost; ongoing suffering of millions of people whose lives are shattered, and of their families; environmental damage; and wastage of vast resources in both human and financial terms. We must not overlook the fact that war is dehumanising and absolutely brutalising because atrocities are always committed by all sides. It is nothing short of government ordered and organised killing; that is, murder on a massive scale. We must stop this killing not only because it will not fix the problems of the Middle East, but also because it is totally unacceptable on moral grounds.

I must reiterate that the anti-war position taken by so many ordinary citizens around the world is not one of appeasement, as Senator Bishop so recently claimed, but a position which challenges the blinkered view that the only option is war. Of course Saddam Hussein must be stopped, but not by war; not by the desecration of Kuwait; not by the killing of innocent Iraqis; and not by offering as victims the hundreds of thousands of young service men and women who are increasingly being called `the cash register coalition'-that is, cobbled together by paying off this country and that to get them on side.

As has been said before, sanctions would have worked given time. Negotiations should now be given a chance to be worked out, especially with the latest Soviet initiative. The Government of Australia must be criticised for its hypocrisy in championing Amnesty International's campaign to abolish the death penalty. I totally support that campaign. How the Prime Minister can square support for that campaign to abolish the death penalty, and yet send young Australians off to war to kill or be killed is hard to understand.

The Opposition has obviously, for some mysterious reason, changed its position and taken up an oppositionist stand to these protocols, which was not its position some years ago. Perhaps it comes down to Senator MacGibbon's expressed concern that such guidelines might prevent the use of weapons of mass destruction-chemical, biological and nuclear. He actually mentioned all these weapons yesterday. The Liberal-National coalition does not want that sort of constraint placed upon the military, they obviously want to keep those options open. That is indeed a shameful admission. I find it really hard to cope with people who come in here and argue that they want the options to use chemical, biological and nuclear weapons left open for this country at some future time. Yet, that is exactly what the Opposition senators and members in the House of Representatives are arguing by their opposition to these protocols.

I ask Senator Bishop: what sort of just peace is there she seems to think the cash register coalition is working and fighting for peace in the Gulf-when women and children are going to be the prime victims? The under 15-year-old age group makes up half of the Iraqi population. Those people are not responsible for their leaders' dictatorial, aggressive behaviours. Why should they be made to pay? This is not the way for brave people to seek peace with justice, it is the cowards way to obliterate the state of Iraq. The United States' objective is to make Iraq cease to function as a nation state and not to liberate Kuwait. That is absolute nonsense. It might have been an earlier stated objective but, behind that stated objective, there has been another agenda which has been very clear from the outset.

Why is the United States not prepared to listen to the initiatives which Iraq made last Friday, although there were conditions attached? They were dismissed out of hand by our Government as well. There was no attempt, on the part of this Government, to convince the United States that enough slaughter had taken place; that the lesson had surely been learned. If Iraq were prepared to withdraw from Kuwait, that should have been heeded.

The Americans are determined to go into a ground war-one can feel it when one watches the television reports; one can sense it from the way the military advisers are saying their readiness is now complete-and the Soviet initiative for peace is a very great interference with their timetable. It is irritating to them in the extreme.

I reject Senator Bishop's allegation that the peace movement around the world is for peace at any price. We are not appeasers; we are not for peace at any price. We agree that Saddam Hussein must be stopped, but not by the senseless slaughter which is going to create problems in the future that we can hardly even imagine. As I mentioned before, the environmental costs alone would be enough to call for the cessation of this slaughter right now, because it is going to produce enormous consequences to the global atmosphere, to say nothing of the water supplies in the Gulf and the desert ecology.

There are so many grounds for calling a cease-fire right now and yet we have people in here saying, `We do not want to limit the military in any way at all. We want to allow the military to do what it will, and to do what it thinks it must in the time of war'. I find that morally unacceptable. Although I very clearly disagree with the Government's endorsement of the United States-led war in the Gulf, I do support its decision finally to ratify these protocols.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking this afternoon in replacement of Senator Spindler who was going to take our part in the debate at this point. I personally support the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill 1990, Senator Spindler personally supports the Bill and the Australian Democrats as a Party support the Bill for the reasons which have been outlined by the previous speaker, Senator Vallentine. The Bill, as other senators have said, seeks to provide increased protection for civilians and prisoners of war during international armed conflicts by authorising the Government to ratify protocol I. As the explanatory memorandum and other notes indicate, protocol II would also be ratified but does not require legislative change.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth pointing out at this stage, as others have done, that we are debating this piece of legislation at a very interesting time. Senator Vallentine pointed out that it has been around for quite a long time and that successive governments have been rather slow in moving to pass legislation which would allow this ratification.

It comes at a time when the Australian Government, together with other governments under a multinational force-not, as the Secretary-General of the United Nations has repeatedly pointed out, a United Nations force but a multinational force-is engaged in an act of war in the Middle East. Several speakers, particularly from the Opposition, have been at some pains to criticise the position which the Democrats and Senator Vallentine have taken in relation to this war, so I think it is appropriate for me also to reiterate the position that we are not, as Senator Vallentine said, appeasers. We are not for a resolution of that conflict-which has been initiated by Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait-without justice.

Where we take issue with both the Government and the Opposition is that we believe it would be more appropriate to seek a resolution to that conflict-as United Nation resolutions 660 and 661 anticipated-through the longer use of effective sanctions. All the evidence, including Central Intelligence Agency reports, was that sanctions were indeed working. That by no means is appeasement. That by no means is seeking a resolution of this conflict without justice. It is indeed seeking a resolution of the conflict with justice but by different means.

I must also reflect-because we are dealing here with the protection of civilians in times of war-on the question which was asked at Question Time today by Senator Bishop when she asked the President a question in relation to the demonstrators outside this Parliament. She linked her clear abhorrence of the behaviour of those who would protest this war with a question in relation to the preparation of the cells under Parliament House. I cannot help but, in my mind, link her vociferous objection to this legislation which is now before us with the attitude which she displayed in asking that question, because I find in that question and the line which one draws through that question an incredible sense of both cruelty and intolerance toward those who hold a different view with respect to this war.

If that is the attitude which is guiding the Opposition-I hope it is not; I hope it is confined to only a few members-in relation to the ratification of this Geneva Convention, then I am indeed deeply disturbed. As I indicated earlier, protocol II provides similar protection, that is, to civilians and prisoners of war in situations of noninternational armed conflict-that is, in armed conflicts in which people are fighting against colonial domination and alien occupation and against racist regimes in the exercise of their right of self-determination. I think that is particularly appropriate at this time when around the world we have many of those conflicts going on-in Central America and in many nations in Africa. We have seen the horrific suppression of tribes in the case of some African nations where a different tribe has achieved a position of dominance, and the right of self-determination and the right to human dignity have been very much impinged upon.

As I have indicated, protocol II does not require legislative authority for the Government's ratification, but will be ratified when the Government receives legislative authority to ratify protocol I. Examples of the specific protections extended by protocol I are as follows: the protection of civilian medical units; prohibition on starving civilian populations-that is, a prohibition on attacking, destroying or removing food unless it is used by military forces; and precautionary measures to remove civilians from the vicinity of military objectives. Prohibitions and obligations are qualified in terms of feasibility during armed conflict; that is, care is taken to ensure that the safety of military personnel is not endangered. I would have thought that that really is the point that has been ignored by the Opposition when seeking rather wider and less restrained powers for the military in arguing against these protocols.

This answers the claim by the Opposition that this Bill endangers the lives and safety of Australian defence forces. In fact, the Opposition's claim is a slur on Australian military personnel, who would, I am sure, reject any suggestion that they would be prepared to kill women and children to enhance their own military objectives or even their own safety. It is regrettable that the Opposition has chosen to oppose this legislation, which seeks to extend humanitarian principles as far as that is possible in military conflicts.

The extension made by protocol II is welcome. As Dr Catley documented during the debate in the other place, there have been 160 wars since the 1949 Geneva Convention, and many were in the category of internal conflict, often in pursuit of the United Nations declaration guaranteeing the self-determination of peoples. As I have indicated, one can find right at this instant many examples of those sorts of conflicts in which there are absolutely horrific impacts on the civilian population.

The Australian Democrats reject war as a means of conflict resolution, but if it becomes unavoidable then we must continue to develop legal protection for innocent victims. I would interpolate here, returning again to the example of the Middle East war at this time, that we do not believe that, at the time when the multinational force, composed principally of American forces-not a United Nations force-chose war as the means to resolve the Middle East conflict, we had reached that stage at which war was unavoidable. We believe a much more extensive period of sanctions would have been entirely appropriate. It may well be that eventually we would have reached a situation in which war became unavoidable. It may have become unavoidable because, indeed, Saddam Hussein may have begun military conflict by invading Saudi Arabia or attacking the defensive forces which were aligned against him for the purposes of imposing the sanctions. It may have become unavoidable. So we are not, as Democrats, in that sense totally opposed to the use of war under all circumstances. But under these circumstances we believe that we had not reached that stage-not by a very long chalk indeed. So it is in that context that Senator Knowles's definition of article 48 as impractical deserves considerable contempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the last one who should talk about contempt. You really are the last gasp.
—Article 48 says:

SPEECH.PARA: In order to ensure respect for and protection of the civilian population and civilian objects, the Parties to the conflict shall at all times distinguish between the civilian population and combatants and between civilian objects and military objectives and accordingly shall direct their operations only against military objectives.

It is clearly the central provision of this legislation. I reiterate, despite Senator Knowles's interjection, that I find that concern over article 48, expressed by Senator Knowles, quite contemptible.

However, there were other provisions which the Opposition felt it could not support. In effect, the Opposition's position means that it is in favour of the use of weaponry that may cause `superfluous injury or unnecessary suffering'-article 35 (2). The Opposition is in favour of `attacks against dams, dykes and nuclear electrical generating stations'. I interpolate that an attack on a nuclear power station potentially may release far more radiation than would be released in many deliberate nuclear explosions. The amount of radioactivity inside a 1,000 megawatt power station, for example, is such that an attack, with the release of radioactive material in its core, would be absolutely devastating.

I remind the Senate that in the case of the Chernobyl fire the total inventory of radioactive material was by no means completely released. So there are long term consequences of deliberate attacks on nuclear installations not only for the civilian population present at the time of the conflict but for the civilian population many, many decades-perhaps 100 years-afterwards.

In 1977 the sixth report on environmental pollution-the so-called Flowers report-in Great Britain, which looked at the consequences of an extension of nuclear power generation, was released. That report contained a line that had nuclear power been in use at the time of the Second World War, many parts of central Europe would still be uninhabitable as a consequence of pollution by caesium-137. As I recall, that report was released some 31 years after the end of the war. So the Opposition is opposed to article 56 (1) which seeks to prevent attacks on dams, dykes and nuclear electrical generating stations, even if `they are not direct military targets'.

The Opposition is not in favour of provisions which prescribe the measures by which `combatants shall distinguish themselves from the civilian population'- article 44 (3). The Opposition is not supporting the `distinction between military and civilian objectives'-articles 48, 49 (1) and 49 (2). The Opposition is prepared to countenance attacks which may cause `incidental loss of civilian life'-articles 52 and 57. The Opposition is not prepared to concede that nations should be obliged to have legal advisers available `at all times' to advise military commanders of their obligations under the protocol. In other words, the Opposition really is favouring a free-for-all on civilians in the event of war, without adequate protection.

In adopting these stances the Opposition has confirmed that its views of armed conflict date back to the Middle Ages. Senator MacGibbon was at pains to point this out during the debate yesterday. Of course, if one reflects over the full gamut of human history and goes back to pre-human history, one finds that Homo sapiens descended from a line of gregarious primates who from time immemorial have lived in small groups defending territory by means of armed conflict.

What the Democrats are saying is that we would hope that after some six million years of human evolution, and at a time when, through our ingenuity-but certainly not through our intelligence-we have devised the most horrific means of inflicting harm and damage on our fellow human beings, we had achieved a degree of intelligence which would cause us to seek means of conflict resolution other than the use of those horrific weapons of war.

As Senator MacGibbon almost proudly pointed out in the debate yesterday, war has been part of human history, in his view, for 500 years. I would remind him that it has been part of human history for perhaps six million years. He seemed to be indicating that it is an inevitable part of the human future. I simply point out that if it is going to be part of the human future, there will be no future for humans. We must, as a matter of urgent priority, seek other means to resolve these international and intertribal conflicts. We believe that the Government deserves credit for this Bill. In conclusion, the Democrats will be supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Government's action to ratify the protocols additional to the Geneva Convention which aim to protect the innocent victims of international armed conflicts. I believe that it is important to support the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill during a time when innocent civilians, including women and children, are being killed and injured in the Gulf war. While supporting Australia's part in this war, I am gravely disturbed by reports that civilian targets have been hit. Civilians must be spared in time of war.

SPEECH.PARA: Protocol I updates and strengthens the `laws of Geneva' that protect the wounded, sick, shipwrecked, prisoners of war and civilians caught up in war. The basic principle of international humanitarian law is that warfare is not unlimited. Countries do not have an open policy on the killing of civilians. This means that in military operations, combatants must always distinguish between the civilian population and the enemy. To spell it out, indiscriminate attacks are those which are not directed at specific military objectives; which employ a method or means of combat which cannot be directed at a specific military objective; which employ a method or means of combat, the effects of which cannot be limited as required by the protocols; and which strike military objectives or civilian objectives without distinction.

If Saddam Hussein, as has been claimed and reported in the popular press, is deliberately placing civilians close to military targets, he is acting contrary to the Hague Convention and there are no words to describe what action should be taken against him. I think at this stage it is worth noting two press reports which contain accusations that have been made against Saddam Hussein in relation to putting civilians within bomb shelters. One headline states, `US bombs hit crowded shelter'. Another states, `US admits bunker strike a mistake'.

I am not sure whether one can take note of all press reports or whether one can apportion blame in relation to the striking of that shelter, but I believe that, in the long term, with Australia supporting these protocols, it is important that the whole affair be investigated and those responsible brought to justice when the war in the Gulf is resolved. Unfortunately the Butcher of Bagdad does not play by the rules or support the Geneva Convention. We are talking about a man who deployed innocent civilians to military targets and who paraded, before the media, prisoners of war who had been the victims of merciless torture, both mental and physical. Other tyrants and warmongers may be deterred from acts of aggression against civilians by the knowledge that the very consequences of their actions would received massive condemnation from the United Nations and from the world community generally.

When studying the history of war throughout the generations, one finds that there has always been massive destruction of innocent civilians. I cite the recent Vietnam war in which this country was involved. Although a minor war when compared with the major conflicts of World War I and World War II, thousands of civilians were killed and more suffered from the effects of bombing and the use of Agent Orange. So too in Cambodia where millions, including an entire generation of illiterate Cambodians, were killed in order to subjugate the rest of the population. Africa has been a bloodbath for decades with documented atrocities in Mozambique and Angola. The action of Russia in Afghanistan was another useless minor war. And there are many more.

Then we have Saddam Hussein's actions against the Kurds where, because of the use of chemical warfare, people sustained horrific burns and disfigurement, with many dying. Our friends, the Americans, had their proxy war in Central America. That was certainly a low intensity situation but nevertheless they encouraged civil war in an effort to get rid of the Sandinista Government. There is no doubt that war, whether major or minor, will continue. Therefore, it is imperative that all sides of the Senate support the ratification of protocol I which at the same time ratifies protocol II.

The situation in Iraq where innocent victims of war-for instance, women and children caught in Kuwait through no fault of their own-were used as hostages for the military should not be allowed to happen again. That these people were eventually allowed to go free is a win for diplomacy and confirms that there is an urgent need for the ratification of the protocols so that any similar move in the future may be attacked with more armoury at the ready. Although we cannot hope that all countries will behave in what we consider to be a civilised or humane manner towards civilians during wartime, with measures such as the protocols set in place we can show what nations will accept and what they will not tolerate during acts of war.

Consideration should be given to the additional fact that the United Nations is also prepared to take action to stamp out acts of aggression against civilians and innocents. The protocols make it extremely difficult for countries that engage in crimes contrary to the Geneva Convention to escape dealing with other nations in relation to those crimes and they will face the consequences. With the ratification of the protocols, crime against innocents, looting, rape, deprivation of liberty, barbaric medical experiments, suicide missions and many other activities should be discouraged by this international agreement.

When this Bill was put forward by the Government on 2 March 1989, it was withdrawn because it was not supported by all sides of the Senate. It is to be hoped that on this occasion-and it appears from the debate that this is the case-the protocols and Australia's support of them will at last be supported by the entire Senate. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill is one for which a great deal of groundwork has been done, not only within Australia but also overseas. I do not intend to go over all the ground canvassed by other speakers in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly the intentions of this Bill and of the protocols are laudable. However, a number of concerns have been expressed not only during this debate but also over quite a period about the actual application of certain articles of the protocols. These concerns have been canvassed in this debate. They were also canvassed when this legislation was first mooted some time ago. At that stage it was the desire of the Government-a quite legitimate desire-that there be a bipartisan approach to these questions because of their importance. That bipartisan approach has not been able to be achieved because the Opposition and quite a number of other people see a number of problems in the application of certain provisions.

It is important that we get it right because the legislation has come before us precisely because we are implementing into domestic law certain of, I suppose, the burdens that are placed on this country because of its ratification. It is therefore essential that we know precisely, and are clear on, what the articles mean.

It is of interest to note that the Government itself has proposed certain declarations in order to clarify interpretation in areas where there are some elements of doubt. I have a copy of the proposed Australian declarations of understanding on accession to the first additional protocol to the 1949 Geneva Convention. It is clear from that proposed Australian declaration that there are elements of doubt in the first additional protocol at all events, even in the mind of the Government.

The question that I am asking-and no doubt the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) will be able to give a response when he replies to the second reading debate or, indeed, in the Committee of the Whole-is why the Government decided that it would propose a declaration of understanding on accession to the first additional protocol rather than a reservation. The appropriateness of having a declaration as distinct from a reservation is rather unclear. It seems to me, though I am subject to correction, that a reservation would have a more binding effect legally than a declaration.

As honourable senators will realise, this matter has been canvassed on a number of occasions, including in the chapter entitled `Australian Treaty Practice and Procedure' in the second edition of Ryan's International Law in Australia, where the question of reservations and the definitions of a reservation are dealt with. On page 68 of that work it is stated:
The distinction between reservations and other devices such as declarations, observations and interpretive statements is a fine one. Although the test is expressed in Art. 2 (2) (d)--
of the Vienna Convention-

to be whether or not the device purports to exclude or modify the legal effect of certain provisions of the treaty, the Convention offers little guidance on how to make an objective determination to that end. Indeed, given the decentralised decision-making process of the international legal system, it may be open to question whether such a determination is possible at all. It has been suggested, for instance, that an interpretive statement is distinguishable from a reservation since it is simply a mechanism by which a State seeks ``to interpret the treaty or part of it in a particular manner thereby indicates its perception of its obligations under the treaty''. Yet if it has the effect, nevertheless, of limiting or modifying the terms of a treaty a statement of this sort may equally be regarded as a reservation within the meaning of the Convention. In the final event, the legal significance of devices other than reservations will depend upon the form and content of the device, the time at which it was made, and the reaction of other parties to it.

That may indeed be the response that the Minister was going to give, but it seems to me to beg the question as to why a reservation was not made. If there are obligations on Australia and indeed, through this legislation, on Australian citizens-and that is the point-we had better be sure that the use of the declarations device gives a proper legal protection, and a legal protection at least as great as that which would be given by reservations.

The Government has gone some of the way in its proposed declarations, but I still feel disappointed that it and the Opposition have not been able to come to a common view about this question. I do not know what future governments may do, and I would be interested to know what the Minister's views are about that. If, for example, a future Government takes the view that the declarations have not covered those possible problems arising from the additional protocol that have been expressed in the debate thus far, what will happen? Will there be an opportunity for that future government to take a different viewpoint and to change the legal position of Australia vis-a-vis the additional protocol? These are questions that are probably more appropriate to be dealt with in the Committee of the Whole, and it is my intention to vote for the second reading of this Bill so as to have the matter go to the Committee of the Whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a most important measure, the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill 1990, which will if passed enable the Australian Government on behalf of the Australian people to ratify protocol I additional to the Geneva Conventions. Basically, the protocol has evolved through considerations over many decades of how civilian populations in particular might be distinguished from combatants and how military objectives might be distinguished from civilian objects so that we can try to modify the horrendous carnage and effects of engaging in warfare in such a way that some protection might be offered particularly to the civilian populations in those areas where war is being waged.

SPEECH.PARA: The protocol is designed specifically to apply humanitarian principles to those military conflicts which are waged and have been waged in the past in ways which have quite clearly targeted civilian populations as a measure of terrorising those populations and weakening the will of the government concerned to continue its waging of war given what is happening to the civilian population, with which it is, I guess, primarily concerned.

The exacting work undertaken by many bodies, particularly by the International Committee of the Red Cross, has led to this protocol. Senator Harradine quite rightly spoke of the desirability of having bipartisan support for this measure. It is regrettable that the bipartisan support which might reasonably have been anticipated from the Opposition parties has not been forthcoming, but this measure will pass because of the support of the Australian Democrats and Senator Vallentine through all stages and Senator Harradine at the second reading stage.

As I say, that bipartisan support was reasonably to be expected because Mr Andrew Peacock, the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, signed the protocol on behalf of Australia in December 1978, thereby signifying that Australia would respect the provisions of the treaty and would certainly not do anything which would be contrary to their spirit while considering the question of ratification.

We know that Senator Durack wrote to the Secretary-General of the Australian Red Cross Society in March 1988 indicating that the coalition had always had a strong commitment to the ideals of the Geneva Conventions and would be supporting the Bill when it was introduced. There was an expectation of bipartisan support, and it is unfortunate that we as a nation cannot give our wholehearted endorsement to this legislation.

It is important legislation and very apt at this time when we are engaged in the multinational force in the Gulf and where the question of the waging of warfare and the way in which it affects the civilian population is constantly before us as a matter of grave concern. It is important to mention that the protocol attempts to make it clear that while the civilian population and individual civilians enjoy general protection against dangers arising from military operations, it faces the reality of the waging of military operations. It deals with the unfortunate fact that it may be necessary in the attaining of military objectives to wage the conflict in a way that will affect civilian populations. But in that case there has to be a real assessment of the proportionality of the impact on civilian populations to the achieving of the military objective. A very stringent assessment of that balance has to be undertaken, but obviously in warfare great care has to be taken to make sure that the loss of civilian life, injury to civilians, and damage to civilian objects are not excessive in relation to that concrete and direct military advantage which is anticipated. But the real object of this protocol is to ensure respect for and protection of the civilian population and civilian objects. I am quite sure that that objective would commend itself to all members of the chamber.

Several matters have been raised during the debate which perhaps could be dealt with now rather than in the committee stage. One relates to the question raised by Senator Bishop who referred to nuclear power stations in Iraq having been bombed. She asserts that in the light of article 56 of the protocol this would be banned. It is quite clear, according to information available to me, that the nuclear facilities attacked in Iraq were not nuclear electrical generating facilities and therefore did not attract the protection of the protocol.

TALK.START.PARA: —They did not have a radioactive core either. They were still under construction.

—I am advised by Senator Coulter that, to his knowledge, they did not even have a radioactive core and therefore would not have released radioactive force, which is the primary reason for their being afforded protection under article 56. I do not believe that that matter raised by Senator Bishop needs to be further discussed.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon claimed that the Irish Republican Army terrorists responsible for the recent attack on No. 10 Downing Street would, if captured, be able to claim prisoner of war (POW) status under the terms of the protocol. That is not correct. Terrorist organisations are not able to claim the protection of the protocol, such as being regarded as combatants and acquiring POW status if captured. Article 1(4) limits the types of armed conflicts to which the protocol applies. A terrorist organisation is not a party to a conflict coming within the definition in article 1(4). It is clear that terrorist organisations cannot claim the protection of the protocol. The captured members are not POWs, but would be dealt with under the ordinary criminal law for their activities. The whole purpose of the protocol is to outlaw terrorist acts and never to condone them. I believe that Senator MacGibbon's misgivings in that respect are unfounded.

Perhaps the most curious matter that needs to be dealt with is the confusion by Senator Bishop and perhaps by other members of the Opposition between reprisals and retaliation and acting in self-defence once attacked. Senator Bishop seemed to suggest that, for example, it would be impossible for a country which had been subjected to attack on its civilian populations to launch a counterattack, an action in self-defence-some retaliatory measure. That is not true. Reprisals are of a different character altogether. Reprisals are those actions which would normally be outlawed by humanitarian international law and by this particular protocol in that they involve the deliberate use of military force against, for example, civilian populations, not to achieve a military objective, but to punish and to cause such suffering that the government waging war might consider desisting from itself engaging in actions which breach the rules of humanitarian international law.

I do not believe that in accepting the protocol in relation to reprisals this Bill in any way will strip Australia of a properly exercised right of self-defence. It merely prevents that right of self-defence from encompassing the deliberate targeting of civilian populations, which simply adds to the horrors of warfare and is such that it should be outlawed. Surely we have reached a stage in trying to curb the horrors of war where every possibility of limiting the impact on civilian populations should be undertaken.

A question that has constantly exercised senators' minds has been the question of interoperability-that is, whether if Australia were to ratify this protocol our acting in conjunction with our allies or the members of coalitions of armed forces put together would make those operations difficult or even impossible and frustrate the complex cooperative and collaborative effort that would need to be undertaken.

Current evidence in the Middle East is that the United States of America is operating quite effectively in a multinational force, the majority of whose members are either parties to or have signed the protocols. Indeed, the evidence strongly suggests that the operations of the task force are being carried out in compliance with the rules of the protocols; that is, in attempting to target military objectives only. It would appear that in the current conflict, I am advised, of the 29 members of the multinational task force 21 are parties to Protocol I; 19 are parties Protocol II; and the remaining seven have signed both protocols but are not parties.

One can see that in the multinational force there is a variety and combination of nations, some of whom have signed, some of whom have not signed, many of whom are parties to the protocol and some of whom are not parties to it. So far as I have been advised, that has not led to any difficulty in the operational compatability as objectives are sought to be achieved and as the various parties are brought into cooperative arrangements to achieve the objectives of the multinational force.

I believe that they are the main points which, possibly, have caused misgivings and concerns in the minds of some members of the Opposition and have led them to consider that they cannot support the second reading of this particular Bill. But I would ask them to reconsider their change of heart-which it appears to be-in relation to support of the ratifying of this particular protocol which would be enabled by the passage of this legislation. I commend the Bill to the Senate in order to achieve that objective.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to the second reading debate I neglected to respond to Senator Harradine's question, and perhaps it might be useful to do so now. The honourable senator asked for the relevant difference between reservations and declarations in relation to this particular protocol, and why the Government had chosen to go the declaration route rather than make reservations. By the way, the proposed declarations have been circulated to the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and the two Independents, although they have not yet been to the Executive Council. That is why, although the Government anticipates that they will be in that form, they have not been incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Both declarations and reservations are binding in the sense that a declaration is a public, interpretative statement manifesting a government's understanding of the provisional term-in this case, of the protocol. It does not have to be accepted by other parties and does not purport to resile from a treaty obligation as does a reservation. I think that is the key: that a reservation would indicate that the Government purports to resile from an obligation which would otherwise be imposed on it by the international instrument concerned.

Senator Harradine asked some further questions concerning reservations or declarations. A future government cannot make a new reservation or declaration. It can withdraw a reservation or declaration at a later stage, but it cannot enter into further reservations or declarations in relation to the international instrument concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would stop it from entering into a reservation or declaration?

—I am advised that this is the effect of international law. It has to be done at the time of ratification in a formal sense, and that is the statement of the nation state at the time. It can withdraw a reservation or declaration but, apparently, it cannot add new reservations or declarations. I presume it is under some international instrument itself that that is the case.

—Am I to understand then that the Government sees its proposed declarations as being the key area for interpretation of the Bill when it comes to consideration by international or domestic courts in respect of the provisions of the additional protocol? In other words, it seems to me that the Bill places obligations on individual Australian citizens. Am I to understand that the Government considers that its proposed declarations will be interpreted by those enforcing the provisions of the protocol as having the standing in law for the protection of those individuals?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as declarations are concerned, I am advised that the effect in international law is that there is an indication of Australia, as a nation state, having a particular understanding of the provisions of the protocol, but that would not be a binding understanding as far as the international community was concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised that section 15ab of the Acts Interpretation Act allows a domestic court to take any material in forming part of the Act which is capable of assisting the meaning of the proviso into account. As Senator Harradine knows, the court is not obliged to take that into account, but has a discretion to do so. I am advised that that is possible as far as a domestic court is concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was hoping for a little better clarification than that. I know what is in the Acts Interpretation Act. It does not really help to say that the courts can have regard to what is contained in the declaration. They may indeed choose to have regard to what is contained in the protocol itself and make their own interpretation of that, given the debate that has taken place in the meetings leading up to the preparation of this protocol. In any international convention the courts would normally have regard to the travaux preparatoire and to the reservations that a particular state may make. That is what I am trying to get at.

SPEECH.PARA: Would these declarations have the same force in domestic courts as reservations do? I feel it would be desirable for the Government to give us some further elaboration on this, given the fact that, as I understand it, the purpose of the Bill is to make sure that in domestic law the protocols are fixed firmly on the statute book and that they apply and are binding not only on Australia as a whole but also individual citizens of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —This Parliament has passed section 15ab of the Acts Interpretation Act which does permit courts to take into account the type of material to which we are referring in these declarations, which will be formally notified at the time of ratification of the optional protocol. I believe that the way in which the section is phrased-I am afraid I do not have section 15 in front of me-does make it discretionary as to whether the court has regard to this particular aid to interpretation. Normally it would do so only where it considered there was some ambiguity in the article itself, which would be enforceable by reason of its being a grave breach which is made an offence by this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know that I can add much more than that. I have sought some advice from general counsel in the last few minutes and it was to that effect-that is, as I say, a court could take into account the declarations if it were of the view that the declaration was in regard to one of its articles which spoke of a grave breach which itself then became an offence under the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do I take it that it is the Government's view-and, therefore, if this Bill is adopted, the Parliament's view-that the proposed declarations of understanding on the accession of the first additional protocol to the 1949 Geneva Convention should be regarded as superior aids to the interpretation of this law than any other interpretation of the articles of the protocol?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —An Australian court which had to deal with the offences provision of the Act, as it would then be, dealing with grave breaches under the optional protocol to the Geneva Convention, would properly be able to take into account the declaration as an aid to the interpretation of the relevant article. That would be an aid to its understanding, as we would claim-and that is why we speak of declarations rather than reservations-and interpretation of the article. The terms of the article, in a sense, always remain paramount. But the proper understanding or interpretation of them in a case of any perceived ambiguity could be resolved by the court in a way which the declaration suggests is the fair and proper interpretation and understanding of the article.
—Would the interpretation contained in the proposed declaration be the desirable interpretation of the Government and, therefore, of the Parliament when this measure goes through the Parliament?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not desirable in that it is in any sense a contrived wish that the article said this when in fact it says that. It is simply that the Australian Government says that, properly understood, it believes that the article means such and such. That would be the way in which we would ask the court to have regard to the declarations.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the Bill be reported.

DECLARATIONS IN RELATION TO
PROTOCOL I

It is Australia's understanding that in relation to Article 5, with regard to the issue whether, and in what measure, Protecting Powers may have to exercise any functions within the combat zone (such as may be implied by provisions in-Parts III and IV of the Protocol), the role of the Protecting Power will be of a like character to that specified in the First and Second Conventions and Part II of the Fourth Convention, which apply mainly to the battlefield and its immediate surroundings.

It is the understanding of the Government of Australia that in relation to Article 44 of Protocol I, the situation described in the second sentence of paragraph 3 can exist only in occupied territory or in armed conflicts covered by paragraph 4 of Article 1. The Government of Australia will interpret the word ``deployment'' in paragraph 3 (b) of the Article as meaning any movement towards a place from which an attack is to be launched. It will interpret the words ``visible to the adversary'' in the same paragraph as including visible with the aid of binoculars, or by infra-red or image intensification devices.

In relation to Articles 51 to 58 inclusive it is the understanding of Australia that military commanders and others responsible for planning, deciding upon, or executing attacks, necessarily have to reach their decisions on the basis of their assessment of the information from all sources, which is available to them at the relevant time.

In relation to paragraph 5 (b) of Article 51 and to paragraph 2 (a) (iii) of Article 57, it is the understanding of Australia that references to the ``military advantage'' are intended to mean the advantage anticipated from the military attack considered as a whole and not only from isolated or particular parts of that attack and that the term ``military advantage'' involves a variety of considerations including the security of attacking forces. It is further the understanding of Australia that the term ``concrete and direct military advantage anticipated'', used in Articles 51 and 57, means a bona fide expectation that the attack will make a relevant and proportional contribution to the objective of the military attack involved.

It is the understanding of Australia that the first sentence of Article 52 is not intended to, nor does it deal with, the question of incidental or collateral damage resulting from an attack directed against a military objective.
