TALK.START.PARA: —The Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill is an omnibus Bill, most of which we support, amending a number of Acts administered by the Attorney-General. Part 2 of the Bill amends the Australian Federal Police Act; part 3 amends the Cash Transaction Reports Act; part 5 amends the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act; part 6 amends the Director of Public Prosecutions Act; part 7 amends the Proceeds of Crime Act; part 8 amends the Telecommunications (Interception) Act; and part 9 and schedule 2 make amendments to a number of other Commonwealth Acts.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the Opposition is supporting the Bill, although I will be moving amendments at the Committee stage in relation to the Cash Transaction Reports Act. Many of the amendments in the Bill are of a minor or technical nature which we would expect in an omnibus Bill. I will be confining my comments to those amendments relating to the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act, the Director of Public Prosecutions Act, the Proceeds of Crime Act and the Cash Transaction Reports Act. The amendments to the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act provide for a number of punishable offences under the supplementary protocol to the Montreal Convention for the Suppression of Acts of Violence at Airports Serving International Civil Aviation. These offences are: first, to unlawfully and intentionally perform an act of violence against a person at, or to disrupt the services of, an international airport; secondly, to damage the facilities of, or to damage any aircraft not in service located on, such an airport; and, thirdly, to attempt, aid or abet the commission of such an offence.

The amendments provide that these offences will carry a penalty of a maximum of 15 years imprisonment for an act of violence against a person, and 10 years for the other offences. Whilst we support these amendments, they are obviously a substantial policy change and go well beyond the usual framework of an omnibus Bill of this nature. I remind the Senate of the words of the Attorney-General that none of the amendments concern major policy proposals or sensitive policy issues. That is obviously not the case in relation to the amendments of the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act which provides penalties for such serious offences as I have just outlined. They are not merely the minor type of technical drafting amendment which is more properly the content of such a Bill. I draw that concern of the Opposition to the attention of the Government because it is something that we have raised before. There seems to be a tendency in recent times to expand these Bills to cover matters of a more substantial nature than was ever the intention.

The amendments to the Director of Public Prosecutions Act provide for the creation of the new statutory office of the Associate Director of Public Prosecutions. The introduction of a new statutory office, as in the case of the amendments to the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act is also, in our view, a sufficiently substantial matter to warrant legislation other than by way of an omnibus Bill.

By way of a preliminary remark in relation to the Proceeds of Crime Act and the Cash Transaction Reports Act, I take the opportunity to reiterate the Opposition's support for the objectives of these two pieces of legislation: the pursuit of the money trail, by tracing the proceeds of crime; and the removal of the incentive for crime by confiscating the ill-gotten gains of illegal activity. They are laudable objectives.

Part 7 of the Bill deals with amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act. The Bill proposes that the operation of the Commonwealth Proceeds of Crime Act be excluded in relation to Australian Capital Territory (ACT) offences. This part of the Bill is to come into effect on the date that the ACT enacts its own proceeds of crime legislation. Therefore, it is a wind-back for that purpose. There have been several cases in recent times in relation to the Proceeds of Crime Act, in which it has received some serious criticism from the judiciary. Examples of such criticism may be found in the 1989 New South Wales Court of Appeal case of Saffron v. the Director of Public Prosecutions; in the Queensland Court of Criminal Appeal case, Brauer v. the Director of Public Prosecutions; and in another case, which I understand is presently subject to appeal, the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation and the Director of Public Prosecutions v. Kunz in the Supreme Court of Victoria. The criticisms primarily relate to aspects of the Act which intrude upon civil liberties.

The Cash Transaction Reports Act also raises the issue of balancing the interests of the State in investigating and prosecuting criminal activity and the interests of individual liberty. The Privacy Commissioner has commented in relation to this Act that some aspects of it also raise difficult privacy issues. Although the Opposition supports the general thrust of the Act, the shadow Attorney-General in the other place expressed concerns in relation to several matters. The first is the wide definition of `cash dealer' in the Act which gives the Act a very wide ambit of operation. Secondly, the offences, excepting those in section 29, seem to be expressed in absolute terms.

Thirdly, rights of review are virtually non-existent, both in relation to decisions and conduct of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency and those of cash dealers. Fourthly, there are severe implications for rights of privacy-for example, cash transaction reports information may be transmitted to non-Commonwealth agencies which are not subject to the provisions of the Privacy Act. Finally, section 16, which relates to the reporting of suspect transactions, has a very wide ambit.

Part 3 of this Bill amends the Cash Transaction Reports Act. The most significant amendment is to section 16 of the Act to provide for reports of suspect transactions from cash dealers to be provided by the Cash Transaction Reports Agency to the Australian Customs Service. Its omission from the definition of `relevant authority' in subsection 16.6 of the Act was evidently an oversight. Apparently, the Australian Customs Service has been receiving such information despite not being a relevant authority within the terms of the Act. This omission is another demonstration of the need to take care and get it right in the first instance.

The Opposition has been concerned for some time about section 16, which applies to any transaction to which a cash dealer is a party and is not restricted to cash transactions. If the dealer has reasonable grounds to suspect that information concerning the transaction may be relevant to criminal offences, the dealer is obliged to provide the Agency with the `reportable details' as specified in schedule 4 of the Act. This effectively forces the dealer-a bank teller, a bookmaker or whatever-to act as an investigator. The general thrust of the Act makes serious inroads into the principle of client confidentiality.

Section 16 (1) (b) (ii) defines a relevant offence as including `an offence against the law of the Commonwealth'. This extremely wide provision will cover all offences from the most serious to the most trivial. This is in sharp contrast to the evident purpose of the legislation, which is to trace the money trail in order to detect serious offences relating to tax evasion, money laundering and organised crime. As I indicated at the outset, I will be taking this opportunity to pursue an Opposition amendment to narrow the ambit of section 16, by specifying the serious offences to which the section relates. This will, therefore, introduce greater certainty into the reporting obligations imposed on cash dealers.

In summary, the Opposition will support this Bill, although we have serious criticisms of the Government in relation to some aspects, which I mentioned in the last few minutes, particularly with respect to the disturbing practice of including substantial policy changes in an omnibus Bill. The Opposition will be proposing an amendment to the Cash Transaction Reports Act at the committee stage of the Senate's deliberation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that Senator Hill seemed to be having some difficulty with pronouncing the word `omnibus'. I am old enough to recall the times when buses were called omnibuses. I guess that Senator Hill still calls them buses and not omnibuses. As a person with a legal background, he will understand the Latin derivation of the word.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Hill has said, this is an omnibus Bill that will make a number of amendments to legislation administered by the Attorney-General's portfolio. The major amendments relate to: obstructing public officers; a variety of amendments arising from the implementation of the fixed term appointment arrangements of the Australian Federal Police; offences for certain acts, such as violence, committed at international airports; the appointment of an Associate Director of Public Prosecutions; evidence of offences collected by the National Crime Authority; and minor amendments to both the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 and the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987. In our view, these are all tidying up-type amendments to those Acts and we therefore support this legislation.

The flavour of these amendments is obtained by looking at the amendments, which are covered in the second reading speech of the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), to the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987. The way the law currently defines the word `Territory' means that confiscation results in the proceeds of crime passing into Consolidated Revenue of the Commonwealth. The amendment in this case allows the Australian Capital Territory to legislate to confiscate the proceeds of crime and for the proceeds of that confiscation to pass into ACT revenue. That is the type of amendment with which we are dealing. The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. We regard the amendments in each case as relatively unexceptional.

I will now deal with the Opposition amendments. We know from Senator Hill's speech that he intends to move these amendments in the committee stage. I have only just seen the amendments as they were handed out a moment ago. I will make a few brief remarks about them.

Broadly speaking, the Australian Democrats have supported the Government's efforts to implement legislation aimed at pursuing the money trail in the context of criminal activity. At the same time, we have approached this issue and monitored the operation of this sort of legislation in relation to the protection of civil liberties; indeed, there is a considerable and often fine balance to be drawn.

The Australian Democrats had reservations about both the workability of the Cash Transaction Reports Act and its impact on privacy at the time of its passage, and we are continuing to monitor these aspects. However, although well-intentioned in trying to strike a somewhat different balance between law enforcement and civil liberties, we do not consider that the Opposition's amendments achieve that end and, hence, the Australian Democrats will not be supporting them. We believe there is a danger that such amendments would make the Act almost unworkable by putting a quite unreasonable burden of interpretation on bank tellers. Putting the amendments aside, I simply reiterate that the Australian Democrats support this Bill and the objectives of the legislation which it seeks to amend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government, I welcome the expressions of support for the second reading of the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. I will leave the matters relating to the proposed amendments circulated by Senator Hill on behalf of the Opposition parties to the committee stage. The Bill is most important amending, as it does, a number of Acts administered within the Attorney-General's portfolio and other related Acts. I will just usefully mention a few of them in this second reading response.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst the amendments to the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 deal with a fairly minor matter of administration to do with review and appeal processes designed to extend rights of review in a way which will enhance efforts to make the Australian Federal Police (AFP) a more unified work force, I think that that terminology masks what has been a remarkable transformation of the Australian Federal Police over the last few years as the premier law enforcement agency of the Commonwealth. Today, as honourable senators will know, members of the Australian Federal Police-whether they are constables or whether they are members who would be called civilians-are regarded as being, and are, members of the one Australian Federal Police force.

From my visits to the offices in Adelaide, Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne in recent weeks, I believe that this has made for not only an industrial relations transformation of the Federal Police, but also has made for a much more unified approach by members of the Australian Federal Police to their task, without depending on artificial divisions when they are all seeking to devote their energies and skills to the achievement of common goals. I believe that the commitment of the members of the Australian Federal Police to their task-to the goals set for them by the Government and by the Commissioner-is, in no small way, helped by this move to be a fully unified work force.

The transformation, for example, whereby members of the Australian Federal Police are employed on a contractual basis of employment rather than with a long term tenure has tended to characterise police forces and has been based on a mixture of civil service, Public Service and quasi-military models-with renewal provisions after a period of, let us say, 10 years has struck outside observers as being quite remarkable.

Indeed, the Home Secretary of the United Kingdom, when he visited Australia late last year, said that this was a revolutionary move in terms of police forces throughout the world which he certainly could not achieve within his own jurisdiction. He commended Australia for leading the way in this particular regard. That will not surprise you, Mr Acting Deputy President, because you will know that the Federal Police have been under the guidance of very considerable ministerial interest during this period of transformation.

As to the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988, there have been some small oversights in the drafting which meant that the Australian Customs Service was not included as a relevant authority to receive certain information. That has been remedied in a way which will enhance the proper operation of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency.

There are other provisions in this omnibus legislation. For example, the amendments to the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act 1973 make it an offence for a person to unlawfully and intentionally perform an act of violence against a person at, or to disrupt the services of, an international airport, and so on. These provisions give effect to the necessary provisions of the protocol-I think it is-to the Montreal Convention, and are most appropriate and apt at this time of the Gulf conflict when we are very conscious of the need to have a high state of readiness as regards airport facilities around the world, particularly international airports, as we safeguard them and of course those who use the facilities, more particularly, from terrorist activity.

Whilst this particular provision was not originally incorporated in the Bill, with the Gulf conflict and threats of terrorism specifically in mind it indicates how proper and necessary it is to have such offences under Australian law, in dependence, as I say, on the protocol to the Montreal Convention, in order to play our part in the international community to ensure that international air travel is not disrupted by violence, particularly that which is designed to serve a political end.

There are amendments also to the Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983-for example, conferring certain powers on the Associate Director but, most interestingly, Senator Hill, dealing with the question of the power of the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) to give use/derivative use indemnity in relation to evidence to be given in a broad range of State or Territory proceedings.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is one of them.

—It is one of the provisions. It is interesting that I had the good fortune to have lunch today with Mr Peter Costello, the shadow Minister for business and consumer affairs, who has just returned from the United States, where he had most interesting discussions with law enforcement personnel, particularly in New York City, about the use of indemnities in order to deal with corporate and securities fraud, and insider trading in particular. As one gives an indemnity to someone lower down the scale, one of course is then in a position to assemble evidence which might be able to be used against somebody closer to the top of the ladder--
—The experience of some of us in this place, on various committees in the last few years, is that one ought to be cautious in giving an indemnity.

—In the course of the lunch, and over a lime and mineral water, I put to him that the experience of the Verducci matter at the Queanbeyan conspiracy trial indicated that perhaps the use of indemnities needed to be treated with caution. In relation to certain types of white collar crime there may be a better case than in relation to conspiracies relating to drug dealing and trafficking.
—I understand there is a reference on this matter before the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority.

—Senator Hill tells me, and I understand, that there is a reference on this matter before the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority. I can understand that there is a very real question as to whether a person lower down in the criminal hierarchy who can give valuable evidence against somebody further up in the hierarchy ought not to be prosecuted and whether his cooperation in providing evidence be taken into account in the sentencing by the judge or, if he is sentenced, in the later decision by the Executive to reduce that sentence.

SPEECH.PARA: It can also be said that it would prevent claims being made during the trial that the witness who had been offered an indemnity was giving the evidence as part of a deal which might colour the evidence he was giving. So it is a very complex matter. But I do note that one of the purposes of the amendments to the DPP Act is to give power to the DPP to give a use/derivative use indemnity in relation to evidence to be given in a broader range of State or Territory proceedings.

We also have amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987. Basically, this is to allow the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) to enact its own legislation dealing with the confiscation of criminal assets. I am sure that the ACT would be upset at the fact that, in respect of an indictable offence against the criminal law of the Australian Capital Territory, any related confiscation proceedings at the moment are taken under the Commonwealth Act and any recoveries are paid to the Consolidated Revenue Fund of the Commonwealth. Quite clearly, that is not satisfactory from the ACT point of view.

The proceeds of crime legislation has been extremely well received in the community, who quite rightly see the stripping of the criminal profits from, particularly, drug traffickers as a very good move. Not only does this penalise the offender personally by stripping that person of considerable assets that he may have accumulated but also, in doing so, it removes the financial base for further criminal activity which could not only allow the person, even from gaol, to further some criminal enterprise, but of course could also be laundered into the white economy and therefore corrupt business, trade and commerce in the community, quite apart from the criminal activity that might be undertaken on the basis of the possession of those assets.

It is the intention of the Government to introduce legislation following up the undertaking of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the last election campaign to make sure that those assets are put into a trust fund, 50 per cent of which would be devoted to further law enforcement efforts and 50 per cent to drug education and rehabilitation projects. Mr Deputy President, I think you would believe in the efficacy of those drug education and rehabilitation projects, or at least would believe that they ought to be supported in a way which the setting up of this trust fund will do. It is certainly rather a nice twist to the sage of criminal greed that the assets which are accumulated by criminals can be used in this way. I think it would receive the commendation of the whole community.

As far as the amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 are concerned, suffice it to say that none of the amendments extend the interception powers under the Act, a most important provision, well safeguarded, as this Parliament-the Senate in particular-requires, because we have such an invasion of privacy where telephone interception is undertaken. It is a very necessary device to combat serious criminal activity and has proved to be extremely useful. The minor amendments being undertaken are to do with administrative matters.

There are amendments to some other Acts; for example, amendments to enhance the efficiency of the National Crime Authority by enabling it to assemble and give evidence directly to the prosecuting authority. I must say-and Senator Hill may be of the same view-that I was a little surprised that that was not the case and that apparently the National Crime Authority has to give its material to the Attorney-General or a law enforcement agency. The intergovernmental committee on the National Crime Authority suggested that it be able to give evidence directly to a prosecuting authority, and that will be able to be undertaken as a result of the passage of this legislation, which I commend to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-During the second reading debate I foreshadowed that I would be moving an amendment to section 16 of the Cash Transaction Reports Act. Two other small amendments are incidental to that principal amendment. Senator Coulter of the Australian Democrats indicated in the second reading debate that the Democrats would not be supporting our amendments. Therefore, I recognise that they will not be carried. Nevertheless, the Opposition regards the issue as important and, therefore, I move amendments 1, 2 and 3 that have been circulated in the name of the Opposition:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 2, page 1, after subclause (1), insert the following subclause:
``(1a) Section 20a and paragraph 21 (aa) commence 4 months after the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent.''.
2. After clause 20, page 7, insert the following clause:
Interpretation
``20a. Section 3 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting in subsection (l) the following definition:
`serious offence' for the purposes of subparagraph 16 (1) (b) (ii) means:
(a) a murder, or an offence of a kind equivalent to murder;
(b) a kidnapping, or an offence of a kind equivalent to kidnapping;
(c) a serious narcotics offence, being an offence in relation to a narcotic substance as defined by subsection 4(1) of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987:
(a) constituted by the production, possession (including possession for supply), supply, importation or export of a narcotic substance; and
(b) involving a quantity of the narcotic substance that is equal to or greater than the trafficable quantity applicable to the narcotic substance;
(d) a money laundering offence, being an offence against section 81 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987;

(e) the receipt, possession (including possession for supply), concealment, disposition of or bringing into Australia any money, or any other property, that may reasonably be suspected of being proceeds of crime, being an offence against section 82 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987;
(f) an organised fraud offence, being an offence against section 83 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987; and
(g) an offence constituted by aiding, abetting or conspiring to commit an offence of the kind referred to in paragraphs (a), (b), (c), (d), (e) or (f).''.
3. Clause 21, page 7, before paragraph (a), insert the following paragraph:
``(aa) by omitting from subparagraph (1) (b) (ii) `an offence' and substituting `a serious offence';''.

As I said in the second reading debate, the amendments which deal with the Cash Transaction Reports Act are being moved because the Opposition thinks that the obligation within the Act that is placed upon cash dealers to report is unreason- ably wide. As I said, section 16 of that Act provides for the reporting of suspicious transactions by cash dealers where they suspect that they have information relevant to the investigation of an offence under any relevant Commonwealth law.

The Opposition is concerned about the ambit of this section which, it believes, is far too wide. We have moved an amendment so that for the purposes of this section an offence under a Commonwealth law will mean a serious offence of a specified kind. The definition of `serious offence' that we are proposing is taken from the Telecommunications (Interception) Act and the Proceeds of Crime Act, which define, respectively, the type of offences for which telephone interceptions are allowed and for which confiscation of property orders may be made.

In our opinion, section 16, as it is presently drafted, poses a serious risk to civil liberties. By this amendment we seek to confine its operation to the purpose intended in the enactment of the legislation-that is, the pursuit of the money trail left by organised crime through the reporting of suspicious transactions by cash dealers where they suspect that they have information relevant to the investigation of a serious offence.

As I said, the substance of our amendment is set out in amendment 2. Basically, a `serious offence' is to be defined as meaning murder, kidnapping, serious narcotic offences, including money laundering, and offences against sections 82 and 83 of the Proceeds of Crime Act, which relate to the possession of money which is suspected of being proceeds of crime and organised fraud offences. Amendment No. 3 is a consequential amendment. Amendment No.1 provides for the commencement date of amendment Nos 2 and 3 to be four months after the date on which this Act receives royal assent. The reason for the delay is so that the Cash Transaction Reports Agency and cash dealers will have time to familiarise themselves with the new requirements. I commend the amendments to the Com- mittee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the aim of the Opposition's amendment is to limit the circumstances in which a cash dealer must make a report of a suspicious transaction under section 16 of the Cash Transaction Reports Act. The amendment would limit the making of a report to those transactions which give rise to a suspicion of a serious offence, as defined.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government rejects this particular amendment because it believes that it would make the suspect transaction reporting provisions quite unworkable. Let me give an example: imagine that a person enters a bank to make a deposit of cash. The teller has a reasonably-based suspicion that the person has been engaged in drug trafficking. At present the suspicion would be sufficient to support a report under section 16. Under the proposed amendment it would be necessary for the teller also to suspect that the quantity of drugs involved was in excess of the trafficable quantity, because trafficking in any quantity less than this would not be a serious offence under the proposed amendment. There may be the question: how is the teller ever likely to be in a position to form a reasonably-based suspicion of the amount of drugs involved in the offence?

I think when one considers the difficulty that a teller would face, one can see that the Opposition's amendment-which I think is well motivated-would in fact lead to an unworkable situation. It may be also that it would lead to a situation where instead of the reporting of transactions under section 16 (1) (b) (ii), a report would be made under subsection 1 (b) (i)-that is, it would deal with the report relevant to tax evasion, which I suppose would quite properly rely on a presumption that money earned from a drug trafficking offence, for example, would not be declared as income.

It may be of interest in that regard to note that in the first 12 months of the operation of section 16, the great majority of reports have related to suspected tax evasion. Of the 6,250 reports lodged, 4,587 have related to suspected tax evasion. I believe that an amendment in relation to the offences-and this is what is proposed by the Opposition-would not really deal with the possibility that more reports would be made in that situation in relation to tax evasion.

The Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill, as we know, is cast in terms of reasonable grounds to suspect rather than reasonable grounds to believe so that the lower threshold will alleviate the need for cash dealers to undertake extensive investigation before being able to pass on information to the Director of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency. This whole question of the threshold and what a cash dealer would have to be satisfied about was considered by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. This morning I read in my office three or four pages of its report. I do not have it with me at the moment but I can confidently say that that approach was endorsed by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

It is also to be noted, I believe, that, where a cash dealer lodges a report in good faith under section 16, the cash dealer is protected from suit by the customer or any other person. This is dealt with in section 16(5). For the cash dealer to be protected, it is necessary for the cash dealer to believe in good faith that the suspected offence is within the class specified-section 16(1) (b) (ii). By narrowing the class of offences as proposed, this exercise becomes much more difficult, perhaps impossible, for the cash dealer.

There are also other consequences. I believe that cash dealers, who are persons subject to the mandatory reporting requirements of section 16, would believe that the burden which would be placed on them should this amendment be carried would be very heavy. I believe that much more consultation-for example, with cash dealers-and the reporting back of their particular points of view would be very necessary before the Senate would pass such an amendment.

When the legislation was first passed by this Parliament, I, on behalf of the Government, indicated that after a period of some three years there ought to be a review of its operation. I gave an assurance that the Government would undertake that review and table a report within three years of the legislation coming into effect. I think that would be a wise course to follow. I believe that the matters raised by Senator Hill could well be the subject of part of that review to see whether the provisions had operated in a way which is workable. Perhaps the review itself could examine the claim that I am making, that the sort of provisions which would be incorporated by the amendment would be unworkable from the point of view of the cash dealers. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a letter from the Clerk to me dated 11 February 1991, which purports to refute allegations made in notice of motion No. 146, given by Senator Coates on 21 December 1990. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
11 February 1991
Senator R. Hill
Leader of the Opposition in the Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Hill

I am writing to each party leader and independent Senator concerning the notice of motion given by Senator Coates on the last day of sitting. On 16 January I wrote in similar terms to Mr President and the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

This notice makes a most serious and defamatory allegation against my colleague Peter O'Keeffe and me, namely, that we have published statements of a partisan nature, an allegation which impugns our professional integrity.

Immediately after the notice was given I wrote to Senator Coates expressing surprise that he had not sought to discuss with me his apparent concerns before giving the notice, and inviting him to discuss the matter with me. I have repeated that invitation but it has not been accepted.

The only basis of the allegation contained in the notice is a reference to two articles written by Peter O'Keeffe and me in parliamentary journals and a report of my answers to some questions put to me by a journalist concerning the procedures for consideration of bills in committees.

There is nothing in these items to justify the allegation of partisanship. A statement with which a Senator may disagree is not for that reason a partisan statement. My article and the press report give a favourable account of the new procedures for referral of bills to committees, but it can hardly be partisan to be supportive of procedures which were unanimously recommended by an all-party Senate committee and which were adopted by the Senate without opposition. Contrary to the assertion in the notice, those items do not contain any ``criticism of certain Senators''. They refer to differences of view among Senators, but offer no critique or evaluation of those different views. The press report contains a great deal of commentary by the journalist in addition to my answers, but I am not responsible for that commentary. The characterisation in the notice of Peter O'Keeffe's article as being ``in praise of a former Senator'' is absurd. That article is a study of the way in which a Senator can use a private Senator's bill to deal with a difficult and sensitive issue. It is no more ``in praise of a former Senator'' than a previous article by Peter O'Keeffe referring to the role of the Chairman of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee was in praise of Senator Cooney.
The serious allegation of partisanship is therefore not justified by the items referred to in the notice.

The articles in question are not different in kind from other articles written by other clerks on parliamentary matters over many years. Such articles frequently contain analysis, critique or evaluation of parliamentary matters, but never partisanship. In fact, articles written by clerks in the past were far more robust in commenting upon proceedings in the Senate than I or my colleagues have ever been. In an article written in 1970 the then Deputy-Clerk, Roy Bullock, referred in the following terms to the practice of the then government backbenchers of clogging the general business section of the Notice Paper with their own items of business:

``This situation was not good. It denigrated the Senate as an institution, frustrated a vigorous Opposition, and was completely out of keeping with the new order of things under proportional representation, and the need to streamline Parliamentary procedures.''
Such writings did not lead to any notices of motion in the Senate, or, indeed, to any adverse comment at all.
If the articles in question are regarded as objectionable, then virtually nothing can be written by any officer.

As you would be aware, my colleagues and I advise all Senators without regard to their political affiliations. Frequently we give advice which may not suit the political convenience of one or other of the parties in the Senate. Hitherto that very proper situation has not led to any allegation of partisanship. I trust that we are not now coming to a situation in which advice that accords with one party's objectives is regarded as good advice but advice to the contrary is considered partisan.

If the notice of motion remains on the Notice Paper undebated, as is normal with general business notices of motion, that may be taken as an indication that the allegation is not regarded as important.
Regardless of any other action in relation to the notice, I ask that this letter be incorporated in Hansard as a refutation of the allegation in the notice.
I have forwarded copies of this letter to Mr President and the Leader of the Government in the Senate.
Yours sincerely,
(Harry Evans)

TALK.START.PARA: —Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1990-91 seeks appropriations for $234.1m in 1990-91. It comprises two items: firstly, $181.4m for payment by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce to meet the insurance claims associated with defaults by Iraq on credit sales by the Australian Wheat Board, which were insured under the national interest provisions of the Australian Trade Commission Act. The Australian Government underwrites the national interest export insurance scheme. The second item is $52.7m for the Department of Defence to meet the equipment and stores expenditure associated with the deployment of elements of the Defence Force to the Middle East.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill in effect is an extra Appropriation Bill, which has been introduced in advance of the normal additional Appropriations process. The purpose of the Bill is to cover urgent payments resulting from Australia's involvement in the Gulf conflict. Unforseen or urgent payments of this nature are generally accommodated by the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance, but in this instance the amount required would significantly exceed the $170m which is appropriated to the Advance to the Minister for Finance.
In his second reading speech the Minister said in relation to Iraqi wheat payments:
Iraq discontinued payments on its wheat debt after the imposition of the UN trade sanctions, and it is now considered unlikely that any payments will be made in the foreseeable future.

The $181.4m is to meet the Government's immediate obligation under the national interest insurance provisions between now and the end of May 1991. A sum of $43.97m has already been paid out of the Advance to the Minister for Finance (AMF) in January, pending the passage of this Bill. The Bill covers with a payment of $181.4m, including the $43.97m from the AMF payable to the end of May, assuming that the defaulting continues. An additional payment of $29.7m will be required in June. This will be included in the normal additional Estimates. Further claims totalling $247m in 1991-92 and $34m in 1992-93 at current exchange rates are anticipated. These will be handled in the course of the normal Budget Appropriation processes.

The Government has also approved additional funds of $68.9m in 1990-91 to cover additional Department of Defence expenditure arising from the Gulf conflict. Of this, $52.7m is being sought under this Bill. The remainder-$16.2m for 1990-91-will be sought through the normal Additional Estimates process. The Government says it anticipates a further $27.475m spread over the following two years-$23.6m in 1991-92 and $3.9m in 1992-93. These latter figures, I would assume, must be regarded as very tempting indeed at this time.

The amounts sought are for equipment and stores expenditure associated with the deployment of elements of the Defence Forces to the Middle East. They in no way represent the total cost of Australia's involvement in the Middle East conflict. Several other departments will incur extra costs, for example, for additional overseas aid, the United Nations relief fund, extra security at domestic airports and at other points in Australia, and so on. The Opposition has strongly supported the Government's actions with regard to the Gulf conflict and it follows therefore that the coalition supports Appropriation Bill (No. 3) now before the Senate.

Other coalition speakers in this debate will cover in more detail matters pertaining to these specific Appropriations contained in this Bill. I wish to confine my remarks to the Government's budgetary position and to the major easing of fiscal policy which has occurred this financial year and which shows no signs of abating.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep it relevant to the Bill.

—Well, it is an Appropriation Bill, so anything is relevant in that sense. I think the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) will find my remarks be relevant to the legislation. I propose to outline this dramatic deterioration in some detail. I have said the coalition supports Appropriation Bill (No. 3). We accept the need for the Appropriations and their urgency. In supporting the Bill I urge the Government to take other measures to offset the still further deterioration of $234m that the Bill makes to the Government's fiscal position. The Senate will recall that in the 1990-91 Budget Speech last August the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Budget will deliver in precise terms, a surplus of $8.107 billion . . . This Commonwealth surplus will ensure that Australia's public sector as a whole is in balance . . . The net public sector borrowing requirement for 1990-91 will therefore be zero as once again the Commonwealth Budget surplus offsets the combined borrowing of all Commonwealth, State and local Government authorities . . . This means that the whole public sector of Australia will borrow no new money and that total Commonwealth debt as a share of the economy will be cut further to be only a third of what it was five years ago.
The Treasurer also said in that speech:

Tonight's Budget . . . builds on the fiscal achievements secured to date and maintains fiscal policy as the Government's principal weapon in the fight against the current account deficit and our overseas debt.
In his concluding remarks in that Budget Speech last August, the Treasurer said:
. . . it is a Budget that will keep us in the right financial shape as we enter the 1990s.

Those fine words, that typically arrogant and self-aggrandising rhetoric which is the Treasurer's hallmark, were never true. The Government has never maintained a fiscal policy as a principal weapon in its fight against the current account deficit and our overseas debt. The Budget Estimates were never likely to be achieved. Indeed his Estimates and the forecasts on which they were based were almost universally recognised at the outset as optimistic. Since then it has become increasingly obvious that this is the case.

In recent weeks we have seen a number of predictions as to the likely Budget outturn. The Minister for Finance started the ball rolling with his comments that he expected the surplus to be about half the original $8.1 billion. He followed that up last Friday by saying that it was `more likely to be less rather than more than half'. The Treasurer in response to the original $4 billion figure put forward by the Minister for Finance would only say, `Yes, the surplus will be down substantially'. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) said last week, `There will be a significant shortfall in the projected 1990-91 surplus'. Again in the Senate today he refused to nominate a likely outcome. A detailed independent report by the merchant bank Schroders Australia Ltd also last week concluded:

The Commonwealth's 1990-91 Budget is likely to come in closer to balance than the Commonwealth's revised $4 billion surplus estimate. A marked fall in employment over the first half of 1991 could see the Budget slip into deficit.
In the Australian today in an article entitled `The Disappearing Surplus' economics editor Alan Wood wrote:
We are witnessing a massive deteriorating in the public sector's financial position . . . I suspect that the extent and speed of the collapse . . . is not generally appreciated.
He went on to state:
. . . in the space of just 12 months the Federal Budget will have swung from a surplus of $8 billion to balance.

Whether the Budget outturn for 1990-91 will come in in surplus, balance or deficit is difficult to predict with any certainty. What is certain, however, is that the statements by the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance do not describe sufficiently the extent of the unravelling of the Budget. There is no doubt whatsoever that the final outturn will be only marginally in surplus at best, and it will quite probably finish in deficit. Nor is it correct to claim, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer and other senior Ministers have, that the collapse of the Budget arithmetic has been due simply to what they term `a cyclical deterioration resulting from the recession'-a recession, of course, which the Prime Minister and the Treasurer said two days before the election in March 1990 we would not have; a recession which the Treasurer said eight months later we had to have.

A not insignificant part of the deterioration has or will result from structural decisions deliberately taken by the Government. They include the purchase of the State Bank of Victoria by the Commonwealth Bank at a cost to the Federal Budget of $413m; tax cuts associated with the wage-tax deal effective on 1 January this year at a cost of $430m in lost revenue-$1 billion in a full year; the decision to make deficiency payments to woolgrowers at a cost of $300m this year; the loss of up to $700m, so said by the Government, after the failed attempt to sell the Moomba to Sydney gas pipeline; and the $234m in today's Bill.

Combined, those five items alone account for a reduction in the projected surplus of more than $2 billion. I wish to make two points here in relation to these decisions. First, I am not implying that they were all wrong. Some were probably inevitable and several of them the Opposition supported, but they represent an easing in fiscal policy. The second point I want to make in relation to one of them is that it is about time that the Government stopped blaming the coalition for its loss of what it claims to be $700m in revenue on the potential proceeds of the Moomba to Sydney gas pipeline. We said at the time of defeating the legislation in this House that would have been part of the process of sale last year that the only reason we were blocking that legislation was that the way the Government was going about it involved a deliberate, cold and calculated breach of normal commercial contracts and normal commercial processes, and that, had the Government gone about its attempted sale of the pipeline in a proper, normal commercial manner, we would have supported it. So let me hear no more of the nonsense that it is the Opposition that has caused that deficiency in the Government's budgetary position this year.

On top of these Budget surplus-reducing decisions, there have been some other major increases in expenditure and decreases in revenue. The half yearly statement of Commonwealth government financial transactions provides some revealing trends, including so-called activity level variations, which show, to cite just a few examples, that Social Security expenditure at 31 December 1990 for the six months was $2.65 billion or 21.1 per cent higher than for the same six months last year. Social Security expenditure will have to fall by some $900m in the second half over the first half to meet budget and, if it remains the same in the second part as in the first, the surplus will be another $900m less. If expenditure rises by the same amount, $1.2 billion, as it did for the corresponding period last year, the blow-out on that item alone will be $2.1 billion.

Health expenditure in the first six months of this year was 11.8 per cent higher than last year compared with a budgeted figure for the year as a whole of 8.6 per cent. Transport and Communications expenditure is 30.7 per cent higher compared with the 12-month Budget estimate of 14.2 per cent. Expenditure on industry assistance and development is up 29.8 per cent compared with a 12-month estimate of 18.6 per cent. Foreign affairs and overseas aid expenditure is up 22.4 per cent compared with the 12-month estimate of 7.4 per cent; Administrative Services expenditure is up 28.7 per cent over the corresponding period last year; and public debt interest is down 13.8 per cent rather than the budgeted 17.5 per cent reduction, and the fall in public debt interest this year will certainly be much less than even the 13.8 per cent of the first six months.

Although timing differences can account for some of these increases, they also account for some reductions compared to the Budget, for example, in labour and employment, education and housing. The net effect of these increases, excluding the social security increase of $2.1 billion, would conservatively see expenditure grow by up to an additional $1 billion over budget for the year as a whole. That result is before the further increases for Defence and Social Security take full effect.

On the revenue side, the signs of meeting budget are equally dim. Sales tax was down 4.1 per cent in the first six months due to a decline in motor vehicle sales and a flat retail turnover on comparable December half figures for 1989, compared with an estimated rise of 5.3 per cent for the full year. Customs duty on imports was down 18.1 per cent versus a full-year estimate of a decline of 6.4 per cent. Company tax revenues increased significantly in the six months to December as a result of changes to payments dates, but that will not be maintained in the second six months. Prescribed payments system revenue was down by a substantial 24.7 per cent compared to a budgeted full year figure of only 3.1 per cent. The reason given for this by the Department of Finance was that the figure was `reflecting depressed building activity'. This activity is not anticipated to pick up quickly in the current half year.

Net pay as you earn receipts were up by a meagre 1.5 per cent compared with a 12-month Budget estimate of 7.6 per cent, and non-PAYE individual tax was down 13 per cent as opposed to the budgeted increase of 14.8 per cent for the year. Both those figures are unlikely to rise over the coming six months and, due to the tax cuts, would never have met budget anyway.

Tax revenues are now certain to fall well short of the Budget forecast-a shortfall of $4 billion is probably a conservative estimate. On the basis of what I have already outlined it is not at all unrealistic, indeed the contrary, to say that the Government is staring down the barrel of a 1990-91 Budget deficit of $1 billion compared with the Budget estimate of an $8 billion surplus. This outcome is not a figment of the coalition's imagination. It is broadly in line with the detailed analysis by Schroders Australia Ltd and with the highly respected economics commentator Alan Wood in today's Australian, both of whom I have referred to earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was this part of the planned recession?

—This was very much commensurate with the planned recession that we were not to have but we did have, according to the Treasurer. The Budget outcome will not only represent a massive easing in fiscal policy in terms of the Budget result; it will also result in a major increase, not a net balance as budgeted, in the public sector borrowing result.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that one can see from those figures the possibility of a positive public sector borrowing requirement of somewhere between 1 per cent and 3 per cent of gross domestic product compared with the nil balance assumed in the Budget. The public sector borrowing requirement has already been relaxed by the $1 billion over budget in borrowing limits for the Australian Wool Corporation and the Government announcement to allow the South Australian Government to borrow an additional $970m over its borrowing limit to bail out the State Bank of South Australia, or more appropriately to bail out the Bannon Government. On top of that, the Victorian budget seems certain to blow out by many hundreds of millions of dollars, although a precise figure is impossible to estimate because the Kirner Government is deliberately refusing to make public the up to date figures on the Government's financial situation. The New South Wales Government also acknowledged recently a deterioration in its budget position compared with its estimates at budget time.

This return of the public sector in a big way to the ranks of net borrower will mean the issue of new government paper onto the financial markets and therefore a drawing on our national savings. It will put heavy pressure on interest rates; it will cause a major drain on our capital markets, just at a time when capital will be necessary to rebuild and refinance run-down local businesses; and it could result in loss of investor confidence rarely if ever witnessed before in this country. This crisis in public finance will be heightened if the Government's 12 March industry statement further draws heavily on Consolidated Revenue. Last Friday the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, said on this issue:
It's unlikely they-
that is, the additional borrowings by the public sector to date-
will have much impact this year-more likely they'd be the subject of future budgets.
This suggests that next year's Budget will be formed with a much lower surplus, if any-or a much higher deficit-as its base.
All the Budget and public sector borrowing requirement collapse is not only tragic but ironic when taken in the context of the Treasurer's comments at the Premiers Conference last June, when he said:

It is very important for Australia to be able to paint the position always, at least in this immediate period, that the public sector has not got its hand in the savings cookie jar of Australia, that it has it out.

That is precisely what this Government has done. It has put the public sector's hands right back into the cookie jar of the nation's savings. This is a public finance problem of enormous magnitude. The Government must urgently set about addressing the disastrous unravelling of fiscal policy if the resulting consequences are not to prove virtually intractable.

In making my remarks I want to draw attention to what I believe is a very dangerous public finance position facing Australia. In saying that I in no way am critical of Appropriation Bill (No. 3), which I said at the outset the coalition supports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on behalf of the Australian Democrats on Appropriation Bill (No. 3). The second reading speech of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) contains the following passage:

SPEECH.PARA: The amounts in this Bill are being sought in advance of the additional estimates to meet urgent requirements which have arisen as a consequence of the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq on 2 August last year.

The Bill outlines the amounts, which are $52.6m in round figures for the Department of Defence and $181.4m for the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. The back page of the Bill gives a breakdown of the amounts which were appropriated under the Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1990-91 for each of the departments. In the case of the Department of Defence that was a figure of $3,259.7m, so the additional $52.6m for that Department means an additional 1.6 per cent. In the case of the Australian Trade Commission I note that the amount appropriated under the Appropriation Act (No. 1) 199091 was $2.8m, so the additional $181.4m represents a 64-fold or 6,400 per cent increase in the allocation to that Department-to quote the Minister's speech-`to meet the urgent requirements which have arisen as a consequence of the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq on 2 August last year'.

While we have a considerable absolute addition to expenditure on defence relative to the amount originally allocated, which represents only a 1.6 per cent increase, in terms of the non-military expenditure there is an enormous increase in the requirement which, according to the Minister, has been made necessary as a consequence of the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq on 2 August last year.

This points to the fact that non-military costs of war are very considerable. I am reminded, as I suppose is every senator and member, that every time one gets on an aircraft one is required to be at the airport half an hour earlier than one otherwise would be. Every time we board an aircraft that represents 100 person hours of time. We are also reminded of the extra security provisions at airports and the extra cost which that involves. This appears nowhere in the appropriations which are now before us. Undoubtedly engaging in war is a costly business, and many of those costs show up in ways that are not immediately apparent.

The Australian Democrats have stressed this in the past and we stress it again. When we look at this conflict in the Middle East we find that there has been a great willingness to plough a very large amount of money into a war effort. By comparison there has been a great tardiness by this nation and many others to spend money in ways that would alleviate very considerable human poverty and deprivation in many parts of the world. We are reminded that the Americans, for instance, claimed that they had spent $30 billion on their efforts in the Middle East crisis up to the end of last year and are now expecting to spend half a billion dollars to one billion dollars per day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before the suspension of the sitting, the point I was developing was the enormous financial cost of prosecuting a war. I was pointing out that the major component of the Appropriation Bill which is now before us is the $181.4m going to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. This represents a 64-fold-or, in percentage terms, a 6,400 per cent-increase in the expenditure under that item. As the Minister said in his second reading speech, this has happened as a consequence of the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq on 2 August last year.

SPEECH.PARA: I was mentioning that up to the end of last year it was said that the Americans alone had spent some $30,000m, and that the current costs were running at around one half to one billion dollars a day to prosecute this war. One cannot help but then reflect on the alternative measures which could be undertaken with this money to alleviate world poverty, hunger, disease and a number of other things that afflict a large number of people, particularly in view of the fact that we are allocating this extra funding at a time when the Government has progressively reduced its allocation for foreign aid. That contribution now stands, I understand, at about 0.33 per cent of gross domestic product compared with the United Nations suggested objective of 0.7 per cent of GDP.

When we debated this matter in January, I think many of my Democrat colleagues also pointed out that this war was not being prosecuted because of human rights abuses. We catalogued then, and have catalogued since in a number of notices of motion before the Senate, the history of human rights abuses and the history of the denial of action on United Nations resolution after United Nations resolution, in many cases involving gross denial of human liberties and human rights. So, one is forced to the conclusion that in this case we are acting on United Nations resolution 678 precisely because oil is involved.

There are a few figures which I think are relevant here. In the debate in January, Senator Tate and several other speakers made great play of the 300-odd babies who had been taken out of humidicribs and left to die on the floor. I think senators will recall an answer by Senator Tate yesterday in relation to the scale of child poverty and death around the world. Senator Evans said that 40,000 children a year-about 110 children every day-die as a consequence of the lack of quite simple things like clean water, immunisation against easily preventable disease, sufficient food, adequate hygiene and adequate shelter.

Again, one is left with the impression that this Government, and indeed the governments of the coalition, in prosecuting a very expensive war rather than pursuing sanctions, have not been doing that out of the best interests of human beings but merely because this really is a resource war and the interest is in the ability to retain access to oil.

I will give a few other figures. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees estimates that between 300,000 and two million refugees will flee the Gulf war. It is anticipated that the cost of providing food, shelter and clothing for these refugees will top $175m-roughly the amount of money that we are adding to our estimates under the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce.

It is also estimated that the increased cost of fuel threatens economic recovery in non-oil producing countries throughout the Third World, particularly in Africa. The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development has estimated that, based on a cost of $25 a barrel, Third World countries this year are facing an average increase in oil costs of 110 per cent, or $450m over the 1990 year.

From August to November 1990 the oil price in Mozambique increased by 65 per cent; Zimbabwe raised petrol and other fuel prices by between 13 per cent and 65 per cent; fuel imports to Zimbabwe increased from 296.4 million to 423.5 million Zimbabwe dollars; and Sudan announced in late 1990 that the increased cost of its oil import bill was 200 million dollars in its money-approximately $US45m.

We have, on a number of occasions, drawn attention to the failure of the Australian Government and other governments to give effect to United Nations sanctions. We believe that a great deal more effective efforts could be made in prosecuting this internationally illegal invasion of Kuwait, not by military means but, rather, by the application of sanctions which, I repeat, were working-and according to the Central Intelligence Agency, were working-before the countries, led by the United States of America, decided to settle this matter by military means.

I would like to turn to a matter which is related to the way out of this present predicament. In that debate in January and, indeed, in many public speeches since, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), other Ministers and spokespeople for the Opposition have used the term `new world order'. Clearly, many people are looking forward to a different arrangement once this war is out of the way, particularly in view of the decrease in tensions-although I think even that must be qualified now in relation to what is happening with the Baltic states and some of the other states within the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR). But assuming that that decreased tension continues, then some different order from what we have had in the past must be put in place.

We have seen many of our leaders-and not a few politicians in this place-strut this term `new world order' as a hope for the aftermath of the present Gulf war. Peace and global security are to be the hallmarks of this new order and that has come though clearly in all speeches. But how is this to be arrived at and what are the other characteristics of this new world order? To find out, we need to consider how the old world order got us into this present mess and whether those factors and attitudes are still ascendant in those who would guide us towards this brave new society.

While defenders of multinational intervention in the Middle East trumpet civil liberty and release of the Kuwaiti people from an unwelcome invader as the cause of this intervention, and while long lists of undoubtedly ghastly crimes against the Kuwaitis are catalogued as substantiation, one is still forced to ask the question: why in Kuwait? The same atrocities, in even greater numbers, have been committed in a dozen other places, in some cases involving disregard for United Nations resolutions, and the nations which have gone to war with Iraq have not lifted a finger. The world is painfully aware of the daily deaths of thousands of children-as I mentioned, 40,000 children every year-from lack of food and clean water, and from a limited number of easily and cheaply preventable diseases.

The world is aware that the cost of addressing this vast, ongoing progression of human misery is a tiny fraction of the money already spent and still to be spent on the Middle East war. The war and the expense have only just begun. One cannot avoid the conclusion that it is not the human torture, it is not the denial of human freedom, it is not the human suffering and misery, and it is not the invasion of one country by another which has stimulated the response of the predominantly rich industrial countries; it is their heavy dependence on oil and the prospect of losing control of this vital commodity.

The environmental components of this new world order have not been mentioned. Yet only a few short months ago the newspapers were filled not with the pictures and stories of war but with accounts of environmental damage, of greenhouse warming, ozone depletion and the need for a drastic reappraisal of the profligate consumption of resources, especially energy resources, particularly oil, by the industrialised nations of the world. Growing Third World debt and the increased inability of poor country after poor country to ever repay its burden of debt was also being reported, as was the lower and lower quality of health, education, nutrition and housing being forced on nation after nation by world financial institutions more intent on debt recovery than social justice and human welfare.

These are not unrelated reasons for the present Gulf war. A solution to these problems must also be part of the new world order, if conflicts similar to the Middle East war are not to be a feature of the world for years to come. One fears, with good evidence, that these other factors are not in the mind of George Bush or Bob Hawke when they talk of a new world order. Having gloated-and we have seen it in this place-at the disintegration of the USSR and widely interpreted this as proof of the perfection of the capitalist system, an indefinite continuation of Western industrial dominance with its profligate and unequal share of resource consumption seems to be their vision of the new world order. Both the US and Australia have shown a particular unwillingness to address the problems of greenhouse. Australia has adopted a policy of 20 per cent reduction in greenhouse gasses by the year 2005, provided it does not have adverse economic consequences for the maintenance of the status quo.

The Government's document on ecologically sustainable development clearly indicates that it has no intention of changing its disastrous economic and ecological direction. Rather it pays lip service to a popular terminology and merely grafts onto existing practices those environmental protection elements which will not cost the economy a change of direction or purpose. The US has also resisted these international efforts to better manage the global environment in every case in which to do so may be seen in conflict with its continuing ability to exploit resources beyond its immediate control. The international law of the sea, Antarctic mining, more stringent greenhouse and ozone depletion standards are but a few examples.

The inter-governmental panel on climate control in May 1990 said that to cause the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere to stabilise, it was necessary that the release of this gas into the atmosphere be cut by between 60 and 80 per cent. The new plateau would still be some 50 per cent higher than the level which obtained at the start of the industrial era. But this sought-for reduction is merely a global average. Australia, with 0.3 per cent of world population, uses about 1 1/2 per cent of the world's fossil fuels. Hence our particular interest in the Middle East.

The reduction in greenhouse gas emissions required in Australia, if this country is not to indefinitely demand an unfair share of this precious resource, is much much higher than the average. It is 92 per cent. Similar reductions are required in the United States and other industrialised countries. Like constraints apply to consumption of other resources. The notion that the consumption of resources can continue to grow in conventional growth oriented economies is not consistent with the establishment of a sustainable relationship between the world's people and the environment on which they depend. The belief that the present level of consumption in industrialised countries can become generalised to all countries, much less even higher levels, is not only without foundation and against all evidence but also extremely dangerous.

There is another element in the old order which has led to the present conflict and which must not be repeated in the new. Nations of many sorts and political persuasions have sought to increase their economic strength and international influence by making and exporting arms to other countries. Arms manufacture has become a component of the economic productivity of many nations inextricably intertwined with every aspect of that economy. The world has been aware for perhaps 20 years of the abysmal human rights record of Saddam Hussein. Yet over most of this time many nations have been prepared to supply arms or the precursors of arms to Iraq. That has been well catalogued in the debates in this place.

The French supplied planes and the nuclear reactor, referred to earlier today, which the Israelis bombed. We may well have supplied the uranium which would have gone into that reactor had the Israelis not bombed the reactor first. The Russians supplied planes, tanks, and other military equipment. The Germans provided the makings of gas. Several European nations, as well as the United States, have supplied the materials which make poison gas, even after Hussein had used this gas against his own Kurdish subjects. Both the USSR and the French provided planes to the Iraqi air force to deliver its gas and other bombs.

I remind the Senate yet again that France is not a signatory to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and was in the process of building the reactor to which I referred a moment ago, thereby supplying the materials and the technology to manufacture nuclear weapons-something to which the Opposition devoted a great deal of attention during the earlier debate. Australia continues to supply uranium to France and other countries and, in our view, has unconvincingly argued that international agreements can guarantee that it would not finish up in Iraqi or other nations' nuclear bombs.

Australia has recently adopted an economic policy of greater dependence on arms exports. This is a deliberate policy, apparently, of the Hawke Government, at the national level, and the Bannon Government in my State of South Australia. It has deliberately adopted a policy of greater dependence upon arms manufacture and export and has set about building up what it euphemistically calls its `defence' industries. A world of increasing inequity-I refer back to one of the other elements that I have mentioned tonight-armed with ever more weapons of greater and greater sophistication is a world of increasing, not decreasing, world instability. It is a recipe for ensuring that the new world order is merely the old world order writ large.

The new world order must be based on a new economic model-a model not based on infinite growth and stimulated by competition, but on a steady-state sustainable and cooperative model. It must be a global economy that lives within the capacity of the global environment to indefinitely support the extraction of resources and the impacts of pollution which industrial and other human processes place on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I move on to my response to Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1990-91, I shall just take a few seconds to respond to the points advanced by the last speaker which dealt mainly with an attack on the support by the Government and the Opposition for the United Nations forces in the Gulf.
