How can we walk away from the naked aggression that we have seen by Iraq against Kuwait? How can we walk away from the opportunity to establish a rule of law internationally which may provide peace not for generations to come but for centuries to come? How can we ascribe a cost to that and then whine and whinge in the way in which we have heard from the Australian Democrats? How can we pervert the argument to say that it is all about oil? I happen to believe that it is about the establishment of a world order. But if Senator Coulter is asking me to support a madman controlling the majority of the world's oil supplies with the enormous consequences that it will have--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. That is gross misrepresentation. If the honourable senator had been in here and heard my speech, he would know that I was not at any time asking anybody to support Saddam Hussein.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order-it is not possible under Standing Orders for Senator Coulter to interrupt me or any other senator while speaking. If he feels that he has been misrepresented, he should wait until the senator has finished speaking.
—Senator Coulter, if you claim to be misrepresented, at the conclusion of Senator MacGibbon's speech you should seek leave to make a statement.

—Then we go on to the greenhouse effect and all the furphies about that. Had Senator Coulter any knowledge of physics and had he any knowledge of current research practices, he would know that the mathematical computer modelling for the greenhouse effect, in the same way as with Carl Sagan's nuclear winter scenario, has never been done. It is very unlikely, even with the massive computer resources we have in the world today, that the modelling could be done to prove or to disprove with any degree of certainty either the theory of the greenhouse effect or the nuclear winter. But this chamber is subjected to all this scare mythology and demonology in the name of a speech on the expenditure of money for the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate has before it Appropriation Bill (No. 3) which deals with many expenses amounting to about $234m. I want to talk about the consequences of Australia's participation in the Gulf and the consequential expenditure that has arisen from that. I want to make the comment, initially, that a large part of that expenditure, which is listed in the second reading speech as totalling $68.9m in aggregate over a period of years, of which $52.7m is brought to account in this additional appropriation, has been as a consequence of the lack of equipment in the Australian ships that have been sent to the Gulf.

There is a great deal to be learned, from a military point of view, about the operations in the Gulf and lessons from that will be learned for years to come. The really striking lesson for the Australian public, and the lesson is public, is how poorly Australia was prepared to support even the very small contribution we have made to the Gulf. That is the principal lesson. Despite the expenditure of nearly $8 billion a year on defence for a period of about seven or eight years under this Labor Government, we are left with the conclusion that the Australian defence forces are very poorly prepared for any active role in support of the United Nations and, more importantly, they are totally unprepared for any self-defence of Australia, which is the principal reason for their existence.

I am putting aside completely the level of training of the defence forces because we cannot hold defence forces at a very high level of training where its members are able to go into combat straightaway. That costs an enormous and quite disproportionate amount of money. I am excluding that from my comments here. The simple truth of the matter is that we do not have the range of capabilities within the Australian defence forces, in the three services, that we need. We certainly do not have the materiel support for those in weapons and munitions that we must have, both for an adequate level of training and for any sustainability. The war stocks held by the Australian services are quite minuscule and if we were to get into any situation where we had to use the defence forces, we would find that we were totally dependent on overseas sources for ammunition, missiles and things like that, which we would require in large quantities. As a consequence of that, we simply have no surge capability.

It should not be like that. Our expenditure is very low and I hope that this Government and the next government lift it from the 20 or 30 year record low of about 2.4 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) to a figure of at least 3 per cent of GDP, which is the barest minimum we can get by with in this country. Even for the 2.4 per cent, we are entitled to something more than we have in the direction of capability at present.

A few minutes ago I said that the Government made a very limited response to the United Nations force structure in the Gulf. There is no secret that the Government could have, and should have, done more. I am very interested in the role adopted by the Government, particularly by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in proposing the doctrine of proportionate response. The doctrine of proportionate response is something that is quite novel in international affairs, where the Government is saying that the response that Australia has made to the United Nations resolutions is proportionate to its size and importance in the world. That is the first time in history that a country has ever been involved in military operations where it has gauged its response in terms of its size and status in the world.

It is very interesting to go behind the scenes and ask how this formula arose. Who devised it? There is no precedent to go on. How was it determined that, for a country with 17 million people, four small warships was a proportionate response? It is very interesting and, of course, there are no answers coming from the Government. There are no answers coming-and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, who is sitting at the table will acknowledge this-because the Government is a prisoner of its left wing. The Government cannot do anything other than make a token contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Democrats.

—The Australian Democrats have no importance in influencing events. The Government is a prisoner of its own Left. I will briefly comment on the contribution that could be made by the three services to illustrate the point I am making. The Royal Australian Navy (RAN) response is adequate and appropriate because, principally, the removal of the Iraqi forces from Kuwait is not a maritime operation. It is worth emphasising that of all the ships in the Royal Australian Navy, out of the 16,000-odd members of the Royal Australian Navy, the total contribution we could make to a hostile situation was only four ships out of the fleet. That is the only number that we could put into a hostile environment, and then only after the expenditure of most of the money that is listed in this Appropriation Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the expenditure of $52.7m that is called up in this Bill went to equip those four ships, first of all, with the Phalanx close-in weapons system; secondly, to put in adequate communications systems so that they could properly operate with the American ships; thirdly, with navigational equipment. There was a bit of minor expenditure for things like chemical warfare kits, but in terms of the sums involved for the other three-the close-in weapons system, the navigation and the communications gear-that was quite minuscule. Those ships are playing a very important role for the United States and they are doing what they are designed for. They are basically designed to be escort ships in a carrier battle group and they fulfil that role very well.

It would be a very different circumstance if Australia were relying on the RAN for its own defence because those ships do not have the ability to stand alone in a hostile situation without the support of a large group of ships around them. That is because this Government, with the abandoning of the Fleet Air Arm, has reduced the Navy to a brown water navy where it simply cannot operate in a hostile air environment unless it is protected by friendly air support. I do not see how we are going to get over that situation in the short term; overcoming that is a very long term problem.

The Air Force does not have any role in the Iraq contribution thanks to the limitations that the Government has put on our contribution. But there is a very good argument to be made for contributing the F111s, the photographic ones, the RF111s, one of the F18 squadrons probably and the P3s if there was a maritime reconnaissance role. The Air Force could have made an effective contribution. If we get back to the point I am emphasising-the inability of the Australian Defence Force to do much in the self-defence of Australia-we find the Air Force is very severely restricted.

The first restriction comes from the fact that we have no way of knowing what is going on in the air space over Australia. We have only got very limited radar coverage and that is mainly on an arc from Adelaide round to Brisbane, in the south-east corner, which is the area most remote from any incursion into this country. The only response the Government has made to this is to proceed to let the contract last month for Jindalee over-the-horizon radar. That will be an eight to 10 year program before it is operational, if it is ever fully worked up to an operational mode. The present Jindalee station is a test facility. It is a research facility which is well down the path to being operational but it is not completely there yet.

In a stand alone role for air space surveillance Jindalee has a limited value. Although it is a wide area coverage system, it has some inherent and unavoidable faults with it-deficiencies, to put it more precisely.

For the Government to embark on Jindalee as the only way of surveying what goes on in the air space around Australia is to be repeating the mistakes that the French made between the First World War and the Second World War. We run the risk of creating an electronic Maginot line and, like the Maginot line, it has got two characteristics. First of all, it costs an enormous amount of money-it will cost about $1 billion to put two stations in, for which there may have been a higher priority in defence expenditure and, secondly, as the Maginot line was outflanked by the Germans going through Belgium and around the end of it, it can be argued that Jindalee could be outflanked by going around it in an electronic sense. Until we know what is going on in the air space, the Australian Defence Force does not have a chance of being able to use those excellent, air-superiority aircraft, the F18s, that we have.

It is a matter of some pride to me that the aircraft that is doing particularly well, along with the F111s, in the Middle East combat is the F18. I remember the time before that contract was signed for the new tactical fighter in 1981 in this Parliament. I was the only person who argued the case for the F18 against the F16. The F16's performance, reliability and operational capability in the broadest sense has been one of the disappointments of the otherwise very successful air war in the Middle East.

We do not have any support in missile stocks, the war stocks that we need for our strike aircraft to be able to use them in a role. The F111s that Australia has are excellent aircraft, they will do everything that the American F111s and the Stealth F117s will do from a weapons delivery point of view. Of course, they do not have the radar invisibility or the low radar signature of the F117s, but they are equipped with the same target acquisition, illumination and guidance system in the Pavetack system that the Americans have. We have very few missiles available for training. We have no war stocks at all-the GBU15 or the AGM130-which are the sort of weapons we need to utilise this capability. We are also very short on any electronic warfare capability. That means that in a hostile environment we do not have the electronic counter measures that we should have.

It is one of the deficiencies of this Government's policy that although they put the radar warning system into the F111s quite a few years ago they never proceeded to do the same with electronic counter measures. That is something that must be done. We also need things like the Harm missile, the high speed anti-radiation missile, so that we are able to remove defensive radars. We have the nucleus of great capabilities within the Air Force, but we also have major deficiencies which limit its use.

The Army has suffered enormously from the Whitlam doctrine of no threat, a 10-year warning time and the low-scale incursions which have been written up so heavily over the years. While we have very high professional capabilities in the officers of the Australian Army and a very high degree of training and readiness in the Third Brigade, the Operational Deployment Force in Townsville, we have an army which has very limited capabilities. It is an army that we cannot commit to the Gulf in any major operational role because it is a light infantry army. It does not have any armour; it does not have any artillery; it has none of the engineering units to the degree needed to support an armoured division or even a brigade. The Army has been reduced to a very low level land warfare capability, the consequence of a doctrine of the low level incursions. The Army has been told repeatedly by this Government that it has to worry about a couple of hundred nomadic guerillas who will come into the country with sacks of rice on their backs and a couple of packs of ammunition. This has been the consequence of the no threat for 10 years and the low level incursions.

It has had a very disastrous and debilitating effect on the capability of the Australian Army. Army lecturers talk about the essential nature of having mobility, fire power and flexibility. But sadly, as a consequence of this Government's policy, the Australian Army has none of those capabilities to the degree it should. The essential point I am making here is the inappropriateness of the policies that this Government has followed with respect to the defence forces, and the Gulf situation has exposed those very dramatically.

One of the basic causes of all this has been the strategic basis paper. Australian Governments of all political persuasions, since a short while after the Second World War, have called for a strategic basis paper to be prepared roughly every decade, or maybe as short as six or eight years on some occasions. In the strategic basis paper various experts try to define what threats Australia might face in the next decade.

The strategic basis paper then leads to a White Paper. The last White Paper entitled the Defence of Australia was published in 1987. The tragedy of those two documents is that they are not accurate. They cannot be accurate with the best will in the world. They are like a Queensland railway timetable; they are a guide to what might happen. They demand a forecasting ability from people who, although they may know a great deal about the subject, simply cannot predict with the degree of accuracy that is required to plan a force structure. The Government then takes the current paper on the Defence of Australia and says to the three Services, `That is how the structure of your three Services will be from now on; go to it'. It is not as simple as that.

If we look back at history we see that no strategic basis paper for Australia ever foresaw the communist terrorist incursions into Malaya-as it was then; no strategic basis paper ever foresaw Indonesian confrontation with Sukarno; and no strategic basis paper foresaw Vietnam, let alone Fiji, and least of all Kuwait. The point has to be hammered that while the strategic basis papers and the Defence of Australia document give a reasonable argument of what might happen, they must not be taken as holy writ. The very sad thing is that when one talks to the senior officers in all three Services, one finds that they all accept the Defence of Australia paper as holy writ-something that cannot be challenged or departed from. One cannot live that way; one gets caught out because circumstances are unpredictable.

The other problem with the Defence of Australia paper is that it inevitably has a degree of ambiguity in it. It is capable of interpretation in several different ways. While there is a good case to be made for having strategic basis papers-and I think we would be very foolish not to have them-and for having a White Paper on defence, the basic position that a government must adopt is to attain a level of professional competence in a range of abilities in all three Services; that is, to run a professional service not slanted, as the Australian Army is for example, towards low scale insurgencies.

It is inevitable that geography and circumstance will create a little bias one way or the other; for example, we might do things quite differently in Australia from the way that Switzerland does them because, for one thing, if we lived in Switzerland we would not have a navy. But the basic point must be that there has to be a range of professional skills in all three services so that when the unusual and unexpected arises it can be coped with.

The point of all of this is that we have to do better. We are not doing very well in the Defence Force at present, despite the expenditure of a considerable amount of money. The Bill before us today shows that $52.7m has to be expended to put three ships in the task force at a time in the Gulf and illustrates the shortcomings of the present capabilities of the Australian Defence Force, which is as a consequence of this Government's policy.

We had to spend a great amount of that money on equipment that should have been in those ships as part of their normal complement. I have been told for years by the Royal Australian Navy that the moment one of our tier one ships slips away from the dockside at Garden Island and sails it is ready for war. Quite obviously, when this degree of expenditure has to go into the close in weapon systems and the communications systems, then when the test comes, it is not true. Most of the other expenditure that has been involved in the Gulf deployment could arguably be offset against normal training commitments of peacetime steaming and exercise time. Basically, the real increase comes from putting essential equipment into those ships that was not there. I believe we can do better and we must do better. We can get better value for money than we are at present, and that is the point that I wish to make tonight to the Senate in relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 3).

—Yes.
—The honourable senator may proceed.

—I claim that the previous speaker knowingly asserted that my position was one thing, when in fact it was quite a different position. Of course, it is a very old debating trick-probably well known to the Neanderthal man, I would think-to assert a position which one could defend rather than to take up the actual issue. Specifically, Senator MacGibbon asserted that my position, according to the speech which I had just given, was that I would take no action against Saddam Hussein. That is not true.
