SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Senate is aware, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1990-91 seeks a further appropriation from the Consolidated Revenue Fund of $234.1m for this financial year. The need for this amount, of course, is directly related to the consequences arising from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait six months ago. Under the circumstances, the Australian Democrats do not dispute the urgency which surrounds the passage of this Bill, or the need to make an advance of the Additional Estimates to meet urgent expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: A great many countries which took part in the United Nations (UN) sponsored economic and trade sanctions against Iraq did so in the firm belief that in time these sanctions would have eventually forced Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Unfortunately, as we have seen, the economic sanctions applied against Iraq to protest the illegal occupation of Kuwait were never really given a chance to run their full course. The irony is that for the first time in the history of the United Nations full and comprehensive sanctions were invoked by the Security Council with wide international support from a majority of nations.

On the two previous occasions when sanctions were organised by the UN Security Council-that is, against Southern Rhodesia in 1966, and an arms embargo against South Africa in 1977-there was nowhere near the same level of international support or indeed cooperation for the sanctions to succeed. As we saw, the sanctions imposed on Iraq had no parallel in the history of the United Nations. Unlike previous occasions, the sanctions imposed on Iraq were actually being enforced.

As we have seen in the case of South Africa, sanctions do work but, in order for them to do so, the world must be patient and not rush into war as has happened with Iraq. The current boycott covers virtually all of Iraq's trade. This is three to four times greater coverage than in all previous successful sanctions cases. Beyond that, Iraq-geographically isolated and dependent on oil for 90 per cent of its export revenue-is far more vulnerable to economic coercion than target states in other sanctions cases.

Australia, of course, has played an active role in supporting the UN sanctions against Iraq. The Democrats have stated many times that we would have preferred to have seen sanctions remain rather than embarking upon this catastrophic and tragic military confrontation. The Bill before us tonight provides for a special payment to be made by the Government to meet those insurance claims resulting from Iraq defaulting on credit sales of the Australian Wheat Board.

It is now a matter of history that Iraq discontinued payments on virtually all of its trade with the outside world following the imposition of sanctions in August of last year. We must accept the sad reality that to take the responsible action of joining in the imposition of sanctions against a regime which is guilty of breaching international law, as Iraq is, involves financial loss to those countries like Australia which join in that economic blockade.

The Democrats, of course, are of the strong belief that Australia and other responsible members of the international community should join together in many more cases to impose economic sanctions against those regimes which are guilty of breaching international law and standards, as Iraq has been. In the past, the Democrats have pointed out how other countries are also guilty of illegally invading and occupying their weaker neighbours, but no penalty has been imposed and certainly no economic sanctions were applied. It is little wonder that many countries and groups in our community are now calling into question the double standards that exist when we choose to forcefully punish countries like Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait while at the same time ignoring the illegal invasions and occupations that occur in other parts of the world. In the examples of East Timor, Tibet, Lebanon and Cyprus, no such international effort to apply total and comprehensive sanctions to punish the invader were organised.

In fact, I have only recently received strong representations from the Cypriot community in Australia arguing that to forcefully punish Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait while ignoring the Turkish invasion of Cyprus in 1974 reflects poorly on the selectiveness with which the international community often chooses to act. In both cases an illegal invasion and occupation took place, and in both cases we find that the aggressors were guilty of an incredible number of human rights abuses. What the Democrats are arguing for is an equal application of international action when illegal aggression takes place.

Accordingly, we would like to see economic and trade sanctions also applied against countries such as Turkey until they comply with United Nations Security resolutions-resolutions such as 353 of 1974 and 550 of 1984 concerning Turkey's illegal occupation of the northern half of Cyprus. To ignore this double standard merely underlines the injustice which has been committed against the Cypriot people.

I have also heard much recently, particularly in this chamber, about the way in which Iraqi soldiers committed numerous atrocities against the Kuwaiti people and that this justified the military option being used. It has been argued that human rights abuses should not be tolerated and that the world needs to stand up to these abuses when they take place. I wish this were the case, but it is patently not. If it were, we would be imposing economic sanctions against dozens of countries.

A mere glance at the recent annual reports from Amnesty International will show that Iraq is not the only ogre in the world today. In fact, I am again reminded of the Turkish invasion of Cyprus in 1974 where outrageous atrocities were committed against the Cypriot people by the advancing Turkish soldiers. Many of these abuses were not dissimilar in fact to the ones which Iraqi soldiers committed against the Kuwaiti people.

I understand that during the Turkish invasion of Cyprus Turkish soldiers systematically went from village to village throwing babies from balconies while on the pavement below other soldiers waited with bayonets fixed in an apparent contest to see who could get the baby first. Following the Turkish invasion, the Cypriot Government was also obliged to change the laws governing abortion because so many women from the northern part of the island had been raped by soldiers of the invading Turkish army. Again, I understand that any woman between the ages of 12 and 80 was considered fair game by the Turkish soldiers.

According to Amnesty International, Turkey today has one of the worst human rights records of all nations. Since 1980, there have been more than one-quarter of a million prisoners of conscience jailed in Turkish prisons. Torture and ill treatment of prisoners of conscience are absolutely routine. In addition to this, we have the situation where the Turkish Government is guilty of widespread suppression of minorities, in particular the Kurds and the Armenians.

I raise this example of Turkey's human rights record and of its invasion of Cyprus to show that the world often does not act in the same way as it has done in the case of Iraq, and to point out to the Senate that the imposition of sanctions as an option in the past has been applied very selectively. On the one hand, the world imposes sanctions against Iraq in protest at its invasion of Kuwait and for its human rights abuses and, on the other hand, we refuse to countenance the possibility of imposing sanctions against Turkey for its invasion of Cyprus-and it is still there.

There are many other instances such as this one which I could point out; for example, Syria's brutalisation of Lebanon and the outrageous human rights abuses that take place under that regime. The awful irony is that both Turkey and Syria, guilty of the same crimes as Iraq, are now part of the allied military action in the Gulf and stand to be handsomely rewarded when the war is over. We find today that the United States (US) and its allies, including Australia, Japan and Germany, are expected to reward both Turkey and Syria when this war ends. In fact, the rewards have already started to flow and include both financial and economic inducements and contracts for the part that Turkey and Syria have played in siding with the allies during this war. We find this totally unacceptable.

Only last year, during the seventy-fifth anniversary at Gallipoli, the Australian Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) agreed to strengthen trade ties with Turkey, when we should instead be looking at ways to apply pressure on Turkey. We should be lobbying the United States and our other friends in Europe to possibly impose the same wide-ranging sanctions against both Turkey and Syria until they both get out of Cyprus and Lebanon respectively-until they both stop committing human rights abuses regularly. In this case the cost may be great to the governments of the world but there is a principle, and future generations will ask us why we acted so selectively.

One other aspect of this Bill before us arises from the fact that Australia alone seems to be bearing an unfair cost for its part in imposing sanctions against Iraq. I understand that when Iraq invaded Kuwait last year, Iraq was in the process of authorising payments totalling $2.8m to the Australian Wheat Board to cover part of the shipments of wheat already delivered. I am advised that this payment was to be via the United States, but on the same day the payment was to be made the US Administration froze all Iraqi assets in the United States. We would have thought that this freeze on Iraqi assets was intended to stop Iraq having access to funds and not designed to prevent other countries receiving money due to them from Iraq, particularly friends of the United States such as Australia. Why is it then that the United States Treasury has continued to refuse to release that $2.8m owed to the Australian Wheat Board by the Iraqi Government? Why is this money still in the US banking system?

It seems to the Democrats that this contrasts quite dramatically with the speed with which the US Congress approved special supplementary payments to be made to Turkey, Egypt and Israel for their loss of trade due to the war. I note that one recent Australian university study estimated that the American subsidies cost Australian wheat farmers as much as $336m in 1987-88. This is at a time when the Australian Wheat Board estimates $115 a tonne as the price Australian farmers are likely to receive for their wheat this year-the lowest in real terms for 50 years. Now we have the situation where changes in American agricultural policy will force that price even lower. This is where the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has calculated the return to Australian wheat growers would be $115 a tonne, even without the trade war. I raise these matters to demonstrate that the Australian economy is suffering much more because of this war than this Bill implies.

Mr Acting Deputy President, the Democrats will be supporting this Bill because we see a very clear distinction between the political decision to send troops to war-with which we disagree-and the reality of supporting those troops in their own defence while they are in a war zone. We have always supported sanctions. We urge the Government to again study the possibility of calling for sanctions on other regimes around the world where human rights abuses and invasions have taken place. Saddam Hussein is a vicious bully who must be stopped. He is not the only one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1990-91. This Bill seeks to appropriate from Consolidated Revenue a sum of $234.1m. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in placing those trade sanctions on Iraq that we have heard so much about this evening, is finally doing something about lifting some of the burden which has been placed on Australian trade. The Prime Minister did declare at the time that not one section of Australia would suffer the consequences of the trade sanctions.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is only a beginning in the replacement of the trade and the income lost by Australian industries. All trade sanctions-those proposed by the Australian Democrats especially-come at a cost. As I have already said, Australia is only now starting to pay for the loss in trade. Through this Bill, we are starting to pay for the expenses that have been run up in actually sending forces to the Gulf. That comes to approximately $52.659m. Of course, the loss of wheat sales to Iraq is a larger figure than that.

This Bill provides for a payment of $181.4m to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce to meet the insurance claims on the non-payment for wheat sold to Iraq that had been insured under the national interest provision of the Australian Trade Commission Act. This is not before time. We all know from what has been said already in this debate today, and yesterday in the House of Representatives, that the Australian wheatgrowers are suffering badly at present because of depressed prices that are not only the result of depressed pool payments and the non-payment of proceeds from Iraq sales, but also the trade war between the United States and the European Common Market. I will return to this later.

I was intrigued by Senator Bourne's remarks that we should have stayed with the trade sanctions which would have finally worked. She went on to contradict herself when she said that trade sanctions fall unevenly on people in Australia. I agree with the latter statement but I could not put the two together. I believe that trade sanctions in South Africa have failed. Other people may think differently. However, even after 20 years trade sanctions have not worked.

As I have said, this Bill appropriates moneys to meet claims by the wheat industry but further payments will be required later on. That is by no means the end of the story. I believe that there will be a further claim of $247m towards the end of June, some more claims in 1991-92 and, finally, a claim of $34m in 1992-93 to help wind up the pools of wheat sold as far back as 1987.

Twenty per cent of the total sales was not insured at all because in practice only 80 per cent of credit sales are insured. Someone has to pick this up. I know who is picking it up at present-the Australian wheat farmer, the businesses that rely on those farmers, all the downstream industries and the suppliers of imports such as chemicals and fertilisers, and rail transport. They are all suffering.

On the basis of an uninsured figure of 20 per cent, I have worked out that $123m is missing. I hope that in due course the Prime Minister will come up with something to enable farmers to recover that money. There has been a lot of talk about this gap of about $123m but no-one has come up with an answer yet. Mr Kerin, along with the Prime Minister, was certainly quick to tell us that we would not want the burden of sanctions to fall on one industry alone. So I am waiting for either the Prime Minister or Mr Kerin to come and tell us what they have in mind.

Senator Bourne pointed that $A3.5m is frozen in the United States. Prior to the beginning of sanctions, Iraq was in the process of making payments to Australia via its assets in America. As all honourable senators well know, when sanctions were applied Iraq ceased paying any accounts. But this one, which was already in the pipeline, was frozen along with other assets of Iraq in the United States. I put on record my disappointment-and, of course, the industry's disappointment-that a friendly nation like the United States did not let that money flow through. I know that it is only $3.5m, but that figure would represent a reasonable amount per tonne extra that could be paid out into the pool.

I know from reading different media releases that the United States Government allegedly paid money out of some frozen funds to its own farmers or businessmen, as the case may be, and kept frozen the Australian finances that should have come through. I am very disappointed and I believe that this Government should keep up pressure on the United States Government to let that $3.5m through. As I have said before, it is not a great amount but certainly it would be better in Australian wheatgrowers' accounts than being left frozen in the United States.

I move on to what the Australian Wheat Board had to say as late as 21 January 1991. I refer to an article in the Canberra Times of 23 January 1991 which had a rather optimistic outlook on payments that are still to come out of Iraq-an optimistic view that I do not have at present. The article reads as follows:
The Australian Wheat Board said yesterday that it remained confident that Iraq would honour its wheat debts and remain an important customer for Australian wheat.
Iraq had always honoured its business agreements-
and I do not deny that-

with the board in difficult times and depended on Australia as a major long-term supplier, a spokesman said yesterday. It was important that wheatgrowers understood all the factors that had contributed to the disastrous returns they were facing.

Perhaps the Australian Wheat Board used that as a palliative to lead wheatgrowers into believing that funds would flow through later on at a faster rate. But certainly with the destruction that is going on in Iraq, I think that it will be a long time before that country will again be a big customer or even be able to pay for past sales. I mention that in passing because I normally believe that the Australian Wheat Board truly represents its industry. But I do not quite share its optimistic outlook in this case. Of course, while we hear about the wheat loss that we have suffered and the non-payment for sales that have been made, quite a few forgotten items are not mentioned very often.

As well as the loss of the premium wheat trade, by which we exported approximately $391.5m in 1989-90, we also lost the live-sheep trade to Kuwait and that resulted in a loss of $30.9m. I suppose the end of the live-sheep trade from Australia to the rest of the world may be music to the ears of one party in this place, that is, the Democrats, but if they think that, they may be in for a big disappointment. When trade with South Africa eventually resumes, it will take up quite a bit of the slack that has been lost. A sum of $30.9m has been lost in that trade. That was the amount for 1989-90. We also exported $18.1m worth of cereals in 1989-90 to Kuwait and that also has been lost.

As a result of the action in the Gulf, our losses do not stop there. The reverse situation applies with imports into this country, that is, the products needed to help grow wheat and other cereals. For example, increased petroleum prices worldwide have pushed up the expenses incurred by farmers and other industries, such as transport, as well as for motorists. A 0.1c jump in prices paid at the petrol bowser represents a $22m growth in farm fuel bills. I will repeat that. A 0.1c rise at the pump means that Australian farmers pay $22m more for fuel in the course of a year. That is a massive figure.

Of course fuel costs are a major part of total farm costs and cereal growers are paying at least 12 per cent more for their imports. Excise payments to the Government, based on higher crude oil prices, have increased. For every $US1 increase per barrel in the price of oil, the Federal Government takes another $70m per year. I do not have any pangs of conscience about supporting this Appropriation Bill. The Government has to make up this insurance shortfall because of the windfalls it has had. I know the world price of oil has reduced from the peak of around $US42 a barrel in the early days of the imposition of sanctions. The oil prices receded once the conflict started but they have stabilised at a higher figure than was around at this time last year.

I believe the windfall to government in one financial year could be around $800m. It has been mooted that it could be $500m in the balance of this financial year. If oil prices averaged $US29.24 a barrel over one financial year, farmers would pay $180m more in fuel costs, resulting in a cut of 12 per cent in farm income. At present the average farm income-I think this figure was estimated a month ago-is only $5,500 or just one-fifth of the average Australian earnings.

Further to that, increased petroleum prices have lifted the cost of sea, land and air transport around the world. We rely on both sea and air transport to export our products from Australia. In the case of sea transport, no-one can tell me it is the buyer of the freight who pays for its transport. The buyers may pay, but it is actually deducted in the original contract, in which allowance is made for it. The same applies to horticultural produce, a great deal of which is air-lifted out of Australia. This will cause a vast increase in the cost to horticultural producers. For example, virtually all produce from the Kununurra area in Western Australia, which is better known as the Ord River scheme, is air-lifted to the eastern States, to Singapore or to places like that. Increased petroleum prices will have a great bearing on the producers there. I could go on and deal with matters such as insurance premiums on shipping in a world in conflict. I could add various examples, but I do not intend to take up too much more of the time of the Senate this evening.

Australian farmers are in severe recession and now wheat growers face further problems as a result of the loss of one of their major commodity markets. At a later date, the Government, as I said, could ease the problem by returning to the agricultural sector some of its windfall gains from the increases in fuel prices, in addition to what is provided under this Bill, of course. The Government could really spread the cost of those United Nations sanctions around. As I said earlier, the cost of those sanctions should be spread throughout the community, as the Prime Minister promised in the first place.

Rather than helping in monetary terms, the Government could help the wheat industry by taking up the idea of a trade mission to the United States. That was suggested by my leader, Dr Hewson, in the House of Representatives today. He suggested the Government should send a high level trade mission or negotiating party to the United States and to all the governments of countries in the European Community. Perhaps that would bring some sense into the trade war in wheat which is currently going on between those countries. Wheat is not like wool. We will be debating wool in the next few days. We have a massive overproduction of wool in Australia but that does not apply to the wheat industry. The wheat industry does not have a debt around its neck as the wool industry does. In fact, the wool industry will probably finish up with a debt in the order of $3.5 billion by the end of this season. The wheat industry, by contrast, is very efficient but it has been forced down to probably the most basic figure per tonne at which Australian wheat growers could hope to stay in production, and that is roughly $120 per tonne.

In a press release today the Prime Minister said that he would consider seriously supporting the coalition's proposal to send a bipartisan delegation to the United States to protest against wheat growing export subsidies. I believe that in that way the Government could, with very little effort at all, put a greater return into the pockets of Australian wheat growers and, as I mentioned earlier, the downstream industries which depend on them and supply them. If the Australian Government could convince overseas governments to stop this ridiculous trade war, which no-one will win in the long run, it will help put this trade back onto an even keel.

If Australian wheat growers could secure just $30 per tonne, I believe they would be put back into a reasonably good position. Most of them are also woolgrowers. I know from research and decisions I have made in other places that one can expect no profit from wool for at least five years. Hopefully at the end of that time the industry will be restructured and will be back in the position it held previously in Australia. I think it will then contribute to the welfare of Australia as it did in the past. However, wheat could be put into that situation with very little effort if the proposed delegation of the Prime Minister and Dr Hewson can talk some sense into the governments I mentioned. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that what we are doing here tonight is repeating a mistake that has been made over decades in the approach this world has had to a number of the problems it has been faced with. It seems that here we go yet again trying to solve a problem by throwing money at it. I would have thought that our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) would have been chastened recently at the World Council of Churches in relation to the suggestion that throwing money at a problem had any possibility of solving it. That attitude has been demonstrated over recent years to have been a fallacy. It is an old attitude, an attitude which was reflected in Senator MacGibbon's contribution. As a preamble to his speech he expressed the attitude that the theory of greenhouse could not be proven through mathematical modelling. He said that because he was obviously concerned about Senator Coulter's contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: As a preamble to what I have to say, I would like to address the attitude displayed in Senator MacGibbon's statement. In fact, practical observations have already demonstrated by measured increases in global temperatures both of the atmosphere and of parts of the oceans that something is changing in those atmospheres and oceans. I was fortunate enough recently to visit the Scripps Institute of Oceanography in California, where I saw both direct and tangible evidence of these changes, and a variety of models-the models which were scoffed at and perhaps not even understood by Senator MacGibbon-which I saw demonstrated by eminent leaders in physics and oceanography. These models attempted to evaluate the potential effects of global warming.

The trouble with pedestrian thinkers such as Senator MacGibbon is that it is difficult for them to extrapolate, to move from the known to the unknown, and to imagine anything other than that which is self-evident and immediately apparent. Such thinking belongs to the category of `I'll believe it when I see it'. That sort of thinking was also expressed in statements made by a few of Tasmania's civil engineers at a conference held in Hobart in 1988. The conference, Greenhouse 88, had to suffer the contributions of such mental plodders, whose best efforts were statements such as, `When the sea level has risen by one metre I will believe that the greenhouse effect exists'.

Such thinkers are unable to imagine the dramatic effects which would result from a fractional increase in world ambient temperatures-possibly such things as the potential shifting of the roaring forties, which is of particular relevance to Tasmanians. Other effects might be the redirection or even the complete disintegration of the gulf stream drift-and I mean the other gulf. I refer to potential effects such as the increased salinity of the waters of our Great Barrier Reef; the southward shift of the Melanesian monsoons; and the interruption, exaggeration or even failure of the El Nino effect. That is something with which Senator Panizza should be concerned, because it is that very effect which brings great variations to the otherwise dependable climate upon which our wheat growing industry depends.

The immense economic, social and environmental consequences of any of these events are things which vary. They are not predictable at the moment but are questionable. These are things which very few people have shown any willingness to consider, and they remain misunderstood and in the category of the unknown. In medieval times, when people did not understand something or did not want to understand it, they saw it as sorcery, mumbo jumbo or the work of the devil and then recoiled in horror. We can no longer afford such childish attitudes. We have a responsibility to explore, to chart if possible and to modify the effects of our actions. But at the moment we are not seriously accepting that responsibility. We are busily engorging ourselves in primitively violent attempts at resolving our problems. We spend huge amounts of energy, make huge physical and social efforts, and make huge investments of intellect and research just to add a technological gloss of sophistication to the primitive arguments we have been conducting over resources for thousands of years.

Senator Coulter was particularly concerned to show in his speech that, if we were to spend but a fraction of our wasted and entirely misguided military spendings on the resolution of the problems we have due to the unequal distribution of our planet's wealth, the freedoms, liberties, entitlements and heritages that we claim to be fighting for could be more equitably shared anyway. It is my belief and the belief of a number of other people who consider the future of society on our planet that resource wars of a number of types are possible if not likely in the future. They are even more likely now because of the investments we have made in establishing military industries and selling military goods to each other, and in selling those goods across all ideologies and religions and across all traditional rivalries, so that those who in the future are desperate for energy, food or mineral resources will be capable of using military hardware to pursue their claims for a share of the planet's resources.

But what do we do? We sit here as witnesses to our pathetic inability to devise and use an economic system which can equitably share our resources. We need a new world attitude. We certainly do not need a new world order, but we do need a new world attitude-one which enables us to distribute our resources equitably and to divide the products of our labours, whether they be primary industry products, manufactured items or whatever. All people are entitled to be rewarded for their efforts and, as Senator Panizza would agree, no particular section of our community should have to suffer penalties as a result of community or government decisions made on their behalf. The problem with the present world attitude-and this is a cliche for which I apologise-is that it is bound up with the attitude of `might is right'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a cliche.

—Yes. I do apologise for that, but it seems that pedestrian thinking generates such cliches, and we are bound in it. I am dismayed that, with the emergence in the Middle East of a problem which had been manifested by an attempt to establish military superiority by the Iraqi regime, we were incapable of recognising that at our very feet, at the very instant that that happened, with the dissolution of the Cold War arrangement of world affairs, we had the opportunity to demonstrate the good purposes to which our technological advancements had brought us.

SPEECH.PARA: We had the opportunity to use the technological superiority which some people would have been pleased to see expressed in air power and the capability of delivering ordnance from one place to another, but that capability was also able to bring to the supervision of the United Nations sanctions something which had not existed before, something which had been lacking in other attempts to enforce sanctions. I refer to worldwide cooperation in communications, information sharing and surveillance. Therefore, the enforcement of sanctions came as close to 100 per cent foolproof as has ever been enforced in history, but we gave it less than five lousy months in which to succeed. We were unable to see the potential to bring about a new world attitude. We certainly need a new world attitude, one in which authority, fairness and good government do not depend on military superiority, financed by unequal resource exploitation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested in hearing Senator Bell's speech which, as Hansard will confirm, was laced with comments about other people being pedestrian, childish, and mental plodders-a term he used once, maybe twice. We may ask ourselves what entitles Senator Bell to use such disparaging comments about other people. Honourable senators may not know that at the conferences held by the Australian Democrats they have what are called RATO courses which entitle Democrats to rise above the ordinary. That seems to entitle people such as Senator Bell to go around casting aspersions on others. However, Senator Bell's speech did not rise above the ordinary, and I am sure that if he attends one of those courses he will fail.

SPEECH.PARA: There is some irony in the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) which is now before us. The Government policy on the Gulf conflict as set out in the resolution passed by this Parliament has received strong bipartisan support from the coalition. There are only two small groups who have opposed our national policy. These comprise the Australian Democrats and the socialist Left of the Australian Labor Party (ALP). These two groups, I regret to say, have in effect formed a coalition to oppose the national policy and our United Nations sanctioned forces in the Gulf. In my view, and I am pleased to say in the view of the vast majority of the Australian people, the Australian Democrats are completely out of touch not only with the national mood, but also with the supporters of their own political Party.

For the edification of some senators who may not have seen last week's Bulletin, I would refer them to an opinion poll that it took on the attitudes of various voters in political parties to the crisis in the Gulf. Senator Lees and Senator Bell may not be aware of that issue of the Bulletin, but I urge them to obtain it. They will see that in answer to the question, `Do you approve of Australia being part of the United States led forces?', just under two-thirds of those who typified themselves as voting for the Australian Democrats supported that proposition. In other words, it is nonsense for Senator Powell to lecture this Senate to the effect that a majority of the Australian people did not support the resolution that was before this Parliament, and Senator Powell's statement was backed up by her Senate colleagues. Not only was that statement untrue, but not even a majority of Senator Powell's own side supported the position of the Australian Democrats. As this debate continues Senator Bell, Senator Lees and their colleagues may well reflect on that matter. Not only are they out of touch with the national mood of this nation in what can be regarded as some type of national crisis, but they are out of touch with the mood of their own people.

It is one thing for the Australian Democrats to adopt a pacifist position, a policy which in my view effectively amounts to appeasement. It is quite another for sections of the Labor Party, the national Left or socialist Left, to adopt a similar policy. Members of the ALP national Left continue to enjoy the perks of office and at the same time oppose the policies of their own Government.

Senator Coates has been rather active in this chamber in opposing the war. He made a speech which clearly showed that he had a very strong pacifist position. I think that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was quite right to point out, and I am happy to support him, that the Labor Party has never been pacifist. Therefore, if Senator Coates is a pacifist, what on earth is he doing in the Labor Party?

It has been a relief in one sense to hear Labor Party members not ask dorothy dixers of Ministers, and we have had many of these questions in the short time I have been in this Parliament. It is interesting that Senator Coates now seems to be able to ask questions which clearly have not been passed out to him by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) or the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). Indeed, Senator Coates still enjoys the perks of government; he is the chairman of an important standing committee in this place.

It is bad enough, in my view, that those in the socialist Left or national Left, or whatever one wants to call them, not only oppose the Government's policy but, even worse, continue actively to campaign against Australia's commitment in the Gulf. It is one thing to say, `I do not accept what Mr Hawke, Mr Keating, Senator Button and Senator Evans are doing' and shut up about it-and I imagine that we can all cope with those matters of conscience-but this is not the case with the national Left. It is not the attitude of Senator Childs or of many people on the Left. They are actively campaigning against the policy of their Government while they continue to enjoy in some senses the perks of office. In my view, there are few more serious decisions that this Parliament has to make than that which commits a nation to war. But having made the decision to commit men and women in our armed forces to war, the public at large, and indeed the men and women of our defence forces, have the right to expect the Government on all occasions vigorously to defend its policy. It is of concern that at times the Government appears to allow the Labor Left to campaign vigorously against the national bipartisan policy on the Gulf crisis.

A divided party certainly undermines the Government's capacity to lead public opinion. Last week there was an interesting example of this. Senator Robert Ray was asked to comment on whether he agreed with a statement by Senator Childs-one of the leaders of the national Left-that the allies should hold back from further military operations in Iraq. He was asked a question regarding the attitude of Senator Childs of the ALP national Left.

It was most noticeable to everybody in this chamber that Senator Ray did not on this occasion actively defend his Government's policy. We certainly saw none of the vigour, none of the determination and, at times, none of the passion which Senator Ray uses in defending his Government's policy-indeed, a bipartisan policy-when he receives questions from Senator Powell and Senator Vallentine. One may ask: so what? Senator Ray is far too smart a man to be trapped into exacerbating Labor Party tensions in this chamber.

That is one view to put. But against that view one has to ask: what message does the Government give to the public at large? What message does it give to the members of the socialist Left, burrowing away, trying to undermine Government policy, when Senator Ray says very blithely in this chamber that dissent is a healthy thing? I can tell Senator Collins that I do not argue that dissent is a healthy thing. When a senior Labor Party backbencher attacks the national policy on this most vital issue, one can say that it is appropriate that we should have some dissent.

Senator Childs has the perfect right to put forward whatever anti-American and anti-Government views he wishes to express. But when he does do that-and this is the point-the public has a right to expect that a senior Minister will vigorously defend his Government's policy and expose the weaknesses and the contradictions of the socialist Left position. Senator Ray-who, I might say, by and large has been an effective spokesman for Government policy-to my mind, gave a very bad impression on this occasion to the Parliament and certainly gave a very bad impression to the public at large who may well have listened to the radio broadcast.

TALK.START.PARA: —He caved in.

—It is the usual compromise one gets in the Labor Party. At the end of the day, there are no principles which are worth standing up for and defending. That is the issue. It was a great pity that, on this very important issue, Senator Ray did not stand up and really expose the fallacies and the dangers to future world peace inherent in Senator Childs's position. Make no mistake about it, the socialist Left of the Labor Party is determined to undermine the national bipartisan policy.
—It is only half a bipartisan policy, isn't it?

—It is a bipartisan policy with, I am happy to say, a majority section of the Labor Party, but factional groups have broken away and joined with Senator Lees and her colleagues to oppose what is an important policy. This is what the Australian Labor Party national Left resolution says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government is not serving Australian interests by pursuing a War Policy.

This is what the colleagues of Senator Collins said. I would have thought the Australian Government was trying very hard by joining with the coalition forces to ensure a world peace, but this is the way that people like Senator Childs view the activities of the Prime Minister. This statement by the national Left was released on 10 February 1991.

This week, the parliamentary Left attacked what it calls the apparent `expansion of allied war aims'. This document was signed by Senator Bruce Childs, whose name regularly appears on all these activities, and Senator McKiernan. Another notorious member of the Labor Party, George Crawford, who happens to be a member of the Victorian upper House and convenor of the socialist Left-and here is a man who probably, in a sense, rode into office on the coat-tails of the Prime Minister and the organisational skills of Senator Ray--

TALK.START.PARA: —This isn't likely to pick up at all, is it?

—Senator Collins does not get up and defend his Government's policy at times either. This is an important point, so rather than being abusive he might listen. This is what Senator Collins's George Crawford said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . initiate a renewed international effort to secure an immediate ceasefire and a negotiated settlement of the Gulf crisis . . .
He said that Australians should be called upon:
. . . to mobilise against Australia's involvement in the Gulf war and join in activities organised by peace groups.

There is concern that prominent members of the Labor Party are becoming increasingly active in campaigning against the bipartisan national policy. A letter to all Labor Party members was sent out at the end of last month. This letter is entitled, `Labor for Peace in the Middle East'. We do not object to that; we are all for peace. The letter started off as Labor Party letters presumably used to, and I am surprised to find they still do, with `Dear Comrade'. I thought that term might have gone out recently. This is, again, signed by prominent members of the Victorian socialist Left-members of the Labor Party, the party of Senator Collins. The letter states:

In response to the deeply held feeling of outrage against the war being waged at the insistence of the United States in the Middle East-and the Hawke Government's rush to commit Australia to the war-a group of Labor Party members have moved to support the growing Peace Movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is room for more than one view.

—That is exactly what I have said. There is room for more than one view. But what we would like to hear from people like Senator Collins and his senior colleagues, when people in their Party cast aspersions-and, make no mistake, they are casting aspersions against a policy which has committed men and women to war-is a more vigorous defence of their policy. That is the point. No-one is arguing that Labor Party people have not got the right to say that. What we are arguing is that we want to see more activity on behalf of Ministers to ensure that the national bipartisan policy is effectively supported.

SPEECH.PARA: There was also a recent report in the Sun-Herald newspaper that an anti-war meeting was held in the office of the Victorian Department of Education. Why the office of the Victorian Department of Education-controlled by the socialist Left, again-is being used to hold anti-war meetings, I really do not know.

Senator Collins might pick this point up: if this conflict proves more long lasting than is currently expected-and we all hope it ends very soon-the activities of the socialist Left will make it more difficult to maintain the national bipartisan policy. The hypocrisy and double standards of the Left stand exposed in its failure to adequately condemn Iraq's barbaric behaviour.

The Senate will notice in the resolutions which the parliamentary Left and the national ALP Left regularly bring down that Israel has not been commended in any way for its courageous self-restraint in the face of Iraq's deliberate attempt to inflict maximum civilian casualties and damage through its Scud attacks and threats to unleash poison gas. Some 10,000 homes have been damaged or destroyed by the Scud missiles that have landed in Israel. Four people have been killed, hundreds severely injured, the country terrorised and its economy severely damaged by the effects of this war. Israel's precarious strategic environment and genuine security concern should be self-evident, even to its most callous critics.

Clearly, the prospect of any peace and stability in the Middle East depends on defeating the ruthless Iraqi tyrant, thereby strengthening the more moderate Egyptian-led elements in the Arab world which are giving the forces of moderation and democracy a chance to grow. As I said, there is an aspect of total hypocrisy in respect of the socialist Left in that there is no recognition at all of the restraint that Israel has shown in the wordy resolutions that it regularly releases.

Finally, I draw the Senate's attention to the allegations made by the Prime Minister and others regarding bias in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's reporting of the Gulf crisis. Even before the findings of the ABC were released, this report appeared in the Canberra Times of 11 February 1991:
A meeting in Canberra of the ALP national Left yesterday called on the Federal Government to begin a renewed international effort to end the Gulf war and-
this is the point-
dissociated itself from Mr Hawke's attack last month on the ABC's television coverage of the Gulf war.
The article continued:
Senator Bruce Childs said delegates felt the ABC was an independent body and that its war coverage had compared favourably with that of other television networks.

This was before the ABC launched an inquiry into the Prime Minister's allegation of bias by the ABC, which he was perfectly entitled to do. Before the results of that inquiry came out, Senator Childs said that his section of the Labor Party dissociated itself from the accusations of the Prime Minister. There was no study and no evidence. What does it matter that a large section of the Labor Party is actively campaigning against a policy which has committed this Government to war? It is incredible.

TALK.START.PARA: —You relate that to a charge of bias against the ABC. It is a policy of the Government. Stop talking such absolute rot.

—Senator Collins generally shows poor standards in this Parliament but I would have to say that that would be the lowest I have seen. The fact that Senator Childs came out and attacked the Prime Minister for his comments on the ABC regarding bias before the ABC had made a judgment shows the division that exists in the Labor Party. That is all right with Senator Collins, is it?
—Everybody in this chamber has a right to a view about bias. It is a very subjective matter.
—Is it okay for anybody in the Labor Party to tell the Prime Minister that he is speaking utter nonsense in relation to bias on the ABC? There are no problems with that?
—None at all.
—Terrific. That will be recorded in Hansard too.
—I hope it is.

—Order! I remind both of the interjectors in the chamber that Hansard is being kept very busy at the moment just trying to keep up with the interjections. I also advise the speaker not to speak directly to other people because he will get interjections. If he speaks through the Chair he might find he has an easier passage for the next 10 minutes.

—Thank you for your advice, Mr Acting Deputy President. I think I was responding to the interjections made rather than the reverse, as perhaps implied by your ruling. As I was about to mention, the ABC conducted an inquiry into the allegations by the Prime Minister. Not surprisingly, the ABC has tried itself and found itself innocent, despite a few shortcomings. The ABC report found that at times its reporting on the Gulf was excellent. Earlier press reports-and I do not know whether they are correct-suggested that there was no need for the ABC to even assess all of the evidence, to get all the tapes along, to have a close look and to subject itself to a rigorous analysis. There was no need, apparently, to call any of the outside critics who may have wished to put evidence before the ABC. Why not? Large numbers of people have said that they have found trouble with ABC reporting and that we should conduct an inquiry to seek the wider views of people. But that did not occur. It is interesting that people vigorously defended the ABC against the Prime Minister's charge of bias, including a number of pacifist groups as well as the socialist Left and the Australian Democrats. In short, if this investigation proved only one thing it was that the complaints procedure at the ABC needs to be dramatically overhauled.

SPEECH.PARA: I was pleased to hear from Senator Collins's colleague Mr Beazley, who does not quite agree with the approach that has been taken by Senator Collins tonight. Mr Beazley said that there were two possible options open to the Government. I hope there was not a third option which would be to do nothing. Mr Beazley canvassed two possible options. First, he suggested that there should be an outside independent mechanism to assess complaints. I suggest that it would be somewhat similar to having an ABC ombudsman. The second option would be to make the ABC subject to the rulings of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I happen to believe that the appointment of an ABC ombudsman would do much to restore public confidence in the ABC. Possibly there should be a parliamentary inquiry into which of the two options is most appropriate. This mechanism could possibly achieve a bipartisan position-I would not include Senator Childs and his colleagues in that-so that we had a proper, independent complaints procedure established for the ABC.

I received a hint at dinner tonight that Senator Cooney, whose opinions we always respect in this Parliament, may well be reflecting on the ABC and this debate and the allegations of bias. Just to make it very clear, because I am sure that Senator Cooney will make many cogent points, I am not calling for an inquiry into the ABC; I am calling for the Government to look at the possibility of, and hopefully carry through, a policy of establishing an independent complaints mechanism for the ABC.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a good idea.

—After three speeches in this Parliament Senator Collins has finally agreed with me. He is quite right; it is a very good idea. I hope the Government proceeds on those lines. I have expressed concerns about the willingness at times-and I do not say that it is all the time-of the Government to defend its policies. I hope that the Government will ignore its left wing and proceed to establish an independent complaints procedure for the ABC. I would have to say that a failure on this score would convince many people that once again the Government is compromising policy to accommodate the Left.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bias in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) has been much discussed in recent times. Senator Kemp, in his usual way, has put the case against it in the most lucid fashion. The allegations, amongst others, are that the ABC has treated Iraq's case too favourably and the allies not favourably enough. War engenders emotions and these make a poor basis for accurate judgment. Where balance lies, what is fair reporting and who should pass comment on the war are questions that different people, different interests, and different groups will answer in different ways. What to one person is a brilliant analysis of a particular issue is a shoddy diatribe to another. When we see bias, we often do so from a biased point of view.
—You would know.

—Well, I do know. If Senator Crane listens he will see that we are all affected by bias. If we are not affected by bias, we should not be in this chamber. Senator Crane put a particular case and I hope that he put it well. If Senator Crane is suggesting that he has been elected by the Liberal Party of Australia to come in here and not to present a case that would forward its fortunes, I suggest that he is not doing the fair thing by his Party. By his interjection, I take it that that is what he is suggesting.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of us have a background, a culture, beliefs, experiences and temperaments that give a particular bent to our view of the world. It is hard to think of anyone without an affinity with a particular way of life, without attitudes to things they encounter in the world around them, and without at least some beliefs to which they adhere. Good judges do hold opinions, do live according to particular philosophies, do practise the tenets of a specific faith, and do possess different attitudes to issues that arise in the community. What makes them good judges is the ability to decide a matter without these things warping their sense of fairness. That is not an easy achievement. However, they do have the help of powerful judicial traditions. They must hear both sides to a dispute and give judgment on the basis of the evidence and arguments that the parties put forward. They must give reasons for their decisions.

People who are not judges do not have these constraints in reaching a conclusion about a matter. Parliamentarians, including members of the Executive, can make pronouncements without going through a judicial process. They do not have to distance themselves from their beliefs, their emotions, and their deeply held attitudes about what goes on in the community. Accordingly, the conclusions that they draw are not guaranteed to be accurate or fair. The risk that parliamentarians and Ministers may run is that they draw conclusions flawed by a bent towards a particular point of view, an attitude or a belief for a political culture.

This is a matter of considerable concern because they determine what funding, if any, the ABC will receive. The ABC is guaranteed independence by legislation but much pressure can be exerted on that either by a specific threat to trim its budget or by a declaration of how its viability depends on the taxpayers' dollar. It is interesting that, in all of the arguments we have had about the ABC, there has been no suggestion that a challenge has been made to the duty thrown onto the Corporation, by legislation, to maintain its independence. Is it the desire and the proposition of those who now attack the ABC to introduce amendments to the legislation which gives it existence-to put in a clause which says that the ABC will always present the views of the majority, be those the views of the government of the day or the views of the opposition of the day, or that its time be shared out so that the Government gets a certain part, the Opposition gets a certain part and the Australian Democrats get a certain part? Is it suggested that in some way the political masters of this country, whether they be in government or in opposition, control the ABC? Is that the suggestion?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, just get the lot!

—From Senator Bishop's interjection, I understand that she wants to introduce legislation to subject the ABC to the will of the Parliament. If that is her position, that is a reasonable position to take up, and she should introduce legislation to see that that is done. If she does not want to introduce that legislation, what is she complaining about? She is complaining about the perception she has that the ABC is biased. If Senator Bishop gets up and puts forward that view, as Senator Kemp has fairly put it forward, that is her right in a democratic society and she should be listened to. But democracy does not consist of people agreeing to whatever the person or the party in power agrees to; democracy is the ability for all people to say what they want without fear of persecution. In that regard the Democrats and the Left of the Australian Labor Party have been much criticised for opposing the war.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that any war raises questions of doubt. I do not think that any people in this chamber, or others anywhere else, have gone into war with such conviction that they do not have some doubts about a war that brings about civilian deaths, that puts at risk allied soldiers, and that causes all types of disturbances in the Middle East. People may have doubt about that. Some people come down on one side of the argument and some people come down on the other side.

Surely to goodness war is not such an issue that people can come down and decide it one way without giving some respect to the truly held and conscientious beliefs of others. Surely we should be a nation so tolerant that we are able to have discussions in a proper and intellectual way. I think that the arguments that the Democrats, the left wing and Senator Vallentine present have much merit. To say that because we are at war the ability to argue, the right to debate and the entitlement to have a different view should be sacrificed is intolerable in a free and democratic society.

I shall just say something about the ABC and the way in which we treat it. It is one thing for someone without any ability to affect the resources of the ABC to rail against it; it is another for someone with that ability to do so. Members of the Parliament, whether on the front or the back bench, have a right to full debate. That is essential to the free society we enjoy. But we need to use our considerable rights in understanding what, in any particular case, they involve. In exercising our rights we should be careful not to diminish those legitimately held by others. The more distinguished the position we hold, the more considered we should be about the statements that we make about the ABC.

Indeed, this independence of the ABC has been upheld by many a distinguished person. I shall quote one of them, Mr John Howard, who previously led the coalition and who is now shadow Minister for industrial relations. On 5 May 1983 he said:

More than ever before Australia needs an independent, fearless, professional Australian Broadcasting Corporation. I would have thought that at the very least that is an issue on which this Parliament might be able to achieve a bipartisan attitude. Perhaps that is an issue on which the much sought after consensus between the Government and the Opposition might be achievable.
The Government is committed to maintaining the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's independent news service.
Mr Howard goes on to develop that theme further. About a year later, on 4 April 1984, Mr Howard said:

The Government has been willing to resort very readily to the cheap intimidation of an organisation which has always valued its independence and which has done a great service-often a discomforting service-to both sides of politics. Let nobody imagine that the Liberal Party has enjoyed some of the criticisms that have been made of it by the ABC. But the fact remains that through the years the ABC has been a worthwhile organisation in Australia. It has shown courage, it has shown independence and, frankly, that is what the Prime Minister cannot really abide.

We have, six years later, a considerable change of heart on the part of the Opposition which seems to have departed from those great principles that rang so clearly from the mouth of Mr Howard representing, as he then did, the position of the Liberal Party. What is wrong with the principles put forward by Mr Howard in those days? Another former Minister in the coalition Government, Senator Messner, on 17 February 1988 said:

That is bad news for Australia because everyone in this country knows the very great degree to which Australians depend upon a reliable, independent broadcasting service from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

Mr Duffy, a former Minister for Communications comes forth to defend that independence and refers to a period when the coalition was in a mood similar to the mood that it is in now. On 5 May 1983, he said:

With respect to the independence of the ABC, I turn at this stage to the record of the people opposite who are now complaining about this issue. Over a period of years there was intimidation of the ABC, continued cuts in its budget and general abuse and denigration of the ABC news and current affairs staff. That criticism came, in particular, from the Country Party, now known as the National Party. That may well be the explanation why a spokesman in this area of communications did not today put forward this matter of public importance against us. Anybody in the Country Party would be embarrassed to talk about anybody on this side of the House in respect of the independence of the ABC.

Let us consider some of the performances. The former member for Gippsland the Honourable Peter Nixon, the then Opposition spokesman, on 17 March 1975, when he was what was somewhat quaintly described as an Opposition front bencher, senior Country Party spokesman on transport and Country Party spokesman on the media, said:
. . . ABC Commissioner is either a naive academic or is part of the plot to disseminate socialist propaganda Australia-wide over ABC radio news.

I want to point out that people become very protective of the ABC's independence or attack it with great enthusiasm depending upon the particular point of view they want adopted at a particular point in time. That seems to me to be evidence of bias on the part of those sorts of people or on the part of that party or on the part of that group rather than a bias on the part of the ABC. I am sure that the ABC is biased, but then the media generally is biased and I suppose everybody in the community, as I have already said, has some sort of bias. The way it is suggested that we get over that is to appoint an ombudsman or some board. Who is going to be the ombudsman? How far are we going to take into account his or her bias? Is that ombudsman going to look not only at the ABC, but at the media generally? Is it proper for us as a Parliament to look simply at the bias of the ABC and not to put that bias, in so far as it exists, in the context of the general bias that exists in the media?

We have spoken much today about the ABC's approach to the war. There would be agreement across party lines about that. But then what do we say about the bias in the press over the affair at Hoechst in Melbourne last year? What do we say about that? What do we say about the reporting of that event? Are we going to have an ombudsman look at that? What about the way the SPC affair at Shepparton was reported? Are we going to have an ability given to the unions or to the employer in each case so that they can challenge the media? Has anybody come in here and abused, in the way the ABC has been abused, the media for the way it treated those two issues?

The reality is that democracy depends upon the ability of everybody to dissent. It is quite proper that people should criticise that dissent. It is quite proper that the various groups within this Parliament-the Australian Democrats, the National Party of Australia, the Liberals, the Australian Labor Party and the Green Party, represented by Senator Vallentine, should exchange healthy debate across the chamber. But that debate takes on a sinister air when there is a threat loaded into it that somehow that dissent, that debate, those differing opinions are going to be visited with sanctions either by the withdrawing of moneys or the threat, as it was made today, of having people imprisoned because they set up a dissent outside this Parliament. That was seriously put today by the Opposition through one of its members. That has not been denied.

Senator Kemp has asked Ministers make it clear that they dissent from people such as Senator Childs. Where is the overriding of the suggestion put by Senator Bishop today that people in this country who dissent should be gaoled for that dissent--

TALK.START.PARA: —I said no such thing. My goodness, you have a variance with the truth.
—Senator Bishop denies that she said that. I understood this to be the situation: she asked a question as to the availability of cells below Parliament House. Was I wrong about that?
—I asked what the intent of the Presiding Officers was in having them cleared out. That is what I asked.

—Senator Bishop will have an opportunity in her following speech to correct any misapprehensions people may have about where she stands. Alternatively, she can seek leave to explain the situation. At this stage, I am asking her not to interrupt Senator Cooney. If Senator Cooney directs his remarks through the Chair I think we might overcome that problem.

—I certainly will. I am glad that I misunderstood Senator Bishop today. I will explain why I misunderstood her. First of all, she asked a question of the President as to whether the cells below this building had been cleared out. She then mentioned the fact that there was a group of dissenters outside the Parliament who had been there for a considerable period of time. I took it-obviously, I was wrong-that there was an inference in all of that that the cells might be available for people and an example of the sorts of people they might be available for was the people who were dissenting outside Parliament. Otherwise, I did not understand what the thrust of it was. If I am wrong about that, I certainly withdraw any imputation against Senator Bishop, for whom I have the greatest respect. I clearly would not have drawn those inferences if they had not been suggested to me in that fashion. But the juxtaposition of the points she was making to the President led me to that belief. In defence of myself, there were other people in the chamber who took the same inference, so it might be a good idea, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, for Senator Bishop to clear up that issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The ABC should not be isolated from the rest of the media. If we are going to criticise it and take it to task for its bias, we should take to task the media generally. Let us not be bullies, picking on one institution over which we might have more power than the others. We should try to do something about that, because, after all, it is not the ABC which is the problem, it is the bias. If the bias exists in the ABC and elsewhere then we should courageously take on the whole of the media.

The next problem is that it is a bit difficult to see who, in this chamber, is going to work out whether the ABC or any other part of the media is biased because, with the exception of Senator Crane, I would say that the rest of us have principles, beliefs, aspirations and attitudes which may give a bent to the sorts of things we do. I congratulate Senator Crane on being free of what the rest of us--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order on behalf of Senator Crane. Senator Cooney did, in fact, say that other than Senator Crane other senators have principles. I ask him to withdraw that reference to Senator Crane.

—If that is how it is taken, I certainly withdraw. I understand that the sorts of things which have been said lead people to conclusions that apparently are wrong. I thought Senator Crane had objected when I was talking about people having beliefs and attitudes which give a particular biased attitude. I thought that he had dissented as far as that was concerned.
—Mr Deputy President, we still have not had a ruling from you as to whether Senator Cooney was to apologise or not.
—Senator Cooney withdrew the remark and so there was not any need for a ruling from me.
—A most vital piece of information has been given to me: the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is conducting an inquiry into the bias and accuracy in current affairs programs.
—All of them.
—All of them. Let us hope that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal approaches that without any attitudes, biases or anything like that.

SPEECH.PARA: In any event, I want to refer to the question of backbenchers differing from the Government. I hope that the occasion never arises where Ministers bring undue pressure on backbenchers who want to express views that differ from the Government. If one looks at the way the founding fathers set up the Constitution of this country, it is quite clear from its three chapters that there is the Parliament, the legislature; the Executive, the Ministers; and the judiciary. They are the three arms which are in balance. To exalt one of those arms-that is, the Ministry-above the others and give it a power to condemn and overrule the members of the legislature-as Senator Childs is-is, in my view, a perversion of the Constitution.

For the proper exercise of democracy and for proper debate in this House, it is absolutely necessary that people have different points of view. I am sure that, at times, there are differing views on the other side of the chamber, though I gather from what has been said tonight that that is very rare. I apologise in advance to Senator Knowles if I offend her, but I suggest that even in the Opposition party room there is from time to time quite heated debate and differences of opinion. If I am wrong in that, I apologise.

Knowing the intellectual capacity of many of the people on the other side and the way they put their arguments forward vigorously, that could happen. But if it does not happen, I am sorry for suggesting it. There might be the odd difference of opinion even amongst the Australian Democrats. I know that they have their differences. I simply say that that is not a sign of weakness on anybody's part. I would have thought that was a sign of a good and healthy democracy. If honourable senators in this chamber-and this Government-insist that everybody should support the war and that it is somehow wrong or even traitorous to oppose the war, we have a society such as that which exists in Iraq.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collins) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to be misrepresented. I make reference to Senator Cooney's outrageous statements about the question that I asked today concerning the clearing out of cells which exist within the basement of this building. I asked Mr President to confirm that detention facilities exist within the basement of this Parliament House and, indeed, whether these cells are being cleared in readiness for future use.
—They are not. I have been there.
—So have we.
—Minister, Senator Bishop has the call.
—I am just trying to assist.
—I would like to agree with you, but you are not assisting.

—The implication is that if they are being cleared out-and they were previously being used for storerooms and have been cleared out in the recent period-for what purpose are they being cleared out and in what context? I specifically asked the question in the context of what occurred to a member of my staff in recent days. A member of my staff parked her car adjacent to the Senate entrance to this Parliament on a Sunday and was called later that day in a panic to come and remove her car because people were about to rip the doors off, tear the engine out, and otherwise destroy it as a matter of some urgency because it was a security matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite clearly we are acting under stringent security provisions-one can call it amber alert; call it what you will. That is why I raised the question of the scuffle that took place between bus loads of protesters outside Parliament House. This again raises the question of whether they are within the ambit of the Parliament House and therefore under the authority of the Presiding Officers or whether they are on public space and, therefore, subject to the discipline of the local constabulary. These are all questions which require an answer.

Senator Cooney, after having been corrected on one occasion, went on to perpetrate the misrepresentation of the truth. But then should I have been surprised? He talked about the virtues of bias and how acceptable bias is and yet, of course, immediately one introduces bias one bends the truth. That is exactly what happened in this chamber tonight. I am pleased that Senator Cooney in the course of his speech had the good grace to apologise. I will accordingly also have the good grace to accept his apology.

That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this occasion to quote from the book by Douglas Lockwood entitled Australia's Pearl Harbour:

SPEECH.PARA: Destruction came to Darwin in mid-morning on February 19, 1942, when war in the Pacific was but ten weeks old.
Destruction came while the sun shone, with a gentle breeze smudging a few white caps on blue waves rolling in from Beagle Gulf and the Clarence Strait.

Destruction by an enemy was brought that day for the first time to Australian soil. It came violently though not unexpectedly, with bombs and bullets and cannon shells scything through life as they splintered a fleet and a town and almost a human spirit.
Destruction and terror were such as to lead to a panic of people. Hundreds fled.
They left half smoked cigarettes, half finished drinks, unopened mail, unmade beds, incomplete jobs, open doors and caged pets.

They walked and they ran. They rode on bicycles and they rode in cars, in garbage trucks, ice cream carts, sanitary carts and road graders. Women and children, the aged, the infirm and those able bodied men who could escape detection rode in an evacuee train of cattle trucks and flattops that left them exposed to tropical heat.
The men who fled were not all civilians. Among them were many subject to a military discipline that was in tatters.

Those who did not flee included nearly 250 men and women, Australian, British and American, black and white, near-black and near-white whose bodies were at the bottom of the harbour, or soaking in oil-drenched mud on the beaches, or lying shattered in inadequate shelters.

Darwin that day became Australia's Pearl Harbour, centre of a debacle in the traditional tragedy of war without equal on Australian soil. Appropriately to the analogy, the Japanese task force which wrought this havoc was part of the same force, with identical leaders, which had started the Pacific war.

Forty-nine years ago is a very important time that we should remember. I am sure that there were many people in Darwin today, both local residents and war veterans of a number of wars since the Second World War, who took the occasion to think about the events of today and today's war in the Gulf.

We must pay tribute to the men and the women who fought and died during the air raid attacks on Darwin on 19 February 1942. The bombing, regarded as the worst disaster in history on Australian soil, killed 243 people, left 300 wounded and caused major damage to shipping and ground facilities. Here we are, nearly half a decade later, and the people of the Northern Territory, of course, cannot afford to distance themselves from any war.

Next year will be the fiftieth anniversary of the bombing of Darwin; it will be an important hallmark occasion. I know that the Northern Territory Government has established a very special committee to look to the future and, in particular, to look at commemorating those events next year. It has proved a controversial project. It has attracted international attention and, hopefully, it will attract international tourists. The fact that many Japanese tourists and, in fact, people who served in the Second World War for Japan may take the occasion to come to Darwin next year, of course, produces conflicts and tensions for those Australian veterans who must accommodate that change and, at the same time, must recognise that 50 years is also an important stage in history. I bring to the Senate's attention tonight the fact that 19 February is an important occasion for Australia. It is certainly a point at which we should be considering carefully what we will do on 19 February next year.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INACCURATE PAYMENTS

The Commission will be introducing administrative changes to the CDEP scheme to take effect from 1 April 1991. These changes have been designed to simplify the calculation of communities' entitlements and should reduce the possibility of inaccuracies. This streamlining will assist the monitoring process.
MANAGEMENT AND ACCOUNTING TRAINING

The lack of qualified Aboriginal people has been a problem for DAA/ATSIC and communities alike. Training initiatives have been taken by DAA/ATSIC and the Department of Employment, Education and Training to address this issue.

As a part of new administrative arrangements for CDEP, a Training Needs Schedule and a training program to meet these needs for each CDEP is required. Through programs administered by the Department of Employment, Education and Training (Training for Aboriginals Program) funding is available for communities to engage a consultant, where appropriate, to prepare training needs analyses and/or training schedules for project participants.
ENTITLEMENTS, ALLOWANCES AND AWARD PAYMENTS

Since the ANAO audits of Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory were conducted there has been a significant improvement in the take up rate of the Family Allowance Supplement by CDEP participants. The Department of Social Security is promoting this allowance through its Aboriginal Liaison Officers and Community Agents.
While ATSIC encourages the payment of wages at award rates, the setting of pay rates is left to the discretion of community councils and organisations.

Award coverage for CDEP communities is a complex issue as the nature of the work generally is only part-time. The Commission is currently in the process of contracting a consultant to undertake research into industrial relations issues associated with CDEPs including the question of award coverage.
