TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 17 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: - With reference to the Minister's response to a Question without Notice addressed to him by the Member for Boothby on 5 December 1990 (House of Representatives Hansard, p. 4461), what factors would lead the Government to reassess the continuation of world parity pricing for domestic crude oil production?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: - Oil is an internationally traded commodity and it would be counterproductive for Australia to attempt to insulate itself from price changes in the international market.
- Any attempt to artificially hold down the price of Australian crude oil in order to prevent increases being passed on to the consumer would have a number of adverse consequences
* it would induce Australian producers to increase oil exports rather than supply the domestic market, in order to take advantage of the higher international prices
* it would reduce the incentive to conserve fuel, leading to increased rates of depletion of a scarce resource
* it would discourage investment in oil exploration and development in Australia with serious consequences for our ability to supply our future needs.

- As the Chairman of the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA), Professor Alan Fels, noted in a press release on 4 October 1990, ``One factor not to be overlooked is that the price of oil has had a history of rises and falls . . . there have been a number of occasions when the price of crude oil has exceeded $US30 per barrel and subsequently it fell. Oil is a commodity the price of which is very sensitive to small changes in the quantity supplied and demanded. Basically, it is price inelastic in the short term. Buyers will pay a high price to secure supplies if there are fears of shortages''.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 21 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the procedures for the determination of priorities in identifying illegal immigrants.
(2) Is a set of guidelines issued to all officers.
(3) What training is given to officers to ensure that the procedures of apprehension used are professional.
(4) Are officers required to give all `illegal immigrants' a written statement of their rights (with translation if necessary).
(5) What is the definition of `work' within a family situation.

(6) How does the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs ensure its officers are giving attention to the serious breaches of Australia's immigration laws rather than harassment of people making direct contact to briefly extend a visit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Illegal entrants are identified through a system which records details of all persons who have remained in Australia after the expiry of their permission to stay. The priorities for locating and encouraging illegal entrants to leave Australia or deporting those who fail to leave voluntarily were announced by the Government on 5 August 1990. They include the following:-
- follow up temporary entrants, including visitors and students, who overstay their temporary entry permits;
- follow up people whose applications to remain are rejected to ensure they actually leave;
- apprehend illegal entrants who are working;
- carry out checks of employers and educational institutions;
- deport illegal entrants who have criminal convictions;
and
- investigate organised immigration rackets.

(2) The Migration Act and Regulations provide the legislative framework for the compliance function. Detailed instructions and procedures for applying the legislation are contained in the Procedures Advice Manual. The guidelines (PAM) are publicly available through the Commonwealth Government Bookshop. All staff are required to apply these procedures in a fair, consistent and lawful manner.

(3) In addition to the training options in administrative law, decision-making, client relations and cultural awareness available to all Departmental staff, specific training is being provided for compliance staff on compliance specific matters. This includes briefing/training on new and revised legislation and procedures as changes are introduced as well as intensive training on the full range of compliance practices and procedures. Additional funds of $425,000 have been provided specifically for this purpose for 1990/91 financial year.

(4) All illegal entrants who are apprehended are given a document entitled Very Important Notice (VIN). This document details the access rights to legal counsel and consular representation, the eligibility requirements for applying for entry permits, and explains the procedures concerning illegal entrants. The document is frequently updated to accurately reflect the changes to the Migration Act and Regulations. For this reason the document is not translated; instead interpreters are used to assist persons to fully understand the Very Important Notice.
(5) The Procedures Advice Manual defines `work' as an undertaking of activity which might otherwise be available to an Australian permanent resident whether in a paid or unpaid capacity.

(6) Compliance staff deal only with people who have breached the conditions of their entry permit and those who attempt to circumvent the provisions of the Migration Act and Regulations. People who abide by the conditions of their entry permit are not subject to compliance action nor are those illegal entrants who are able to satisfy requirements for extending their stay in Australia.

However, people illegally in Australia are subject to the provisions of the Migration Act and Regulations until such time as they either regularise their status in Australia, or leave. When an illegal entrant approaches the Department directly, procedures require staff to satisfy themselves as to whether or not that person has the right to lodge an application for an entry permit or, if not, whether the person should be arrested, detained, released or allowed to remain in the community pending their departure from Australia. In practice the majority of people who approach the Department are not arrested and detained, but are questioned to enable officers to make decisions on their eligibility to apply to stay or options for their departure from Australia.
